column10: I prefer the original and Battle at Antares... but this remake is decent enough to bring new players to game.  Mostly what bothers me is the combat,  I preferred the old method of turn based combat where each ship was individually controlled.  Anyhow... still worth a recommendation.
Great upgrade for Galactic Civ II.  I have been waiting for a new Strategy game!!!

23.7 of my 24h Playtime was trying to get this game to work with the mods I wanted. All 11 mods. 

Closest I got to 'playing' with mods was freezing at the end of TURN ZERO. (the first turn.) Other players said these mods work and what order to put them in. I think I installed and arranged them correctly; they do not work FOR ME.
All these years later and this is still a solid fun game
Good Game.

Played it many years back. Gave up, it was too buggy. Tried it again in 2024, nice experience. Not as good as Civ VI with all DLC, but a good one. 
I hope they continue the series
good if on sale.

It plays very closely to Masters of Orion 2, which is one of my favorite 4x games.  Turned based, upgraded graphics, and the Ai is not blatantly violent toward you in diplomacy.  You can play hard and quick or slow and steady, just be aware that longer games will start to be slower from turn to turn.  still fun though.

It's My First 4X but there's nothing wrong with that. Example: when you research better stuff for your ships, you are immediately taken to an 'Update Your Blueprints' screen, where you can just click 'Update All', which keeps your ships up to date while removing the designing ships part. This, and other streamlining options keep the turns flowing one after the other. 

Not a fan of the Antaren thing. They will come by every once in a while to blow your stuff up, while bypassing your system defenses. Not really sure why they did that.

Most of the 3D cutscenes are a waste of time, as is the voice acting.

I've played complex 4X games and it's refreshing to only have a few things to deal with each turn. I like this game.

I paid 4€ for this game. Great value at that price, but I probably would have written the same review at 15-20€.

STREAMLINED 4X FOR 4€, WHAT'S NOT TO LIKE.
I like the first one but Master 1,2 and 3 seem to be junk on my

This is basically Civ in Space. It's not very deep or lore engaging like Endless Space or Stellaris, but it is a fun turn based game. I would recommend for easy playing. I wouldn't recommend if you're looking for something that draws you in and challenges you-for that, look at Stellaris as the pacesetter.
Awesome turn based strategy!

Wonderful game with that "just one more turn" quality that every space/colony sim needs.  The ai of the other factions can be a tad predictable, but ultimately a very worthwhile investment.  I would encourage availing of the DLC to press greater diversity of experience, but even in the basic package, this is a a delightful time sink :)
The game has good pace, allows for variety of style and great cinematic interactions with other species in the galaxy

This game is a solid TBS game for people who like 4X games. It's a little light on diplomacy in one player mode, as I generally play it, and it can get a little tiresome if you play it too much, but twice a year or so, it's an amazing game to play.
Fun
This game won't play.

It fixes all the older problems of the Original Masters of Orion.  Also offers custom mode so you can develop your own racial traits and still use the diff races.  If you want to play the silicoids but have them have great research, you can.

Bought it at release and wasn't too thrilled. Tried it 8 years later again together with 5x, UCP and tactical mods. Boy, what a difference! Modders made the game work as intended and more. Devs could have made a ton of money with dlcs, if they had fixed their initial mess themselves. Well, probably the publisher's fault.

With  those mods this game is a jewel. Just make sure you follow the installation instructions. It isn't hard by any means, just know that clicking on "subscribe"  ain't enough.
It's a great remake of a great game, and blends the old MOOs into a new MOO!
A little tedious but so fun.

Master of Orion... game speaks for itself. Only issue is the game really slows down after about 300 - 350 turns, and becomes progressively slower as you go on. Developers programming issue. Course they will never fix it.

it's a classic game that I used to play in the late 90s and now at 45 it took me back to those days
Great remake of a classic!

If you enjoyed any of the previous entries in the Master of Orion series you will love this game. It is a simpler and more streamlined galaxy takeover game than Stellaris (also an excellent game but that has so much more depth and micromanagement that I don't care to handle).
Great game

As of now the game is non working. It is missing DLL files, it will not load a game sometimes, menu icons are missing, and it is slow. I have uninstalled and reinstalled the game multiple times as well as turn off all mods that made the game playable. I don't know what is the issue with it but I would not recommend this game as of right now. Even on a sale.
one of my favorite games. the entire series "maybe not 3".

First, I've played the first MOO back in the 90s. I've played MOO2 since release and likely have thousands of hours. I bought this game on release and couldnt get into it. I just recently played again and pushed through... the AI just sucks.... I'm almost 500 turns into this game (Huge galaxy 8 races on hard) none of the races will engage me in battle. Their disposition towards me remains in the center. No matter how much I reject their treaties etc. If you dont start war with them, they will not start war with you. Diplomacy is absolute garbage. All they do is try to form alliance when in trouble, constantly offer you credit for gifts, never anything else. never request to exchange tech or anything else. No random attacks. Not like MOO2 where your cool with a race and they show up in your system with a fleet, and declare war because they side against you with another race. The AI on this game doesnt have any initiative. they dont do anything! At almost 500 turns in.... I had to start a war myself. and each turn takes a VERY long time once the galaxy is populated. When you click next turn... your going to be sitting there forced to watch every little mini-battle for each race in every system... it takes  HOURS to get through a handful of turns. what in the world were they thinking? The art, media, voice acting, graphics are great. The game play just sucks.......
Simple and fun. Good voice actors. Easy and relaxing empire builder.
I love that Game. So good technology tree and diplomacy settings. I never played Orion before but I love Master of Orion Game. I just extincted Maclers first time. So good to found such simulator.

If you're familiar with Wargaming/WG Labs, it's about what you'd expect; a solid tech demo spackled-over with some decent art assets. If you're hoping for a space 4x game, go pick up Endless Space 2 instead. Even with the hilariously-bad bidding mechanic, ES2 is still just reasonably better by every single metric.
classic fun

This is a great game with one huge caveat. You will need to install the "Unofficial Code Patch", otherwise it will be extremely buggy, especially during ship combat. You will also want to use mods to deal with some of the shortcoming in the original game.

The game does require a lot of micro-management of colonies. There are mods to reduce this and there is an active modding community. If you love games like MOO1 or MOO2, you will probably like this game, but you will have to spend time learning the mod scene to overcome it's shortcomings.

Five years ago, I made a huge mod called "Nebula Galaxy" that works around the bugs without using UCP. Revisiting this game, I see UCP has come a long ways in fixing bugs. I am now starting a new mod that will work with UCP to bring out the best of both.
Be ready to sacrifice many, many, many hours to this game.

Honestly, Master of Orion 2 is way better.  The tech tree is dumbed down and simplified.  It lost too many of the features of the original which is just way better.  Economic victory is way too easy.  Just doesn't have the same feel as MOO1 & MOO2.  There is no boarding action during combat, you can't capture ships to steal tech, totally lame combat system.

Don't waste your money.  I used to love the Moo series but this is a hot pile of garbage.  No bug fixes, no updates, you absolutely NEED to install the UCP mod to fix all the glaring issues.  I still keep getting crashes though and it's just not worth the effort anymore.  The community itself is friendly but this game itself is barely playable until you can't continue anymore due to some bug or another.

It's an OK 4x game. My biggest critiques are:
1. Movement is way to slow, you can only ever move your units one jump space even if you have the best engines in the game, which means it takes FOREVER to move units across the map.
2. It's too easy to make every planet a fortress and makes it very slow to conquer your enemy.
3. You basically want to colonize every planet and build every building, which gets boring.
4. Diplomacy is meh, basically you have trade treaties with everyone except maybe one person who you hate.

That being said, it's still pretty fun to explore, conquer, design ships and build armadas. It's fun, but it definitely gets old and doesn't offer a lot of replay value IMO. I would buy it again on sale and if you do play it make sure to play on a small map with more AIs than normal to keep the action alive, on big maps things are too spread out to ever get interesting.
great game

Bit quirky and far away from the legendary MOO1, but once you get into it, its addictive and has the right amount of micromanagement tinkering and automation possible.
Battles are hard to grasp but I often just Autoresolve em, like it was a dice game, cause they are real-time Command and Conquer like minigames in an otherwise 4x turnbased everything.
The game has a fairly small but okay wiki for it, with some holes in the info, but the community has lots of mods as the game allows for mods built-in to the game already, which is HUGE for longevity.
The Reddit community for this game is strong.
PS: To kill a star, Star Wars or Babylon5/Vorlon style, equip a Stellar converter to a Titan or Doom Star and attack an enemy planet and pick Destroy. This took some finding out to figure out.
a bit on the simplistic side of things but more than often, simple is just plainly better.

I have found it has a good balance of growth, production, improvement, and maintenance that keeps you involved throughout the game. For example, if you try to build everything on every planet you will run out of money, have to raise taxes, everyone goes on strike, and you quickly loose. The balance of the game make it advantageous to think about what you build and where. A weather controller will cost the same on any planet, but is more cost effective on worlds producing large amounts of food because it is a flat percentage increase (i.e. more food per BC spent). 
   I almost forgot to add, the AI created ships suck (a lot). always check before accepting an upgrade.

Turn based strategy isn't something I enjoy without a decent story line. This... was a complete waste of time. I played a 630 turn game of galactic conquest on the largest map. Throughout the whole game I was left wondering when some sort of story would show up. Sure enough, GNN chimed in occasionally, but that got old after a while because there are only so many scripted scenes for that and it revolves around game stats. Maybe another update will roll out with something more engaging than game stats and a way to go beyond the surface level of cinematic AI controlled battles. It was a mildly entertaining way to pass a lot of time.

good game (if you mod the crap out of it)

Let us start with the good.  The game maintains the spirit and play style of the original MOO and many good things came through from MOO2.  The landing screens are fun to watch (though they do get repetitive) but the moprhing of the planet views as the population soars is a nice feature.  I like the ship customization, graphics and voice overs (I can imagine that they weren't cheap).  Generally game play is smooth and I didn't encounter any critical errors.

That aside the game comes with frustrations and this is unfortunate as someone who was around for all previous versions.  Overall I played it 7 years after its release (I was busy :D).

1. In comparison to other games, like civilization, no victory condition can be chosen.  One of the most frustrating things is to be told by the computer that "XXX won and though it would be a hard grind they are 'the best'".  Starting before and continuing after the message, I was ripping up stated empire apart.  A complete oversight in a strategy game market that seems to favor a particular 'way to win'.  Not being able to turn this off and subsequently turning off other victory conditions is a slap to the face.

2. DLC's are a money grab.  In the original version of the game the races being offered as DLC were original to the game.  This observation was made from a quick look at the race selection screen in the beginning.  So, all I can see is that a significant purchase price of the games value for the DLC that only adds a race.  During ship customization, there is a second picture that can be chosen for the model instead of the 'standard'.  I did not check to see if DLC's offered up new ship models based on race, but THAT would have been a good feature for sale.

3. No Hotseat multiplayer.  I actually  peeked into the multiplayer servers and they are more dry than a piece of toast on the back deck lid from a car in North America in August or more vacant than a politician's soul (do they have souls?). 

4. Autosaves - I did not see an option to control this.  On one hand, you certainly will not build up too many saves, and that is because I can only see a single one being kept.  There is no way to correct further back than your last turn other than manually saving yourself.  It would have been nice to have a selection to keep the last 10 or 15.  Something configurable.  (possible that money went to the voice over budget).

For a game where voices that are repetitive, too much was likely invested and things that would have been important for gameplay likely glossed over (I would be assuming due to budget).  Baldur's Gate 3 is a good example where good voiceovers in a very rich story line with alternate paths are a key investment! Understanding games are expensive to produce, I do wonder if the Project Manager of Chief in Charge on this was a true fan of MOO2, arguably the best game of this series.  Unfortunately they missed the mark on improving and lost maintaining that resonance by clipping the victory condition.  Even though you can continue 'for just one more turn' (reference to Civilization and Sid), the game doesn't feel the same, in fact I did not notice the Antarans continuing to attack, though it is possible I didn't give it enough time.  

I do not recommend buying this.  I have had better deals (cost wise) with the civilization series, and certainly recommend grabbing them, especially when on sale.  They have continued to maintain their timeless allure, and set the bar high for how games should be done.

It's essentially a remake of the 1996 Master of Orion 2 with some of the mechanics introduced from the unfinished and buggy Master of Orion 3. I wouldn't say it's better or worse than MoO2 because there are enough differences that it's noticeably different and there are things I feel each game does far better, though fans of MoO2 will probably struggle for awhile due to the changes between the games. 

Pros over MoO2-
- Most of the species and the ships look better from updated graphics.
- A greater degree of customization in the galaxy seed, how quickly or slowly you want production, research, and population growth to be for that game, how long the game can run, and what conditions for winning are available.
- Expanded diplomatic options with other races including the options to buy/sell tech and colonies, offering multiple items in exchange for tech or treaties, and declaring war on another empire in exchange for money/tech.
- Trading tech with AI players is a bit fairer though with there being less tech available to trade it's still usually more useful to offer to sell a tech.
-Galactic "monsters" can be detected without first having to encounter them with a ship (and probably losing that ship) or by using the Omniscient trait (though it does make that trait far less useful in MoO).
- Greater control over espionage actions and players can ransom or kill captured opposing spies. Spies can level up becoming more effective offensively or defensively.
- The size of the map and the number of players determines the number of leaders an empire can have and though leaders now only have one or two abilities (compared to up to 4 in MoO2) some of the abilities are very powerful.
- Barren planets are able to provide food. Toxic planets can be cleaned up to become barren planets that can then be terraformed. The new Volcanic planet is great for heavy industry due to pollution not being a factor on them, though volcanic planets can't be terraformed and the Lava Breather homeworld trait basically requires taking the Lithovore trait since Volcanic/Inferno planets otherwise can't produce enough food at the start of the game to support your population.
- Pollution affects food production instead of losing industry efficiency.
- Changing a ship blueprint automatically updates any ships currently in production or in queue.

Neutral-
- The game uses MoO3's starlanes making choke points easier and players can explore the entire galaxy from the beginning. Players can buy and trade star charts as soon as they make diplomatic contact with other empires.
- Galaxy map sizes favor larger number of players or larger games so even the smallest maps have a few dozen systems.
- MoO2's turn based combat is replaced by a version of MoO3's real time combat (I much more prefer turn based). It offers a lot of interesting options for combat but it becomes a clusterf*** keeping track of what's going on once combat involves more than a few dozen ships.
- All tech has branching paths and prerequisites- more realistic but it means each empire specializes less and overall there are fewer times upon completing a tech field where you have to choose between what technologies to learn.
- The tech trees have been overhauled. A number of techs have been removed and a few have been added. Empire wide techs require building and system techs usually limit the bonus of that tech to just the planet it is built on .
- Population growth is dependent primarily on the amount of excess food produced. Food can only be distributed within a system once the technology has been developed.
- Attacking a colony directly requires bombs thus the player can design some specialization with their ships (but not to MoO3's levels).
-Morale no longer offers bonuses or penalties to colony production but instead factors in how many population of a colony will work at a given tax amount (higher taxes lower morale, tech raises morale). I would almost put this as a negative as it means until mid-game most of your planets will start featuring striking population once at 6 population (7 with a Marine Barracks).

Things MoO2 does better-
- 3 of the original races are paid DLC
- Any condition for winning you disable is completely disabled (examples- turning off Political Victory means the Galactic Senate never forms. Turning off Economic Victory disables players being able to buy, sell, and trade GMF stocks).
- Unless you want a challenge there is no point enabling Antarian Victory. Everything about the Antarians is worse- from the lackluster design, that the Antarians will always attack the player with the highest score and always at the same planet (which the same planet is the only way it becomes possible to make a defense). In MoO2 Antarians would send slowly growing raids of ships with end game tech and by mid game players could build large enough fleets with enough developed technology to defeat them. In this game Antarians have only slightly higher levels of tech than players but rely on overwhelming numbers that actively change depending on the leading player's military strength (no matter how many ships that player builds beforehand when the portal opens every 30-45 turns the Antarian strength will be greater than the player's).  In late game this can result in raids that are massively stronger than what's defending Antares.
- Combat is actually kind of boring and with how shields regenerate focus fire is a necessity. Planetary defenses are also not as useful in MoO (possibly because they are no longer an optional technology to learn and instead something the player will get at certain tech points)
- There are fewer race penalties available in custom races to make min/max races and a number of the races in the game are unbalanced (can't be made in character creator due to using more points than are available)
- MoO2 offered 4 different types of governments, each with their own strengths and weaknesses and each with a different playstyle. They have been removed here. 
- Trade and Research treaties only last 20 turns and have to be repurchased each time at an increasing cost. Research treaties are not worth the high cost even early in the game and usually an empire can't afford them (they provide a one time boost of research points at the end of the treaty). Trade treaties are almost a necessity for much of a game if an empire is doing any kind of planetary development.
- By mid-game the player is usually struggling financially with economic technologies and trade treaties being a necessity due to spy, leader, and development upkeep costs. Upon attaining the late-game Galactic Currency Exchange tech money becomes almost unnecessary outside of refitting and buyouts.
- Declining any AI diplomatic offers harms relations with that empire and having any diplomatic contact with an empire they are at war with also harms relations. Factors affecting relations can linger for 40-50 turns. When it comes to major treaties (non-aggression pact, alliances, peace treaties) the AI will often make heavyhanded demands if the player asks but will offer to bribe the player with the same treaty and no demands if the player waits (sometimes in the span of a couple turns).
- Refitting ships can be very expensive and can only be done with BC. Refitting engines is cheap but upgrading or even adding additional weapons increases the cost significantly. The cost feels bugged as generally the price to increase the number of weapons on a ship (even by 1) costs more than stripping the ship to add all new weapons.
- Some tech only becomes available too late to be all that useful (like the Planetary Supercomputer when the tech tree is nearly maxed out) and research becomes useless (and a drain of BC) once an empire maxes out the tech tree (in MoO2 continued development made ship tech smaller and cheaper).
Classic gaming at its best.

Sometimes you just want to play a game that is easy to use, can have some depth of play if you choose, and decent graphics.  Nothing earth shattering, but just a simple fun game.........this is it!

(The above was my review in Nov 2019)

Today, Sept 2023, I was looking at the reviews for this game and was completely surprised to see all the negative comments. People complained of many bugs, crashes, and the game being unplayable. In my over 180 hours of playing this game I never saw any problems, so I decided to play again to see if something had changed. So I started up the game, made all the option changes that I wanted, picked the races I wanted to play against, and tweaked some of the settings (like having GNN not show up and no pirates)....and I then started. I played quite a while and found no issues, not even the slightest bug or hiccup. The game was smooth, the graphics decent (for a game that has been out for 7+ years), the challenge of creating a space empire still there......I enjoyed myself immensely! I can only wonder how others have set up/tweaked their gaming machines, that something as simple as MoO is having problems. Bottom line, MoO is a fun game dealing with research, warship design, diplomacy, and strategy. The game is simple to play but can be hard to master. I have found it to be bug and crash free, no issues in over 180 hours of play. It is simply and VERY good game and I highly recommend it.

What starts as a sleek interface with pretty cut scenes and space combat quickly turns into a tedious "colonize every plant, build every building, research all technologies, make some ships, and watch boring combat where choices don't matter." Somehow worse than MOO3.

If you're looking for "Civ in space but with no need for strategy or diplomacy," this is the game for you.

If you're looking for "MOO1/MOO2 but newer" you'll have to keep looking. There is none of the magic of the original two releases.

Nothing like MoO2.....
You have to wait a million years for it to load just by passing a turn. Incredibly annoying. The graphics aren't worth it. The combat is even worse than evolving. 
Compared to MoO2 and Stellaris, or Galactic Civs it's pretty meh. Otherwise if you never played those it's pretty good.
It just needs a turbo mode.

Is it fun to play?  Yes.  Is it a faithful remake of MOO 1-3? No.   Is it full of bugs?  Yes.

I loved the original MOO and for some reason this remake takes MOOs turn based tactical combat and make it RTS.  RTS games are fun in their own way but MOO combat should be tactical turn based.  Unfortunately now the RTS combat is frustrating, hard to control and the auto resolve option gives you way worse outcomes than if you just run it real time with the AI controlling your fleet.  MOOs turn based tactical combat was one of my favourite things about it and they just threw that into the dumpster.  

Overall I recommend it but think of it as MOO re-imagined more than a remake and you have to look past all the bugs that are never going to get fixed.
great strategy game. each race with distinct advantages(and disadvantages). Has what was great with the originals, and added things that improve on what made those great
Published in 2016? STILL SO MANY GAME-BREAKING BUGS AND BALANCE ISSUES. Virtually unplayable.

this game is great, there is plenty to do, and plenty of ways to do it, i keep seeing comments giving it a bad recommendation, then complaining about it being a strategy game, or not having options setup correctly to make the game easier, there are plenty of different aspects to the game, and it is a great strategy game, you can't just jump in and hope for the best, you can't just concentrate on one aspect, such as tech, because other races will just steal your advanced tech, or will blow you out of the cosmos with ships they spent time building while u were concentrating on research, the amount of depth that is in this game, and the amount that some extra mods can add, is great, and the graphics are pretty cool too

I remember having the CD installation when this game was released, and the reviews stating that it had "the most aggressive AI ever conceived" at the time.. 
Since then, and hearing of the many changes made in its graphics and gameplay.. i had been looking forward to seeing how the changes affected it. And im glad to say that it's much improved!! 

Initially, the whole game felt like you were thrown into the deep end without any instructions - so unless you had played any of the first 2 versions, you had no idea what you were doing and just winging it! That part, im glad to say - has DRAMATICALLY changed!! It no longer feels that way, the controls are a lot easier to understand and much less confusing... 

Graphic wise, definitely an improvement too.. cinematic cut scenes are a massive improvement and gives a feeling of being more immersive at times.. 

Overall, love the revised version.. if i had to pick on anything.. wish the included all the races instead of having to pay for some of them..

For an old Master of Orion addict like myself this game is really not something I should have on my drive. It's way too easy to spend way too many hours playing this. 

The nostalgia is there, the artwork is spot on, the voice acting is a real treat for someone into Star Trek and other shows. This game is mostly a revamp of the old Master of Orion 2 (MoO2) but it has some features from MoO3, like the star lanes. Those give you a chance to block off your opponents and concentrate your forces in choke points.

You have a limit of 7 Leaders and those can be any mix of ship or colony leaders. You no longer get the last Orion by beating the guardian. Other space monsters are there as well. Antarans are there aswell but they are somewhat easier than in MoO2.

Space battle is "real time" with pause function. Missile boats can still take out beam ships by shooting and scooting but the map size is of course limited. Many maps have asteroids that block both missiles and beams. Other maps have nebula parts and when inside a nebula your shields will be down (unless you have the Hard Shields option added to your ships).

The tech tree is a bit limited and I wish there was a "Future tech" in the end that you could just research over and over again for further minor bonuses to ships.

All in all it's a fun game. And at 80% discount I just couldn't resist it.

Fun galactic sci-fi strategy game with different combat/unit system than Civ 6.
It is fundamentally similar to Civ, but with a different map system.

Runs off a single core, no optimisation and abandoned after seemingly day 1. Seems the devs and/or publisher have only interest in day 1 sales after building hype with zero interest in doing more than the bare minimum. You can fix problems, you can't fix lazy.

I can’t believe I’m saying this but… I don’t recommend this game!

I played MOO2 excessively in my youth and stand by my position that it was/is the best space 4X game of all time. All they had to do was update the graphics and maybe the combat to a 3D experience and the next MOO release would have been very well received.

The graphics have been updated and do look great, but the combat is TERRIBLE. Still not in a 3D space (combat is all on one plane) and the “Admiral” control of the ships is painful to experience (not to mention the “odds of winning” calculation is WAY off). It would have been better to keep the turn-based combat of MOO2! Instead, you end up learning how to cheese the opposition without using all the combat options provided (which don’t seem to work anyway).

Oh, and then there’s the very annoying marine invasion situation where ALL of your troops just disappear after wiping out the opposition in battle. Even if you landed 20 troop ships to attack a planet defended by 1 population, ALL your troops are used up… gone.

But that’s not the real problem… the game is just dull! It’s lost its charm. It didn’t feel like I was exploring strange new worlds or building a civilization or interacting with other cultures (diplomacy is flat). I just did the same process every turn on each planet over and over.

I went through the whole game (which was a yawn fest) and “won” via conquest (wiping out everyone and then rebuilding, as that was easier than dealing with a conquered population), just before being able to create the portal to take the fight to the Antarans (who were comically not terrifying – more like annoying bugs), only to find out that because I met the conquest victory conditions, I can no longer enter the Antaran portal that I had just built… WHAT?!? Why? That was the ONLY reason I kept playing this tedious game…

Oh well.

This game is decent, but is not as good as some of the other similar offerings such as Endless Space 2, Sins of a Solar Empire, or Stellaris. The music composed by Dave Govett is some of the best I have heard in these types of games, however the way his music is incorporated into the game is very poor, where we end up hearing basically the same two musical loops over and over again, ad nausium. So if they had improved how music was implemented in this game, it would have been a lot better. The game play is okay to bad. The AI is either pathetically easy or so hard it wipes you out quickly but very little in between nuance. The initial Pirates AI mechanic is horrible, where tiny bands of pirates attack you incessantly and can easily wipe you out early game. So I always end up disabling pirates in the custom game settings on launch of a new single player game (which is unfortunate). The AI in this game is really dumb. The graphics of the ships in this game is mediocre to poor. The games I mentioned above are far better alternatives. This game looks like it was developed by one person using the Unity game engine, and getting all their assets from the Unity assets store. Where they did a great job is in the voice over cast, where we have famous Star Trek  actors such as Michael Dorn (who played Worf). and John DeLancie, who played Star Trek Q, voicing the Human ambassador. So that was a really nice touch. Too bad the game itself is so mediocre or this could have been great. The space battle simulator is laughably pathetic. This game would have been so much better if they had a good space battle like Endless Space 2 does (which has the best battles) or like Sins of a Solar Empire. Seeing games like this be so mediocre makes we want to try to develop my own space strategy 4X game. The only reason I gave this game a thumbs up is because some things are really good while others are 'meh' to poor. Its not a game I would say avoid playing (hence no thumbs down), but its not an amazing experience either. So hopefully by giving this game a thumbs up, it will encourage people to buy the game and hopefully development will improve over time.

I remember not getting very far into the game when I first bought it and couldn't remember why I'd stopped.  I reinstalled it recently and remembered.  There's just nothing to it.  The game is probably the most watered down 4X experience imaginable.  None of the options for the races make them play distinctly differently, every racial decision comes down to minor bonuses or penalties to basic stats.  Nothing about the colonization and expansion phase is interesting. Ship design has some possibilities, but there just isn't enough to really go anywhere.  

Everything about it is just so simple.  Also I personally dislike how they tried to make nothing in the game serious at all.  I hate listening to my advisors trying to make humorous small talk.  And the Klackon adviser's face is nightmare fuel.  After playing it again for an hour and a half I uninstalled it and went back to Endless Space 2 which actually has interesting racial options and factions that play distinctly differently from each other and some real customization.
Voice acting is 10/10, If conquering the stars tickles your fancy get this game! A remake worth playing.

OMG does the AI cheat!

I picked custom race and I set the bonuses to get the most out of tech, research and science advancement.
I colonized 5 worlds before the computer players had 3. 

My area of the galaxy was locked out by unstable warp paths so I felt rather safe.

I conquered the pirates in my area and allied and supported the free pre-warp races, 
all seemed good. I was up to 12 planets that were mine.

Then all hell broke lose.
The AI players started showing up and scouting my space. How, I asked! 
There are no paths to warp into my area and they do not have the tech to cross the unstable paths.

I developed the unstable warplane tech first and the AI kept coming and begging for it. I said no!

About 20 turns later, the AI is still asking for the warp tech however, they are now
colonizing planets in my area of space. I see war ships of theirs in my area as well as scouts and colony ships.

Next I look at the graph and various areas to see how I am doing against them and all the AI races have more 
tech points and more tech than I. Along with they are better than me in every way except I own the most planets
still and I have the largest population still as well.

Antarans open a portal and attack one of the AI, actually taking out a huge fleet the AI owns.
Then jump back into their portal. That AI had it's Victory points hardly drop and I see 2 more fleets of 
the same HUGE size flying around their space just 2 turns later.

The Terrans and the Humans go to war. I send spys to keep them at war. They destroy each other all over
my area and their own. The humans manage to take out another AI and the Terrans take out 2 other AI races.
They stay at war but keep moving around these huge fleets of ships.

Please keep in mind I have more planets and more population then they do and they are still asking for
the warp tech to navigate unstable warp paths! I have my Production cranked now too.

( No idea how they are all over the universe, they must ignore the "unstable" part and move freely. )
Sure enough, I see them flying up and down the unstable paths unhindered!

I build my first Titan and I assign it to my main fleet. I save the game, at this point I am going to experiment.

The humans are ahead and the Terrans are close to me in every aspect other than population, planets and tech.
I am still ahead in tech. against them even though the AI seem to have more points. Makes no sense because when I
over to trade tech they have none I do not have and I have a ton that they don't have.

I attack the Terran Home Capital world and manage to take it out. I now own it. They take out 2 of my smaller planets
and I head for their 2 main fleets.

I take out their first main fleet, all the while my spies have been killing their leaders. We took out 6 leaders before I attacked the main fleet and won, total annihilation of that fleet they lost a lot!. I lost about 40% of my fleet.
I scrambled and pull all my ships from everywhere giving up all protection for my systems and make a new main fleet.
I attack and take out their 2nd fleet, which had also grown in size. I am down to about 25% of my fleet left but they have no ships anywhere. I have scout all over so I can see all their map area and more.

I go on a bombing run across their systems to keep them rebuilding and so they can not make a new fleet.

The human AI is still asking for the warp tech I mentioned above and they want an alliance. I say no, then turn around and 
sell them back 4 spies that I catapulted for some good cash and annual payments from them to me. They complain about it and I end negotiations. 

Maybe 50 turns have passed since I took out the 2nd fleet of the Terrans, many of their planets have been bombed by me
and I am still behind the humans in Victory points. No other races left in the game. I think this should be easy.
I hit the Orion Planet system kill the Guardian and take over, then about 20 turns later My capital is hit by a MASSIVE Terran
fleet and destroyed! Not taken over mind you, but not worth anything now.

I send my refreshed fleet to take on the Terrans new fleet and when I see the size of it I am like, " There is no way they could have built this!" 4 Titans, 7 Battleships and what looks like countless others ships.. All from where???

Now, I have to say I love a challenge. All my years of playing MOO when it came out, MOO2 ( Best game ever ! ) and yes, 
I even played Moo3. I never had the game cheat like it does in MOOcts!

I am left speechless at how bad the developers must be in programming and at tactics that they have to write the game 
so the AI cheats so much! I never even made it to where you go after the Antarans. 
Yes I could go back and play but what is the point.

The game uses cheating to compensate for bad programming and bad written AI.

I think I will stick with playing MOO2 when I feel the urge to play. I may come back just to try some crazy setting and see
where that takes the game. However for anyone wanting a great game, full of Sci-fi fun, tactics and a good challenge,
please, go play MOO2. It is a much better game, easier to find out what the different techs do and you feel far more 
in control of your ship design, weapon upgrades and the overall experience is far-far better!

"Master of Orion: Conquer the Stars" is the 4X game you've been longing for, surpassing the competition in almost every aspect.

This game not only satisfies that craving but also outshines its competition by a mile. What sets it apart is the perfect blend of turn-based gameplay with real-time space battles, creating a seamless and exhilarating experience.

I've been playing for a short while, and I'm impressed by the absence of any bugs or lack of polish, making for a smooth and immersive journey. The empire management system, particularly population management, is brilliantly simple yet effective, allowing you to focus on the aspects that truly matter.

For fans of the classic "Master of Orion 2," you'll be pleased to find a mostly faithful remake, with enhancements that I personally find superior, such as the inclusion of star-lanes from the third installment and the revamped RTS combat system.

I highly recommend this game, delivering everything you've been longing for in the genre.

I never played Master of Orion back in its heyday, but even I can tell that this was an embarrassment.

I played this lazy dumpster fire of a game when it first came out because I genuinely love the genre, but between this and Stellaris from about the same time they soured me on the whole genre with their disgusting fake challenge.

What is "fake challenge" you ask? Well, when you have the A.I. pulling suspiciously large military forces out of nowhere when they lose a couple of planets...it's kind of suspicious.

When you can pour everything into developing planets and technology and someone whose been in a two front war has more planets with bigger populations and more infrastructure than all but your homeworld...it's kind of suspicious.

When a spy causes your homeworld, i.e. the capitol of your civilization, to revolt against the civilization it itself controls...it's kind of suspicious.

BUT! When you have a coalition of species united in a glorious war only to, the very next turn after the last enemy world falls, immediately have one betray you because it's the "lowest" rated of your allies at a whopping 77 instead of the 85 of the other ally and immediately declare you to be interstellar Hitler...well that kind of clinches it, huh?

The developers spent so much time and money getting Sci-Fi actors to voice their characters that they forgot to actually make a game. Thanks, it's much more important to me to have Mark Hamill voice a frickin' bird man instead of actually have functioning game mechanics. Great choice, guys.

I don't care how long it's been since release. The makers straight up didn't care to actually make a game, which considering that's what I, and presumably you, came here for, is flat out insulting. The developer should've been sued.

This plays very much like MoO 2, which is completely fine. It is well polished and holds its own but doesn't really introduce anything new, which I think lets it down a little considering other strategic space and colony management games that are available and more fleshed-out (e.g. Stellaris).

But this game still offers enough variety and engagement to make it playable and enjoyable. I had hoped for more detail than MoO2 but the stability of the engine, original creativity, and the logic of challenge presented, makes it a solid game overall.

If you're a fan of classic 4X space strategy games, then Master of Orion is an absolute must. I mean, just saying the name brings back so many memories of the first game that it's hard not to get excited for the remake. Even if you've played it before, check it out again.

It's been a while since I've played the game, but stepping back into it was like stepping back into a familiar universe filled with intriguing races, intricate diplomacy, and epic battles. The game is a true homage to the original, with updated graphics and mechanics that make it feel like a modern game without losing its classic charm.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2963117206
One of the things I love about Master of Orion is the variety of races you can play as. Each has its own unique backstory, strengths, and weaknesses, making each playthrough feel fresh and exciting. Do you want to be the noble and honorable humans, the sinister and technologically advanced Sakkra, or the enigmatic and powerful Psilons? It's your decision.

The game also features deep diplomacy mechanics, allowing you to form alliances, negotiate trade deals, and wage war with other civilizations. There is always satisfaction in successfully negotiating a peace treaty or allying with a powerful empire to defeat a common enemy.

Of course, no 4X space game would be complete without epic space battles, and Master of Orion doesn't disappoint in that regard. Watching your fleets battle it out against huge battleships, frigates, and fighters is a thrill, especially when you emerge victorious.

But what sets Master of Orion apart from other space strategy games is its humor. The game doesn't take itself too seriously and is full of quirky and funny moments to keep you entertained throughout your gameplay. From the crazy racing designs to the silly dialogues, it's impossible not to smile while playing this game.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2963117119
In summary, Master of Orion is an excellent remake of a classic game that will delight fans of the original as well as new players. It's a perfect blend of modern mechanics and classic charm, with deep gameplay, epic space battles, and a healthy dose of humor. It's been a while since I've played the game, but I can confidently say that it's still one of the best 4X space strategy games out there.

[i][b]Master Of Orion[/b][/i] is a stress-free strategy game where you start off with a single planet and attempt to pull an entire galaxy into your grasp by fighting, spying, populating, constructing, and, of course, engineering.

The initial gameplay is moderately high and straightforward ‘find planet, colonise it, allocate resources to increase productivity and search for another planet’ scenario. To a small extent tiresome once you begin to understand it, but in time another race is encountered and once contact has been made you can communicate and attempt to make trade agreements or alliances, swap technology secrets or declare war. Becoming friendly with other races is beneficial for trade and is a good war avoidance tactic, but it also allows you to put in a particular position spies who will get involved in industrial espionage and sabotage.

There are many ways to achieve your objective, from exploiting the discovered planets and being pleasant to other races in the hope that they will cast their vote for you at the council meeting, to destroying any alien you come across and taking their planets. You can overwhelm the galaxy with members of your race on uninhabited planets and make the atmosphere suitable for breeding - no soft lights and [b][i]Barry White[/i][/b] records, but concentrating resources on keeping the atmosphere clean and free of industrial waste.

Advanced technology allows you to develop everything from killer ships to lethal weaponry to a improved pop-up toaster that doesn't burn the bread on one side while leaving the other cold.

Another feature is the inclusion of Leaders, talented freelancers that hire their services out to players. You can sign them up to lead your space-craft, head up battles, take care of planets, adding all sorts of variables into the strategic mix.

[i][b]Master Of Orion[/b][/i] has been reshaped and revitalised making it altogether more attractive. The graphics, animations and space combat has improved. In addition, the voice acting has prominent names.
Great 4x, wish we would continue the series, but this at least continues the MoO tradition without being repetitive.

Very good game, of course it could be improved but it's overall a fine in terms of UI, AI and Graphics.  It's quite simple compared to Endless Space 2, but for me a casual gamer that's a good thing. I feel like I am getting to know what I am doing much quicker than with ES2 (on which I have 250h+ but still exploring). Plenty of mods as well.

Master of Orion is a turn-based strategy game is set in a vast and detailed galaxy, where players take on the role of a space faring civilization seeking to conquer and dominate the universe. One of the game's greatest strengths is its depth and complexity. The game features a vast array of technologies, ship designs, and planetary improvements that allow players to customize their civilizations and tailor their strategies to their play style. The game also features a complex diplomacy system, allowing players to forge alliances and treaties with other civilizations, or engage in political intrigue and espionage. The game's graphics and sound design are also impressive, with detailed and colorful visuals that create a vivid and immersive galaxy. The game's music is also excellent, with a sweeping orchestral score that adds to the epic scope of the game. The game's single-player campaign is engaging and well-written, with a variety of missions that test the player's strategic abilities. The game also has a multiplayer mode, allowing players to compete against each other for galactic domination. One of the game's few downsides is its outdated user interface, which can be confusing and difficult to navigate for new players. The game's AI can also be inconsistent at times, with some civilizations proving to be too passive or too aggressive. Master of Orion is an excellent turn-based strategy game that offers a deep and immersive experience. Its complex game play systems, impressive graphics, and engaging single-player campaign make it a must-play for fans of the genre. However, the game's outdated user interface and inconsistent AI may make it less accessible to some players.

The game is very well done. The user interface is nice. The colony screen is good, but the list of buildings in a colony should be easier to see. The list of current production in all your colonies is a needed and missing feature. 
The available technologies are good. Also, the Alkari adviser is funny with his continuous screeches!!
Up to a mid-game, you have lot of fun. Then, if you go to conquer all the enemies then you are fine and go on. But if you prefer a different and pacific route, then at a certain point the game has nothing more to give you: no more exploration, no more challenges, perhaps just the Antarans.

Highly recommend if you like turn based.

Objectively the 2016 remake of Master of Orion is a solid 4x title. Don't get me wrong there are better space strategy simulator games out there, heck Stellaris came out the same year as this game and Sins of a Solar Empire is still a better game than this one and came out nearly a decade before it. That being said Master of Orion (the 2016 remake) is still way better than a ton of other space sims that I've seen. So why am I not recommending it despite believing it to be a pretty good game and having bought this in 2023 for 6 dollars? It's simple Master of Orion and Master of Orion 2 were the best space sims to come out in the 90s. 1996 was one of the best years for video games in history and some of the most important genre defining games came out that year Elder Scrolls 2 daggerfall, Duke Nukem 3d, Super Mario 64, Final Fantasy 7 came out in Japan in 96 but would come out in America in January of 97, Quake, Star Ocean, Diablo, and Master of Orion 2. Master of Orion 2 really stood out that year, the other genre defining games were rpgs and first person shooters but Masters of Orion 2 was THE space game. There are some truly die hard fans of this game because compared to the other games on this list Master of Orion 2 flew under the radar and the people who discovered MOO2 felt like they had found a piece of buried treasure. If you want to remake a game with as much depth and nuance as MOO then you can't just make a generic 4x space sim and throw a coat of paint on it and slap MOO as the title and expect fans to be happy. This game should have been extraordinary but instead it's just okay. If the title of this game was Random Indie Space Simulator 2016 then I would have recommended it but when you tell people that you are selling them a Rolls-Royce but actually sell them a Toyota Corolla then people are bound to be unhappy and feel cheated.

There is another thing that I would like to add. I went back and played MOO2 the other day and realized that the combat in this game isn't as good as a 4x space sim made in 1996. Every battle in MOO2 happened around a particular star system and fleets interacted with planets in the middle of space battle which meant you could ignore an enemy fleet entirely and carpet bomb a planet. This made space battles far more nuanced in MOO2 and there was far more tactics involved. Sometimes your fleet's objective was just to bomb an enemy planet and flee because your fleet didn't have any strong attack ships and had to rely on nimble stealth bombers to hurt an enemies production capabilities during war. Sure your enemy has a bigger stronger fleet with better technology but you have hundreds of suicidal bombers that are waging total war on every planet your enemy holds.
The system is pretty easy to learn and game play is decent. A good space game if you are looking for one.

This game is bad.
I played 1 game in MP with 1 friend and 4 AI.

When you initially start playing this game it seems like a pretty simple 4X with decent production values.
However the further you get in the clearer it becomes this is NOT a good 4X game, the game doesn't give you a lot of information you need to make informed decisions, like what components of a tech do, it also sometimes gives you false information.
There are basic design and interface issues everywhere, it seems like the designers looked at other 4X games and took a lot of inspiration from parts of their design without understanding *why* that design was made.

An example is the Antarans, they initially seem like they are a form of end game crisis, they appear randomly (or not so, they mostly harassed my friend) and will go to one of your planets, bomb it once doing minor damage, and then leave. Simply moving your fleet away makes them safe, because they don't follow them.
Another example is pirates, pirates become a non issue as soon as you have a few ships. their combat potential does not scale at all with your own making them a pushover even from the start of the game.

In MP you cannot fight tactical battles, only auto resolve. This is pretty boring and a lot of ship parts you unlock via tech seem to only do something in the tactical battles and be useless in MP. Designing ships is a pain in the ass with bad UI and an auto upgrade system that really seems to want to downgrade your ships most the time.

TLDR:
There were many other annoyances and issues I haven't mentioned, this game is not fit for MP play, and given that the AI seemed utterly brain dead and large parts of the game are just bad, probably isn't any fun in SP either. Avoid it.

Let me be blunt: This is just Master of Orion 2 with fancy modern graphics and top-notch voice acting. You could just play MoO 2 and have a great time without the shiny new clothes.

With that being said, this is a good remake of MoO 2. Yes, they didn't really improve the gameplay at all. And the graphics, while nice, are not especially remarkable for the most part. What really makes me prefer this over MoO 2 is the voice acting. I like having Civilization 5-style leader screens voiced by amazing actors like Mark Hamill. And I really like Micheal Dorn's narration. It all comes down to personal preference.

If you like space and strategy, you should get this, unless you prefer the original Master of Orion 2. I would generally recommend either over Stellaris; they are MUCH less expensive and also much less complicated.

In many regards, this looks, feels and plays exactly like the classic Masters of Orion 2 that we all loved back in the days.

There are some notable exceptions though.

You cannot go to the empire screen and simply drag and drop population from one maxed out colony to a new one.
Instead you have to build transport ships and move them where you need them, which increases micro a fair bit.

But my biggest complaint is the lack of repeating end game tech.
Once you reach the end of the tech tree, there is nothing else for your scientist to do.
But you can also not just put them into production because production slots are capped.
At that point half the population is essentially useless.

In MOO2 and virtually every decent 4X game you have repeating end game techs, that give you small incremental bonuses and keep increasing in price. 1% more credits, 1% more miniaturization, 1% more energy weapon damage ect...
How anyone could release a 4x game without that is beyond me, to be honest.

Sure you could, at that point just go for the sciency victory and win the game.
But I like to turn off all victory conditions other than domination, so i can really take my time and shape the galaxy to my hearts content. 

Would recommend for enthusiast.
But definitely not a must have game.

Master of Orion is one of those classics that are fun to have played at least once. Sure, there are newer and arguably better variations on the theme, but MoO is fun, sometimes quirky, just complex enough, and very much replayable.
IF you liked the older versions then this will be mostly the same with better graphics and UI . Having some fun here so enjoy !

Some of the graphics are nice, but overall MOO1 and MOO2 are better games. Among other things I prefer the more tactical round-based combat over pseudo-realtime.
Despite all the effort for graphics and voice acting this MOO version seems unfinished and done without enough love for the game.
Menu animations, cut scenes and texts waste too much time.
I also had a lot of problems with bugs like UI freezes.
I especially don't like that they changed some abilities of the well-known alien races and left out some abilities (also for custom) and that 3 of the MOO2 races were locked behind a DLC.
Something about the ship design editor doesn't seem right. The available space is quite a bit to tight and some devices take up too much space. It feels not balanced correctly.

I really like the visuals, but this is very subjective.
The game is simple, compared to Stellaris, but that simplicity sometimes really does it for me.
Game is comparable to Galactic civilization, which I also find enjoyable.
There is nothing epic about this game, but you will get your moneys worth of fun, that's for sure.

They should have just called this Master of Orion 4. It clearly borrows from both MOO2 and MOO3, as well as other games like Galactic Civilizations and Endless Space. I got this for about six bucks on sale with all of the DLC and MOO, MOO2, and MOO3. 

Spoiler: It's not a terrible game, but Master of Orion 2 is still the best in the series. You can make it playable by changing the Growth speed setting when creating a new game. If you don't, it's too slow and boring like Gal Civ.

TLDR This is streamlined Endless Space.

What's good?

- Graphics. Everything got an overhaul including the main screen, the close ups of aliens, GNN, and battles. 

- The aliens have a lot more personality now via diplomacy.  The Gnolams are the most lifelike. Bird people are next, and I'm pretty sure Mark Hamill voices the Avian people.

- You can now specify the number of duplicate items to build.

- Unlike Endless Space, it's not endlessly buggy. That is a big achievement.

- Unlike Endless Space, it's not a resource hog.

- Unlike Endless Space, it doesn't need an internet connection for single player.

- There are now more ways to win: Science and Economics


What's ok?

- The voice acting is ok. More on this later.

- They now have focused AI management e.g. Food, Production, etc... and it's still broken, but nearly every 4X AI management is broken except for one game and that game is really boring. There is still a lot of micromanagement. 

- Music is solid given the genre.

- The new Gal Civ space constructor mechanic isn't bad, but it takes out two major game mechanics.

- Spaces lanes are definitely borrowed from Endless Space. Not bad, but it kills two major Master of Orion mechanics.

- Tech tree is ok. Most of the time it doesn't piss me off. It is familiar.

- They added space pirates and minor factions. It's ok.

- They have a tutorial system.

- They improved the Espionage mechanic a bit.


What sucks?

- The way the game treats population growth is just too slow. It doesn't even matter if you have a small planet. Even with cloning labs, you're not going to fill up all the space at turn 200. What makes this issue even worse is that the colony ships remove population as they're built. The end result is that pacing is mind numbingly slow. 

EDIT: You can fix this with settings. Just change Growth to "Very Fast", and the game becomes playable. This should be the default setting. I'm now changing this game to Recommend since I didn't need a mod to fix it.

- There is also no longer a "Housing" mechanic where you use production to grow the population which makes the above problem even worse.

- They have real time battles with limited control, which is what everyone hated from Master of Orion 3. Maybe instead of dropping so much money on really expensive voice actors from Star Trek and Star Wars, maybe they should have spent it on tactical battles instead? Again, this is what makes MOO unique. They need to bring this back. At least it looks pretty now.

- They removed colony bases. Why? It made no sense. None. It also drastically slows the game down just like with the insanely slow population growth. Colony ships seem to be almost just as expensive as MOO2.

- They took out the limited travelling distance mechanic. This is a key mechanic that is unique to MOO. 

- They messed up the colony list management screen. You can no longer see researcher, farmer, and worker allocation per colony. This is even worse since the AI does bad allocations automatically. 

- You can no longer select multiple workers like in MOO2. Why?!

- The Anteran mechanic is now just really stupid. No matter what you have, they will always have better tech. It scales, which again is stupid.

- The Galactic Counsel where you vote for Supreme Leader isn't guaranteed to happen. All races have to meet each other. There is no guarantee of it ever happening. I've beaten a game where this didn't happen. While I hated it in MOO2, in this new game it's essential to keep it from dragging on.

- The Creative trait is a lot less useful. Your choices on which optional tech to take is much less gut wrenching. This game prioritizes growth over everything else.

- You can't do counter proposals when the AI offers you something diplomatically.

Minor complaints 

- Not all of the speed settings are saved from new game to new game.

- There is too much voice acting. I don't need everything narrated. I can read.

- There's too little variety in events. GNN could have been much better.

- The AI management is really broken for Silicoids, but no one plays them anyways.

- Whoever thought an overly happy old lady voice was a good idea to give to the Silicoids is an idiot. Most of the tech research voices are terrible. It's so bad that they have an option to turn it off.

- The cinematic fights have a frequently recurring jitter at certain angles. Definitely does not look as good as Endless Space.

Conclusion

It's not a terrible game. It's just Endless Space Lite. The main problem is that there are many other games in this genre that are better including Endless Space. If only they just released an HD version of MOO2. If only. Development would have been way cheaper AND more there would have been more sales. 

This would have been an amazing game if they didn't waste so much money and time into voice acting. I have a feeling that management just wanted an excuse to meet with the Star Trek and Star Wars actors.

TL:DR - This is an update of Master of Orion 2, but with some wonderfully hammy celebrity voice actors and almost prettier graphics. And Nothing else.

Just to be Clear - The negative review is just crushing disappointment.
But yet I can't help but be impressed with how cynically the publishers tapped into the nostalgic impulses in my brain.

Yes it is MOO2, but they managed to take out all of the interesting parts or tactical and strategic nuance.
It is a copy of the original 4X game, and then promptly doesn't do anything new or interesting, from an update of an over 20 year old game.

If you want a prettier Masters of Orion 2 clone - Stars in Shadow is a pretty fair copy and while not as pretty as this outing, it does tap into what made the 20 year old game great.

If you want a game where challenges and play styles are asymetrical between factions  - the Endless games are very good with interesting story telling.

If you want THIS exact game but done better, ZeroSums - Stardrive 2 is worth a look, just use the mods and be prepared that he will probably never get round to actually finishing the game.

In short, on my one Vanilla play through, I was hoping for something interesting to happen, but it never did.

Also didn't help was that I won through the intergalactic version of "The Big Short"

Just get any of those other games, or the myriad of clones, those are better.

This game is a downgrade from Master of Orion 3. Loss of functionality in many game interfaces. You cannot dispatch an available colony ship from the planets menu. But the worst failing is that the zoom in/out is permanently bound to the mouse scroll wheel.
Lots of fun for the family if you like turn based space battle sims with lots of races to try. Fun to comeback and play when bored with current games.

Fun game, except that it's 100% broken and totally unplayable.  I'll explain:  I like to use the 'Creative' racial trait.  It takes all ten of your starting race points...

And doesn't work at all, not at all.  I started THREE games trying to fix this, and I'm not the only person with this issue.  Every game I play in MOO2, I play custom races, with Creative...

In this game, it fails to work 100% of the time.  I would rate this game a negative score if I could, as it is, 0/10, does not allow the ONE feature I always use.

Ironically, Creative worked for the FIRST game I played, so I went over the two hour limit to get a refund from Steam.

This game is over seven years old, to have such a consistent issue that has persisted all this time reveals the company that shat this out clearly doens't care about quality control.

All of that being said, the graphics are nice, gameplay is smooth, too bad this game doesn't allow the ONE option I ALWAYS pick when I play.  I'll be going back to MOO2, and never playing this again.  Money wasted.

So this game is inconsistent at every level. The graphics are very good AND very bland. The game play is compelling AND boring. The voice acting is very good and very annoying. That last word is the ultimate reason for my thumbs down. This game in the end is dominated by its annoying aspects and where it isn't annoying t's mind boggling inconsistent.

I have searched for so long for a good space empire game...and this ain't it.

This is a boring game - it is that simple.

In fact, it is so boring that I struggle to find subjects and themes to write about in this review, but it is reviving through my mind like sludge, so, here goes...

I do not like there is not a campaign.
Maybe I am too old and traditional, but I like the campaign, the expertly crafted levels, and the story to take me through and CARE about the game.
However, this game only offers randomly generated maps with randomly generated enemies - SNORE!

Then, it does the Civ games nonsense where a nearby enemy is OP very early in the game.
For example, I chose the first style of map and number of opponents by clicking through, which brought me to a "small" map with 5 opponents.
I bumped into an opponent 5 FUC KING turns in, and they already had 3 war spaceships, whereas I started with a colony ship, two scout ships, and one war spaceship.
It is impossible to create that many war spaceships in that amount of time - even if a player had the resources!

No.

Also, the game does the chickensh it Civ thing of introducing random space pirates in a long cleared away area from nowhere.

The game inevitably begins in a hospitable solar system, which I can quickly colonize - cool.
Then, often, the nearest system which the game indicates had a "Terran" or hospitable planets, which I would carefully direct and, balance and husband my resources to create a colony ship (which takes many fuc king turns to create from the ONE colonized planet), would have a planet which was marginally suitable and took like 60 turns to be anything worth anything.

60 turns!

Yes, it is neat to explore in a huge map all the different planets, but soon it gets boring and repetitive, because there are really only so many types of planets.

Combat and strategy is over-simplistic, and I can simply create fortresses at strategic choke-points.

I found myself asking - WHY?

Why in the absence of a campaign with a clear goal would I want to trudge through turns, and turns, and turns of tedium to advance ever so slightly, I guess?

I gave up when I found a "Gaia" planet in the bottom corner on my side and while I was sending a colony ship, a transport ship and a space factory with it at different intervals, a flyspeck space pirate appeared from NOWHERE in a space I had already thoroughly cleared and threatened this endeavor which took HOURS to create and more HOURS to rectify.

I am considering uninstalling it, but may retry after awhile, although my first impressions are seldom incorrect...

Spent way to much time playing MOO1 and MOO2 back in the 90's and only just saw and got this --- it's a real labour of love, can see that the developers liked the original two games a lot. It's a great blend of both with elements of its own. At first I wasn't sure about the real time combat but it's been implemented really well and makes trying different weapon styles more enjoyable. Seeing those Gauss cannon rip up the other guy's battlestation and capital ships is great. The additions of nebulae and asteroids add a bit of variety. The advisers are a nice touch and are fun - I can see the designers spent a lot of time getting them right and didn't need to. Voice acting is superb. Calling up the other ambassadors is made quite a lot of fun because of those and the animations.

When you've finally assembled your fleet and think you are ready to take on the winning race who's way ahead of you - suddenly declaring war on them after amassing a huge fleet on their doorstep is exciting but feels a little disturbing.

All in all - if you liked MOO1 and 2 you'll enjoy this. Really well done! Worth full price.

Are there any cons? With a big galaxy the other player's turns can take a little long especially if you're waiting for ship builds. Also - just like the first 2 it takes up too much time.

I'm kind of hot and cold with this game. With the Name Master of Orion, it's hard not to compare it to the legendary MoO and MoO2. Having said that, there are some decent improvements and a few omissions that should have been added.

Obviously, the graphics are superior. The monster animations are nice, and races are portrayed well. With the base game, there are a similar number of races (and most are familiar if you've played the old games) and more that you can purchase. The AI isn't as bloodthirsty as its predecessors, but that may be good or bad for you. I kind of miss the urgency MoO2 had to the beginning of the game. 

A few things that are glaringly absent: combat isn't turn based. While the RTS style they use is okay, I miss the turn based system from before. Also, your ships don't level anymore. No more fleets of green, regular, and elite ship crews. They're all just NPCs now. Diplomacy would have been a good thing to fix. Like in the older games, AI races will declare war on you for seemingly no reason whatsoever. Admittedly, it doesn't seem to be as bad as the previous games, but it's still not very realistic. GNN is just... well, it's a hard nope for me. It's trying way too hard to be funny, and it comes off worse than Dad jokes. I just turned that shit off.

I like the addition of anomalies and pirate attacks. It takes a bit of the boredom out of the beginning since the AI doesn't usually try to hit you very early.

I think it could do with a little more balancing though. There's really no need for larger ships when you can kill about anything in the game by Zerging it with a horde of frigates and destroyers.

All in all, if you liked the older games, this one is pretty good and familiar enough to strike a chord or two within you.

Reminds me of Civilization IV in a way. It's kinda like Civilization IV in space. Which is awesome.

Anyway, thumbs up from me!

Whether you are allowed to retreat is apparently random, and the battles which were rated as a sure thing are actually unwinnable.

Meanwhile, the fun things in MOO II are missing, like boarding ships and capturing them, teleportation, the various details of tactical combat like which shields are up, the genetic modification technology, the balance between small, fast ships vs. big powerful ones, etc.

Overall, it feels like they improved the cosmetics and crippled the things that are fun. Almost as if a team worked on it who had no idea what was fun about it before and had no interest in the game. They must think people who loved that old game are a bunch of losers.
