The Master of Orion remake is an easy access into the world of 4X and also worth playing for everyone who wants to take a step back and just have a casually good time.

[b]The main difference between Master of Orion (MoO) and other 4x space games on Steam is its focus.[/b] 
While all other titles strive to deliver in dept game systems and have a steep learning curve, MoO went back to the basics and focuses on a clean game interface with a simple approach to pretty much everything. 

It also puts a large emphasis on presentation as all races have their own ships, population icons, voiced advisors, leader and spy pictures and so on. In fact, the entire game is voiced from race selection, over advisors, to GNN the funny news channel informing you about important events throughout the universe. In terms of accessibility there are no sub menus to get lost in, managing population or ships in a fleet is as simple as to drag them around, the most complex thing is weaponry and its fire directions.


[b]Now to the cost of keeping it simple[/b]: 
The game has some major cons, that have been ironed out by other titles and their advanced systems in systems, very typical for older games where game creators had not put as much thought into things:

Since there is nothing limiting your expansion, the only viable way of playing is to forward settle as many good planets as possible, build many buildings on them to out-tech and out economy your AI adversaries - a pure numbers game. This also means you are at the total mercy of the random galaxy creation when you start a new game. [i]There is an option for balanced starts... but it doesn't work[/i]. It is possible to not get a single immediately life supporting planet anywhere near your home world, while someone else gets a system with three large earth like planets right next to their home star. Last game I had to restart FIVE times until I had something I deemed acceptable, far from perfect but playable - it's a major annoyance.

The second negative aspect of this is how incredibly stupid the AI acts. They too are just a numbers game in the form of a disposition bar that swings more left to hated or right to loved. Pacifying an AI is relatively easy if you gift them on a regular basis and make trade treaties. On the other hand AI does not take no for an answer and acts like a diplomatic elephant in a porcellain store. 

[i]Example a[/i]:
If you support a much weaker race with money and tech while they are at war with someone else, they will love you for it and their opponent dislike you - so far, so logical. But then it is inevitable that the weaksauce will ask you to go to war with them - which is a big deal, but declining will instantly drop your relations enormously. Yet, even if you said no and took the relationship penalty, then rebuild your good terms with them, they will ask again. They have zero regards for your stance of saying no as well as your continued support, even if they depend on you for economic survival. 

[i]Example b[/i]:
If the AI decides they want to trade something with you, they also get mad for declining. Normally a trade should be something that is either accepted or not no harm no foul. But in MoO aliens see it differently. They might offer you a tech you don't need at all and demand something you're not willing to give up in return. Or want star charts you do not want to share... not only will they like you a little less for declining, they will keep asking again and again and again, until you are basically at the brink of war.

Now, the AI is no push over even on normal. They will build strong fleets and take your worlds. But it mostly stems from settling really everything, even barren worlds, very early on and always instantly knowing when an obstacle (monster) is being removed by the player so they'll send colony ships from everywhere right away and you have to have your own ship ready. 
As well as spamming small ship fleets. In other games small ship spam has been eliminated through more complicated battle systems - in MoO it still beats technologically superior large ships when you have more small guns pointing at them. It should be noted that a major fleet loss will pretty much lead to the AI taking most of your worlds if their own fleet did not get crippled as well. They act very goal oriented here.

This game did also not receive a lot of post launch attention and bugs never got fixed. It's nothing too bad though, the one things that bugs me is how assigning roles to your ships in their building screen uses the wrong role if you changed another ships before it, so you have to slide it back to what you actually wanted.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
If you can look past these obvious flaws, you get an otherwise really nice simple strategy game. Wether you are new to the genre, or don't want to think things through too hard after a long day at work, or are a dad looking to get your children into 4X - Master of Orion would be the perfect choice. The only limitation for small children I would make is to deactivate the Alteran encounters as their herald looks pretty scary.
I love it it is the best Master of Orion since MOO2 BUT when you get in the late game even on a high end machine one turn takes about 1-2 minutes, that is just unacceptable.

TLDR: This is a nostalgic modern rendition of the early 90s classic DOS based game; it faithfully sticks to the formula of the original Master or Orion and for the most part is the exact same game, but there are a few QoL improvements in gameplay that I enjoy.

Longer: I've played Master of Orion since it came out 30 years ago and was super impressed with how much this mimics the gameplay of the original and hit my nostalgia bone in the exact right place.

I generally stick to Civilization on turn-based 4X games and don't have much experience playing any kind of space based 4X game other than Master of Orion, but I played Stellaris for the first time a few weeks ago and saw some obvious comparisons between the two and will help explain what I see as the main differences.

Both Stellaris and Master of Orion are pretty similar in colonizing planets/star systems, gathering resources and research while managing very complicated and in-depth diplomacy (or at least way more in depth than anything Civilization offers). 

While Stellaris is kind of a hybrid RTS and Turn-based game, Master of Orion sticks to turn-based only formula which I prefer. Stellaris has a lot of little pop-ups and side quests that come up while exploring, and to me it was difficult to manage everything in real time such as reading side quests and managing tech/build orders while the game is running. Yes, you can pause time to do all these things, but it gets exhausting to me and Stellaris is just too busy and has a much higher learning curve to understand all the nuances. 

Master of Orion is less busy, more streamlined, and arguably more dated overall gameplay experience than Stellaris, but I 100% prefer this version of Master of Orion to the 90s version of Master of Orion and Stellaris.

I do want to mention that combat in Master of Orion is either real time where you control ship and can maneuver around and maximize efficiency of battles, or let the game decide for you quickly; previous version combat was turn based and had a much more archaic and less fun combat system.

At the end of the day, this game may not be for everyone, and the vibe I get from reading reviews is having memories of the original Master of Orion is what tends to win people over with this game; so if you're looking for a faithful recreation of Master of Orion with great new gameplay updates or a less busy and complicated version of Stellaris that is purely turn based, this might be the game for you.

This is my third attempt at finding an accessible 4X game and, have to say, it's taking off. I first tried Stellaris (too complicated) then Endless Space (good but a little clunky) and am finding the look, feel and polish of MOO to be what I needed. It just looks and plays great and I'm really enjoying building my own home among the stars. Sure, it's probably a pedestrian ride for the more seasoned 4X player but as an aesthetically pleasing jumping on point I really can't complain.

I had Master of Orion 1 installed on my first computer. It was a i486 with 2MB RAM. Even though it looked impossible to learn, I had a lot of time and energy in my hands to understand how stuff goes. Through 20 years, I have followed second one with same enthusiasm, however third one was unbearable.

After all these years, I was delighted to it remastered. I thought nobody else played it, and it felt like cosmos is doing me personal favor. After 6 years and 400 hours, my prejudice has not changed a bit. This game is as awesome as the first and second one. I am still enjoying it every time I do another run.

However unlikely, I hope others will see it through my eyes someday and we can have a fan-base big enough to demand another entry.

I've played MOO since the first one.  Unlike MOO2, you can't create an uber race. Government types no longer exist. 

The tactical combats are also more interesting. When designing a ship you can give it one of three roles in tactical combat (blitzer, brawler, or sniper).  You can set the maximum distance a ship will engage at and a distance that your ships will try to keep between them and enemy ships.  

The usable "cells" for each planet size and planet type (volcanic, barren, etc.) is a nice touch.   Pollution is also more realistic, because it only affects food production and takes time for the pollution to build up and time to reduce.

The elimination of fuel cells and the introduction of warp points in systems gives the game a more strategic feel, because you can decide which systems to colonize and which warp points to place a military outpost in order to create choke points and create areas of the galaxy to back-fill at your leisure.  

All in all, MOO CtS is a solid successor to MOO2.  It is not as a wide open free for all that MOO2 is.

Decent enough space 4X Game, but not nearly as fun as the original games that inspired it.  It's like an odd cross between Endless Space and Master of Orion 2 with some tweaked bits.  Planetary management is similar to Master of Orion 2, but navigating between systems is more like Endless Space.  The revamped Espionage system is mor ehands-on and offers a much more nuanced control over how your agents carry out their missions.  

Pros:
- Graphics are pretty nice
- Ship auto-design is decent enough, upgrading fleets is fairly simple.
- Ability to automate battle either by a single click on in cinematic mode (a la Endless Space.)
- GNN is as hilarious as ever.

Cons:
- Seemingly arbitrary limits on how your citizens are assigned jobs
- Space navigation is no longer the sandbox , go-anywhere style.
- Lack of planetary terraforming options.  They're now "Uber" planet picks you have to choose using racial points.
- Menus seem to be a bit laggy.
- Tech Tree seem to be a bit short.  ship designs stop improving, and there's no automatic miniaturization as your overall tech improves.

Others:
- No government types, some of the traits/bonuses associated with Orion 2's government type are now tied to racial traits.  This can make a lot of races kind of flat.
- While there are more nuanced traits to pick from for custom races, there just aren't enough points to go around and make something really unique.

Conclusion: competent 4x game on its own right, but still doesn't have the same "fun factor" as the original games.

The game has a great awesome potential but in the present state I can *not* recommend this game.

There are heavy issues (quasi non-existing multiplayer, bad game design aspects which lead that you have to colonize a lot of small planets rather than a few large planets and therefore you lose yourself in mid and end game in too much colonies with too much details instead of having only a few strong planets and clear overview and your head free to think about strategy and decisions instead of doing tons of micromanagmentg - examples for that: growth penalty on large and huge planet and pollution penalty on large and huge planets with big population and strong industry - many small planets with in summary same strong industry suffer not the same pollution penalty, then bugs bugs bugs, a ton of heavy balance issues resp. AI stupidity - even on the hardest difficulty you beat the AI at first attempt, and the developers from NGD studos have abandoned the game, not a word from them and from Wargaming (who has the intellectual property of MoO)  since two months.

One of the big things is the TOTAL FAILURE OF SPACE COMBAT: The AI is not shooting back if you keep your distance: 

With a weak ship you can destroy much bigger KI fleets: You use missiles and the AI only uses beam weapons (which have a shorter range).  If you keep your distance you can fire missile after missile after missile while the KI fleet does not fire a single shot back - simply because ther weapons are out of range and they dont build fast ships to quickly bridge the distance.

You dont have to research and build good ships and weapons and shields, armor etc. and build huge armies, if a single weak ship with some lousy missiles is enough to win vs KI even on the hardest difficulty.


[b]THIS IS A TOTAL DEAL BREAKER![/b]


Furthermore there is no up-to-date manual and apart from the new stuff in the outdated manual even many of the older things are not explained e.g. that population on small planets growth faster (that is a pretty important thing which you might easily miss to discover if you don't know it), how armor penetration and armor resilience is working (these two terms are in the short tutorial - but missing in the manual), how ground combat is working, etc.


[B]THE GAME HAS A GREAT POTENTIAL  - IF ONLY IT WOULD BE USED BY SOME CARING DEVELOPERS.[/B]

A revived modern classic 4x game.  It's mostly by the numbers and sticks close to the formula.  It's hard to fault that.  I like the formula.  But this game doesn't really innovate either.  The game is pretty good, but it never really achieves greatness.  It has a great foundation that deserves multiple expansions to really grow into the stellar 4x game it deserves to be.  Unfortunately, it never got those expansions.  I recommend it to fans of the original, and those that like the classic 4x experience, particularly if you have some nostalgia for MoO and MoO2.  I wish this game had half a dozen expansions to really flesh it out, but as is, it's pretty good, just not as good as it could or should be.

A fair refresh of the series. Its pace was perfect. Win conditions were unique and interesting – though I wish final victory were more cinematic. The graphics are great, the many creative ship designs were cool. The space combat was satisfying thought its cinematic camera was a bit bland. Bombardments and ground invasions were dull. I wish they’d allowed customization of scouts, colony ships, and transports and more than 6 ship types at one time. All the races were expectedly unique, perfectly realized, and fun to play as. Its biggest sin was simply not including a rally point feature. Admittedly I’m new to spacefaring 4x but this seemed like a worthy one.

The only negitive things I can say about this game is it is slow paced in the begining. So is CIV3-6 and Endless Space. But, the space battles... They are pretty to watch, but the only thing you do is put the fleet together. Useing the above mentioned games, in CIV you can put ranged units behind melee. In this game it doesn't matter that I have seen. You have ships with only missles and a few with only lasers, they all bumb-rush the oponent and open fire, en-masse. In Endless Space the battle plays out as well, but before the battle you can choose a stratagy, which was reserched . AND when you have point defence ships they fire away until all incoming missles, fighters & bombers are destroyed. In this game they only defend the ship they are on. AND Missle ships tend to stayat Max distance or try to keep the point defence ships between them and the enemy. And the only ships Bumb-Rushing the enemy have short ranged wepons with a shorter cooldown time.
 But having this said it stands on its own and is a game I enjoy playing. I think most people who like CIV style games will like this. It was worth the money I spent like 13 bucks for the game and 3 dlc races.

The graphics are nice. Wonder if they will ever pick up / expand on this series more, they should.

I tried. I really tried. I love MOO 2, was thoroughly disappointed by 3, and I had high hopes that the promise to return to the earlier version might be fulfilled. DISAPPOINTMENT!

First and foremost, if you are playing a large galaxy with lots of aliens (as I like), the size of your saved games will soon exhaust your google drive.  The game provides a feature which allows you to return to a prior turn without actually saving the game at that turn. This leads the size of saved games (even if it's just the one you're playing) to grow in a VERY non-linear way. I have to ask why? I can save my own games, and I don't really feel the need to preserve the game state at the start of every, single turn.

This version continues the limited travel between star systems which was created for v3. Okay, I'm not happy about the restriction, but I can live with that change.

I played 3 games, with the first two aborted early (see below). Even when I solved some issues in that 3rd (and final ever) game, my summary judgment is that if you like to watch paint dry, you will absolutely love this game.  EVERYTHING takes LONGER than it should, even the visual movement of your fleets - turn, creep across their route, turn again - it looks nice the first time, but by the hundredth time you've seen it, you'll get my point.

Then there's the fact that next turn sometimes doesn't mean next turn in population growth. If you're timing your growth to fill a colony type vessel, the settler (a farmer) is removed first; so, your food falls short pushing pop growth back a turn. (Why not take a worker who finished production for that turn?) Of course, you can go back to the last turn and put in an extra farmer (unless all your "slots" are filled - the number of farmers and workers is limited well below max pop, unlike MOO 2).

And all food must be produced on the planet (or, later game, in the system) where it's used. (Really? You can move people and armies, but not food?) So, "barren" worlds allow some farming?? It just seems to defy logic.

I also have to ask why left over production (especially after a buy out) is NOT reflected in the first turn buy out price of the next item. It does show up later, but that's some major BS.

Then there's all those bar graphs. Pretty, but some actual numbers would be a good deal more useful, especially when you're doing late stage (big numbers) research.  It's a real pain to find yourself a fingernail's depth short. Either you basically waste an entire turn of research (no carry over here), or go back to find a few more points, which it would have been nice to know was all I needed before I went through that long, draw out inter-turn.

Oh, did I mention how LOOOOOOONG everything takes. Late stage "load game" is a 10 minute operation. "Next turn" takes almost as long.

Also, the game likes to be boss. It will move your focus as it sees fit, override your zoom setting, and (another waste of time) zoom out and back in when you "Move Next Fleet." UGH! Just go there; if I need context, I'll zoom out. Or, better yet, just leave my zoom setting alone entirely.

Now, as to the first 2 games, I was jammed with 2 of 7 races into 1/4 of the galaxy. Unstable warp points, only passable with mid-level [turn 150?] tech, blocked access to everything else. GRRR! Turns out that is an UNDOCUMENTED feature of selecting your galaxy shape ("correctly" chosen in 3rd game obviated the restriction). I only discovered this "effect" when reading another player's comments.

Finally, those first two games were whacked by disaster after (random event) disaster.  In my first (very easy?????) game a turn 50 settlement was attacked by the Antarans on turn 83 and then a turn 105 settlement attacked on turn 127. In MOO2 Antarans never attacked before turn 130, and MOO2 progressed much faster (I made MOO2 turn 130 equivalent around turn 250 here).  In another game, a turn 50 disaster basically destroyed my first colony, and that session.

I can take a hint. It's being-hit-on-the-head lessons in here, and I don't like it. Bye.

Master of Orion: Conquer the Stars is a faithful successor to the MoO series, reviving 90% of the fun of the first 2 games in the series while incorporating advances from subsequent modern 4x games. As someone who purchased and played the original two games last century, I was pleased with this version, and happy to revisit the old aliens from 3 decades ago. I recommend this game for players who would be turned off by the dated graphics and interfaces of the originals. It is a highly accessible place to start in 4x gaming.

The biggest improvement over the old titles I found was that the aliens are better balanced - not perfectly, but better. There are far fewer dud games, though the same few aliens still usually rise to the top.

The disappointment was in the missing 10% of fun they took away from the previous games (1 and 2. 3 must not be spoken of).

- The scaling behavior of the Antarans encourages strategic weakness, which is boring.
- System roundabout traffic slows everything down, which is boring.
- Only 1 doom star? Oh ... God ... no! I want my end game doom star swarms back! Boring.

I wanted to give it a thumbs up, but it's not what it should be. They graphics and voice acting is beautiful but the game play is hollow. The depth and polish is missing. At some point the producers decided that's enough now and it seems they stopped working on it. Even when the game ends - you'll get just a pop-up with you are victorious (not even a pretty - victory related one) and that's it. A few month more development and it would have been great but now it isn't.
Continually Freezes Processing Turn not worth the time to download let along pay for.

Maybe the best 4x game I've ever played. 
All paths to victory are valid. 
AI does actually do reasonable diplomacy.
Pace is epic even on lightning speed. 
Really just a lot of fun.
Old but perfect 4x
Still a great game after so many years

Marginal, Pointless, but maybe worth under $5

4/10

This could as easily be a "No" recommendation. Like so many, I want to like this game. I still remember the amazing experience of Moo 1, and have continued to play Moo 2 for over 20 years. Given the failure of Moo 3, I really looked forward to this version (Moo 4!) And,..

Hollywood keeps trying to remake classic films, and usually they are disappointing failures (think remakes of Valley Girl, Pelham 1, 2, 3, Godzilla, King Kong, and so forth.) Moo 4 is in this vein. It's a terribly disappointing and flawed game, but not the worst time waster if you buy it on sale for under $5. (I see it settling at $1.79 like many much older games in a few years.) You can have fun playing the game, and it is an improvement over the utterly failed Moo 3. But after you play for a while you realize how seriously flawed and pointless this edition is. 

The game began ambitiously enough. The intro graphics are good, if brief. The voice-acting was first-rate, including greats like Mark Hamill, John DeLancie, Dwight Schultz, Robert Englund, and Michael Dorn. The galaxy map and world graphics are an improvement, but maybe not as much as expected after almost 30 years of Moo. The rival leaders are well animated and drawn, and then voiced by a good cast of real actors. And, unlike Moo 3, all your favorites are here, including the Elerians, Bulrathi, and a new Terran race. And GNN is back too, if somewhat annoying. All of the familiar 4X elements are present, from starlanes to tactical battles. And ship design is as good as ever (the real core of Moo.) So, what could be wrong? 

It almost looks like the developers gave up or ran out of time/money when they shipped this, and over 6 years later have no intention of completing or repairing this effort (there are Mods, and they even built modding into the Steam version, basically leaving it to the fans to fix.) The absolute WORST aspect of Moo 4 is there is no Hall of Fame! That's right. In every 4X game you play for two goals: to beat others in multi-player, or to best your own score and build the biggest, best empire you possibly can. After a while you realize that your instinct to colonize every world, max out the populations, conquer every enemy, etc., is just pointless. When you meet one of no less than SIX victory conditions (you can disable these), you win. No victory screen, no HoF entry, no nothing. It's a real let-down after playing an lengthy and intensive game. In lieu of "winning," you get Steam achievements. So, you can try to win a diplomatic victory as the Silicoids, or a military one as the Psilons, if you want to earn all the badges, 

Also, the expected graphic upgrades are uneven. Leaders, the galaxy, and planets look nice. But colony development is very blah, with ugly square 'buildings' plopped on the surface. Inferior to Moo 2. Ship designs are limited, and each class is portrayed identically on the map anyway. Ground combat is essentially Moo 1, lacking even the limited combat graphics of 2 & 3. Space battles are another thing. You can resolve these automatically, which is recommended, especially for large battles, or in 3D. 3D looks cool, but is hard to control and runs choppy, even on a 8 gb GPU. (You can allow the AI to run the battle and just watch the pretty, if slow, screens.) This was another exciting idea of the designers that appears to have fallen short. 

The victory conditions are too many and, as with other 4X reboots like Civ4, can be annoying when you "win" by surprise. You can (and should) disable many of these at the start screen if you want a longer game. In addition to the usual win by conquest, election, or defeating Antares, you can conquer the galactic stock market, achieve a scientific  victory, or just get the high score by the end of a timed period (which can be disabled.) But even here the game is annoying. The Galactic Council cannot meet until ALL races have met each other. This is hard to actually make happen, especially when smaller empires stay cramped in corners of the galaxy. I have played several games and yet to have a meeting. (Mods have apparently fixed this.) And attacking Antares requires acquiring 4 ruins asteroids and exploiting them, which usually necessitates invading your neighbors. 

And there is the infamous "slow-down" effect as you get into later turns. 

The Antarans are also a problem. They appear to be attracted to attack whatever system has the largest fleet, even early in the game (like one frigate.) Apparently the goal is to add balance, but it is really annoying. Even worse, it can be spoofed. Instead of fighting the Antarans, lead them to a shielded planet, leave before they arrive, and let them drop a few bombs on the shield (ineffective) and they go home. The Antaran fleets only get stronger if you defeat them, so why bother? 

There are some new features that are improvements. You can convert asteroids and gas giants into planets even in systems without colony planets. You can build military outposts (forts) at jump points, as well as listening posts, labs. gas mines, etc. You can choose different galaxy types which actually lead to different movement rules and numbers of empires. Some races even have their own alternate "Gaia" worlds, suitable to their physiology. And, while somewhat dull, custom race building is a lot more balanced. No more omniscient, telepathic, creative feudalisms. (Unfortunately, there are no government types any more.) Also, you can now build advanced colony ships that add Automatic Factories, a basic lab, and hydroponic farm to a new colony, a nice time saver. Maybe the best improvement is a much expanded and improved espionage system.

But a lot is also missing, You can only build one Death (Doom) Star per empire. Why? No governments types, all are just you. Also, there is no in-game documentation of techs, weapons, etc. You need to refer to the online manual. or download it. And tech descriptions are often sketchy. So, should I develop Fusion Beams? I have no idea what they do until I have them and am adding them to a ship. Movement is slow, even at advanced tech levels. And some useful advances, like fighter bases, don't exist at all. In fact, planetary defense is something of a joke. Antaran fleets (and your enemies, if they could ever get it together) bash aside star fortresses and orbital batteries with ease, although shields are much harder to defeat. 

Bottom-line: You can spend some enjoyable hours with this game, but in the end it is rather unsatisfying with the lack of benchmarks (HoF) and some missing elements that made the earlier versions fun. But for a few bucks, it is OK. But no way is it worth $25 retail. With modding, it gets better. But I would not pay the developer full-price for a game that owes much to volunteer modders. 

And here is some good news: For a mere $6 normally (and less, on sale) you can buy Moo 1 & 2 as a bundle. And both, especially Moo2, are much more complete and playable games. And compared to this version, Moo 2 is not all that primitive. Enjoy!

As a fan of the original Master of Orion and MOO 2 I really wanted to like the game. The graphics and audio are nice but the game play feels hollow.
In a way the game feels like a mobile phone version of a strategy game. Theres no depth and the game comes across as boring when compared to other space strategies like Stellaris and Endless Space.

The 4x space strategy game I've been looking for, for so long. With the 5X Mod available in the Workshop, you'll have a great time conquering the stars. 

And the game has great production value. It feels good and has a lot of polish and personality. It doesn't feel bland like Endless Space 2 does. 

Also, it might not be as deep as MOO2. I only played MOO2 a few times, so I can't say for sure. But this new MOO is a game you'll have a good time playing. 

Have fun!

Great game.

I refer to this edition of Master of Orion as CTS (Conquer the Stars) because that makes differentiating easier.  And it doesn't really deserve the MOO acronym.

Dull and boring.  Uninspired.  For kids.  I really tried to like this game but there's nothing interesting here and the game is easy enough that even higher level difficulties don't help challenge.  I would call it cookie cutter but even generic samey cookies are better than no cookies and if Conquer the Stars was the only 4x game available I'd probably switch genres.  There are signs of inspiration here, dashes of talent and effort but that's only when you're watching the various NPCs.  NPCs are animated, distinct and interesting to watch and listen to but that seems inevitable since the hiring manager for voice talent for this game seems to have just wanted to meet all these celebrities and used the game as an excuse.  But aside from the NPCs this game is awful.

There's a lot of hand-holding and most systems are automated.  You -can- design your own starships, but there's rarely any need as the AI can't keep up anyways so there's little difference between hitting the "Upgrade All" button and intricately designing a killer ship.  You can develop the best path for a colony to grow but all colonies end up being samey and uninspiring and it makes just as much sense to hit the autobuild and leave them alone..  

Galaxies are small and uninteresting to look at with one star per system and star systems only have a couple points of interest.  There's a difference between simplistic to the point where information is distilled down to the most important parts (see original Master of Orion) and being boring an uninteresting.  Star systems look all the same after a while, orbital distances are always identical and I never felt a sense of discovery or exploration when entering a new system.  If you've seen one CTS star system you've seen them all.  Literally.  There's not too much available in terms of different art assets.

I wanted to avoid comparisons to Stellaris because Stellaris is widely considered the dominant 4x space game right now and it feels unfair because they're very different games.  Stellaris is designed to be complex, big, epic and cinematic with an emphasis on the exploration and grandeur and vastness of space.  It creates a sense of literally anything being possible and that space is just -waiting- to rip you apart.

CTS is designed to offer the most minimalist experience one can have and still be called a 4x game. It's good for kids under 10, I suppose.  They can learn the basics of 4x but the same can be said of Candyland being an appropriate introduction to table top wargaming and RPGs.  CTS is cute and dull, flat and unimaginative.  If you want to introduce someone to 4x games you could give them MOO1.  Or MOO2.  Or Pax Imperia: Emminent Domain.  Or the Galactic Civilizations games.  Sword of the Stars 1.

Mechanics for exploration are micro-managed but nothing happens during that management.  Who cares what class a planet is or whether it's Rich or Poor.  These values don't matter much.  More planets = Win.  Technology research feels like asking Mom for a toy at the store and she tells me to pick one.  Combat is boring and uninteresting to watch or participate in, not that your participation really changes outcomes all that much.  It was so easy to pull ahead of the computer that most wars are effectively over at 10 turns and the rest is just convincing the AI that you won already.

Overall just a big disappointment.  Occasionally I reinstall just to make sure I wasn't being harsh, play for 20 minutes and then realize I was actually being nicer than CTS deserves and delete again.  I just wish CTS realized that more than 8 year olds play video games.

(Update for 2022)

Started playing MOO and MOO2 again this year so I thought I'd try out CTS and see if it had gotten any better.  No patches, no releases, no new DLC.  I bought all the DLCs for the races but unlike Stellaris, there are no new game mechanics to go along with their race pack releases.

The same bugs that existed before still exist.  If you use the cinematic camera view in battles the ships jitter and shake as the camera tries to keep up with them which just looks awful.  Like freshman college 3d animation work.  What's worse is that there have been no new editions, galaxies are still pitifully, ridiculously, comically small and there's no way to ever have all the races in the game in the same galaxy as each other.  

I give up, this game just plain sucks.  I like it even less now than when I was first disappointed by it not being a "better MOO2".  And after years and years of regular, large content updates and DLCs from Stellaris I can safely say that the only thing CTS offers is inspiration for a mod for Stellaris bringing over all the playable races.

Man, I really looked forward to this too.  Such a waste of voice work and character animations.  Even mods don't always work correctly and some cause constant crashes.  Not that it's the modders fault that basic features like galaxy generation and number of opponents selections are, for lack of a better term, neutered.

Actually, yes, that's the perfect way to describe CTS in 2022: A neutered 4X game.
Stellaris
Interesting 4X, kind of true to the old games. Worth playing.

I knew that it would probably be a disappointment, so I waited until it was on sale for 4 bucks.
It still was a bad investment.

They kept it somewhat close to MoO2 in some points, but changed others. The problem is that the things they have changed made the things they didn't change no longer work.
For example MoO2 was an open galaxy kind of game. You could fly anywhere, but you were heavily restricted by range. All fleets were automatically hostile to each other, but that did not matter since nobody could get to you.

They changed from free movement to star lanes. I don't even think that this is a bad idea. Star lanes have many advantages in terms of game design. However all fleets are still automatically hostile and now everybody can reach anybody (in your locked in area of space which everybody shares). Which means that everything you are building will be destroyed by someone. Any scoutship that encounters anyone will be shot down. And if it isn't the other races, then it is pirates beelining to your new building project (or colony ship) from halfway across the galaxy.

Which changed the game from an open galaxy exploration (with defense being mostly a colony thing - and most of your space being defended by range) to basically building walls/strongpoints and operating behind them. The map in this game becomes more like a board game where you try to block choke points to secure space.  It feels very small.
There is a certain fantasy that people want to fulfill when they play a specific kind of game. And this mechanic kills the fantasy. It's not enjoyable.

This also applies to the Orion System itself. It used to be in the middle of the map and everyone had more or less the same chances of reaching it. Now with the travel restrictions Orion is in someone's territory (and not even close to the galactic center for some reason). Everyone else is unable to get there (without declaring war to several other races or opening your borders to several races). The first few playthroughs I never even knew Orion existed. And even after beating it a couple of times... you just have won by the time you can get to Orion. There's little to no point to it.

Right away, in the first 5 minutes or so, the game welcomes you with bad polish. Like the opening developer cutscenes not being skippable. The first time I tried to start a new game it froze. Custom races need to be redefined every single game. The build queue is horrible to operate. 
The UI is confused. For some reason they replaced hovering the mouse and explanatory tooltipps/popups with the need to click on things to see details in some other control. Which I don't get at all. Did they think they were making a smartphone app in the beginning? How does that happen?

I was warned by the bad reviews. The game quickly gave me an impression that they were right. And nothing happened to make up for the initial impression.

I will probably play it again and maybe even invest some time into it. But for me it is the kind of game that I play because I want to figure out how to beat it (and then forget it). Not the kind of game that I would play because it is fun/engaging and keeps me coming back.

If you are looking for a good MoO2-like 4x play Interstellar Space. Or MoO2 (between the three I would prefer MoO2, even today, but IS came pretty close).
wee wee woo woo my ship go boom boom

Excellent game! After 3 starts I've learned how to progress/stay alive, and realized what needs to be done for a long game.
The UI is slick and intuitive. Tutorial help really helps ;) Moving through menus and finding your way around is a breeze.
Modern graphics look great. Traversing the stars and planets is very easy. Knowing where events are taking place is a matter of clicking on the icon notification. WOW... well done devs. 
The research tree is vast but after taking some time to read through them as I go helped me see things I need to focus on.
Now I have to learn how to manage planets as their size maximizes, ie terra-forming to allow more pops, adjusting the economy to keep pollution down and morale & BC($$$) up. And then... moving into the galaxy to meet and greet others ;)
Shall I be naughty or nice?? oh boy this is gunna be fun :))

This game is awesome. Anyone waiting to pull the trigger is missing out. I restarted again as I realized I wasn't aggressively expanding. Unlike games where happiness is global, MOO happiness/morale is planetary only. So colonize all you want! The primary focus becomes building up your fleet for war!! The Antarenes periodically invade 1 of your planets. So 1 goal is to wipe them out. Then there's the ai that surrounds you. AND then there's Orion! I'm playing on easy and surviving to turn 500 so far to learn what to do.
The turns play fast and great UI helps move the game along at a steady pace. Forget the past, unlearn what you know... just buy it and enjoy :))

If you were a fan of Master of Orion 2, this game scratches many of the same itches.  I wish it had a bit more customization option in terms of map types, races, etc.  But overall I've really enjoyed what feels like a modern version of the game I loved years ago.

The game can be fun, but ultimately is mostly an inferior clone of Master of Orion 2. It also very buggy and very clearly unfinished. For that alone I'm very strongly tempted to thumb it down, but I do want someone to eventually one day make a *good* Master of Orion game again, so I'll still thumb it up.

Some positives and negatives:
+ The planet graphics are very nice and probably the biggest improvement over Master of Orion 2.

+ The tech tree is, for the most part, copy-pasted from Master of Orion 2. This includes the innovative "you can only research 1 out of 3 possible objectives" mechanic.

+ Designing your ships yourself with a slate of techs is cool (copied mostly wholesale from MoO2)

+ They, at least, made an attempt to add tactical combat. More than you can say for 99% of the post-MoO2 4X space games.

+ Espionage is slightly better than in MoO2 (but still not great).


- For some reason the dev team got confused about what they were building and made this game partly into a tower defense game. There are limited paths from each star, only allowing you to go to certain other stars. You can have stars right next to each other where you can't travel between them without following some convoluted maze. This makes no sense in the context of the game world and is annoying gameplay-wise. 

- On top of this, the ships can for the most part only move 1 "area" per turn. "Area" meaning planet to planet, planet to warp point, warp point to other warp point. This is regardless of what engine technology you research. The net result is that moving your ships anywhere is mind-numbingly slow. Even at end game it'll take you a minimum of 3 turns to move a ship from a planet in one system to a planet in an adjacent system. It absolutely ruins the gameplay. Because of this point alone, I will never play this game again.

- The tactical combat feels like a demo that a few programmers whipped up in a couple days. It is completely inferior to the detailed combat in MoO2 where you were encouraged use specific weapons in specific scenarios and methodically figure out where to move your ships next. In this game you'll almost always just be making minor adjustments to what your ships are choosing to do on their own, which never involves any strategy. The formations feature seems completely broken as I've never gotten it to successfully work. For some reason there are speed sliders (why would you ever want your ship not at full speed?). I'm sorry, but 2D tactical space combat is superior. I've never seen a dev do a good job with 3D 4X space combat. FTL showed the world how to do fantastic tactical space combat over a decade ago and yet no one seems to have gotten the hint to copy them.

- The fleet management in this game sucks. You have no way of assigning names or hotkeys to your fleets (or ships). The creation of fleets is completely haphazard- a fleet is created if ships happen to be sitting in the same area doing the same activity. This means in late game when you actually have a lot of ships and want to keep groups of them together and not have them mix accidentally, it's next to impossible.

- Trade deals were overpowered in MoO2 but in this game they are insanely overpowered. From early to mid-late game, they give you many multiples what you might earn from your colonies alone. I don't have a problem with trade deals being lucrative, but I have a problem with them being so unbalanced in comparison to what colonies can earn on their own.

- Capturing enemy ships is not in the game

- Ship veterancy is not in the game. This was a crucial aspect in MoO2 (and is in most 4X games) so its absence really sucks.

- The end-game sucks for a bunch of reasons:

  - Inexplicable limit of 1 Doom Star per civilization. Why would you put a limit on the coolest and most powerful ships in the game?

  - Once a planet is full, your excess food is useless (unlike in MoO2 where it could be shipped to other planets or sold)

  - Once you've exhausted the research tree, your science points are useless (unlike MoO2, where you'd research hyper-advanced techs that offered additional miniaturization benefits)

  - Going to Antares just takes you directly into a battle screen. No cutscene or anything cool about it.

  - No end game cutscenes after achieving victory

  - The economic victory condition involves investing in some galactic stock market which offers no other benefits than points towards the economic victory

- The ship design screen is a mess. When you make modifications to a weapon you can't directly see how much space it takes up. You have to just add it and then see how much your available space decreased by. It's this way with lots of other stats too. Why hide statistics from the user? In short, it looks a little cooler but is vastly lower in utility than the comparable screen from MoO2.

- For some reason, you're offered 2 models per class of ship to choose from. But if you choose the alternative model, it will not appear in icons or on the main map. Only the primary model ever appears.

- Invading a planet just sort of throws the results on screen. There is no animation, no effect, no dialogue, no nothing.

- The devs forgot or never bothered to offer terraforming for lava or grassland planets.

- Lots and lots of other bugs not mentioned here

An excellent new rendition of the old classic Master of Orion I & II. It diverges a bit from the past games, trying some new things out, but if you are familiar with Master of Orion II play then you can walk into this knowing basically what to do and when. Its not a Stellaris clone and considering its pedigree was never meant to be; more old school in the classic struggle for dominance. There are no penalties for going to war, you can be at war the entire game, with everyone, at all times. You can also Ally with everyone, and win diplomatically. You can get open borders with someone one turn, fly your fleet to their Homeworld uncontested, the next turn declare war, and in the deplorable words of Col. Miles Quaritch, "when we destroy it, we will blast a crater in their racial memory so deep, that they won't come within 1,000 parsecs of this place ever again." The interaction between civilization management and diplomacy is more decoupled, no war wariness, no limits on empire size, or debuffs for being successful. Which is fairly common theme of 4X games now to prevent a player from running away with the game; really to prevent a player from curve stomping the AI so the developers don't have to put any effort into developing said AI for single player game modes. So less of a story telling medium, more of an empire brawl. And yes the AI will do the above to you if you let it. So good luck and have some fun mastering Orion.

I previously had this negatively reviewed, but after having played a little bit more I enjoy it and would recommend.  I will say Galactic Civilization III is probably the better game, go check that out.  Both are very similar in many ways.

It is surprisingly complex for it's price-point, and has a reasonable amount of depth to really go for many different playstyles and strategies.  The tech-tree is pretty deep, and the micromanagement of planets definitely makes large impacts.  It is also simple and easy enough to jump in and start playing after watching a 15 minute youtube gameplay video, unlike games like EUIV where you have to basically watch 8 hours of tutorial to know how to do everything.

There are a variety of races, good graphics, and the combat/battle system seems fairly complex with different weapon types, armor categories, engine and speed differences, as well as weapon facings.  It is worth noting the manual battles are difficult to control, and most experienced players resort to auto-resolving everything.

Now for some negatives.  You need deep research of a specific far-teched military troop invasion in order to conquer an enemy planet, and must spend dozen[s] of turns getting an army from one of your worlds to one of theirs.  I will say other space games similar to this also have similar barriers, but im not sure I like the forced tech down a specific line every game if you want to conquer anybody.  

I played my first game on a cluster based galaxy, this was probably a mistake because the ONLY way to travel between distant star points is again a very specific technology far down the tech tree.  I recommend a normal spiral galaxy, even then you are limited in exploration until again, you reach a specific technology down a specific path fairly deep into the mid-game.

Also I've never played any of the other Master of Orion games, nor do I have any nostalgia or past experience with this series.
It's not a particularly in depth or complicated 4X game but that's what i like about it, it's simple and doesn't clutter you down with tons of systems and mechanics.

Recommend, but I've loved MOO since MOO 1 and even liked MOO 3, once got over the monumental learning curve.

The Good
Pretty much everything, has the 4x down and the alien interaction is excellent.  You can really build a relationship with alien neighbors, one you can count on, and the game has a great GUI to let you know how your diplomatic efforts are going.  Tech tree captures all the classic MOO technologies.   The custom alien design, excellent as always.  Just note the pre-made alies break the design rule having far more build points than normally allowed.  Nevertheless is satisfying to win against such opponents and the game is challenging but not impossible to win.

The Bad
Ship combat.   The user interface and controls are too high level, not intuitive at all, hard to use and no where explained.  This was not the case in MOO 1 or MOO 2.  I love that the battle spaces have stuff in them that can be used to advantage BUT with limited or no ability to control ship movement or weapon use it is pointless.  

For example, despite on-line videos and tutorials have found no way to tell a ship to hold off firing a weapon (in old MOO games you could click to turn it off) this is critical to tactics as many good weapons have such a long cool down you get one shot really.  It very much is an issue with missiles as they have a long cool down and also there are certain defenses that trigger on the first missile so staggered missile waves are the way to defeat them.

The controls you do have are not great AI, like stay at a certain range, fire at a  certain range etc.  They require micromanaging to work as advertised.

In all this makes fighting the Antarans at home impossible as one must use tactics to defeat them, sheer numbers and tech wont do it.

The Ugly
Nothing ugly about this game.

The Want
Improve the ship controls for ship combat.  More things to build at steroids and warp points would be cool.  More aliens, bigger maps :)  just because they are cool.
is good game been playing for 15 years
Good game turn based space conquest at its current best.

Overall, I'd give this remake an OK status. The best way to describe it - take Master of Orion 2, change a few things, upgrade graphics and here you are. If it's enough for you then feel free to stop reading this review, but if you want more of a indepth analysis, then continue reading.

As I said before, the base line for this remake was obviously MoO2, however in remake the devs changed quite a few things. Probably the most controversial of the changes is the math behing pollution. During the early access times they change the system quite a few times (3 in total, if I remember correctly), before stopping on the current one. It's decent enough, however, they also changed a few core buildings and technologies that made the pollution really annoying and a general limiting factor for your production. However it also made it possible to send you production into overdrive mode and pollute your planet to oblivion (or to the point of climat changes), so... a plus and a minus from me.
Changes to technologies however are a minus with no redeamiong factors. The process of researching became more unified and less impactfull. There is a high chanse that everyone end up with everything, as there is not that much branching choises. Some tecnologies and buildings are pretty dumb, to the point of total uselessness, like i.e. warehouse, that makes buyouts cost less for all buildings. On paper it should be a decent upgrade, however this building is pretty high up on the tecnology tree (lvl 4 out of 12) and as such require a considerable production or money investment.
But on to the more positive side - combat. Let's face it - as much as I love the indepth combat in MoO2, everyone know that as soon as more then 10 ships are involved in the battle, it becomes a very tedious process.  Here this problem does not exist, as turn-based combat was traded for realtime combat. And devs made their best effort to translate the weapons and abilities into new realities. They were finetuning the combat balance probably the longest before the release, and as such I'd say they've done a really good job. However, the rocketspam is still strong, but there is also a high chanse that you end up on the other end of this, as an AI sometimes takes a liking to that strategy too.
To more of the positive changes - espionage. In most of the instalments of the series, espionage was nothing more than a bunch of numbers. Here it is more personalised, with agents being valuable and loosing one may hurt you a lot.
But the one thing I will never forgive the devs for - the beautifull invasion screen from MoO2 is gone. Now you have more or less MoO1-style invasion instead of a simulated battle animation that was acurately portaiting the numbers of troops, tanks, mechs, even jetpacks! But alas, it's not what we have.

The game looks pretty enough and has some fun voice acting but that does not make a good strategy game. Everything feels bland and mediocre and almost the whole time I was playing I just felt myself wishing I were playing Master of Orion 2 instead.

[h1]A Beautiful UX In Search of an Interesting Game[/h1]

Whoever led the user experience design for this game should get a promotion and an all-expenses paid vacation to a Gaia-class island resort. Each of the empire management screens is well-organized, easily accessible, a pleasure to look at, and easy to understand. Miraculously, the screens are [b]always[/b] available from the top-right corner of the screen, which is a crucial detail that's so often neglected.

The game is fully playable in the sense that you can build ships, use them to settle new colonies, negotiate with your neighbors, spy on them, and blow them up. There are multiple ways to win and the game is free of bugs. There are a couple of clever ideas like having individual spies gain experience and having 'warp points' that connect nearby systems and give you a place to build a powerful defensive outpost or just place some ships in position to intercept. Fans of Bujold's Vorkosigan Saga or Elizabeth Moon's Serrano series will enjoy playing out 'wormhole blockades'.

Unfortunately, I have no further praise for the game. The elaborate real-time combat system is inscrutable and left unexplained by both the manual and the tutorial; I wound up just clicking 'auto-resolve' every battle even though I'm usually a control freak. Despite being a veteran from MOO1 and MOO2, I have no sense of what kinds of ship builds are useful here or how I would coordinate different kinds of ship tactics with different ship designs. The leaders show up with random abilities and there is little reason to care which planet or ship they are assigned to. The planetary buildings mostly just let you collect more of the same basic resources (food, production, and research). The unique planetary resources like "dark quartz" also mostly just give you a modest bonus to production or credits. There's no way to trade them with other species.

One of the game's most promising ideas is the 'system administration center,' which lets you export surplus food from large, urban planets to newly settled frontier worlds, and import production from those frontier worlds to help your stellar HQ crank out large projects a little bit faster. The problem with this idea is that systems are too small to really benefit from it -- the average star only has 2 planets, so you really don't wind up doing that much intra-system trade. The system administration centers come relatively late in the tech tree, so they have only a small impact on the game.

As far as trading with alien species, it's fun at first, but most of them keep only a tiny amount of credits in their treasury. As the game continues, the amount of money needed to sign a trade treaty or research treaty keeps increasing, and eventually none of the aliens can afford it. The aliens have no sense of proportion -- they'll offer you 0.1% of your GDP in exchange for declaring war on a powerful enemy. I captured one of their spies a few times, and the aliens never once tried to ransom their prisoner -- but then if I ask them what they'll offer me to get the spy back, they're willing to pay far more than it would cost them to recruit a new spy.

Espionage missions are likewise wildly imbalanced -- the cost and risk of driving an entire world into revolt is similar to the cost of blowing up a random building on that world; the cost of stealing an unimpressive galactic map is comparable to the cost of stealing cutting-edge military technology.

In theory, asteroid belts and gas giants offer interesting extra-solar targets that you can exploit even when you don't have a colony in their system. In practice, they're just not an important source of income -- 6 gas giants (which is nearly all of them on the map) will get you 30 credits a turn, compared to a total empire-wide income of about 1,000 credits per turn. They're literally not worth defending against pirates and rival empires; rather than building a warship to protect them, you'd be better off just building another production building on your core worlds.

I don't think I've ever been this bored playing a 4X game. If you're a graphic design student or UX engineer, buy this game to learn from its example. Otherwise, give it a pass and play the original MOO or Alpha Centauri.

Master of Orion 1 and 2 are so much better than this game.  Building a colony is hampered by too many things.  Most buildings are not worth building because of high upkeep costs until late in the colony development or not worth the investment at all.  Slow population growth (sometimes 40+ turns to increase worker count by one) slows construction to a crawl.  New colonies are not self sufficient for a huge stretch of turns so you can only create so many before your funds are strained.  Fleet production is expensive and the cost of maintaining planetary defenses is so high building a marine barracks is probably all you'll ever do.  Combine lack of defenses with pirates, Antaries, space monsters, disasters and other races you get a situation where the fleet is constantly being redeployed to put out fires.  This is because ships are slow to build, slow to move into position and heavily limited by cost and fleet cap.  Research goes from useless to usable for 1 out of 5 colonies.  This game doesn't come close to living up to it's legacy.

Master of Orion (2016) is a great nostalgic strategy game...what I like about it is that it keeps the narrative of past versions of game while adding new content and game play.   It's straightforward so its not overly complicated and you can get into action fairly quickly. This game is solid with endless replayability.  As a CON I'd offer that it needs additional content and an overall updated game; however, it is still good and often played.  As a PRO it keeps the game narrative spirit of previous version and the sound track  is a great addition over past versions. Personally I've played Sid Meier's Civilization, Colonization, Alpha Centauri, Beyond Earth, and Starships...this game always had that narrative of one more turn and continuation of exploration from these other games...too bad they don't create a story line connecting them.  I recommend this game without question and look forward to future versions.

Just enough is the same to activate my nostalgia. Which makes it fun, but also makes me want to play MOO2 instead. This is not the most complicated or deep space 4X game, but neither were its predecessors. For me, it feels like the right amount of complexity, except in the specific cases where it falls short of its namesake.   

+ I'm not sure about the hyperlanes themselves, but I like the way they've handled movement within a system. It's simple, but adds just enough extra strategy to make it interesting. 

+ The game looks nice, and there are a lot of small touches that help elevate it. Selected fleets point in the direction of your cursor. Ships in hyperlanes have a nice warp effect on them. The UI is light years better than MOO3 (but not 2). 

- The overall tone of the game is much more cartoonish, from the goofy GNN broadcasts, to the voice acting in general, to the Disney-esque animations of the characters. This is probably not a negative for everyone, but it's something that I personally don't like. 

- The Antarans are not mysterious or scary. They remind me more of the Vorcha from Mass Effect than the Antarans of MOO2. Basically space goblins. They show up and gloat and hiss at you, then yell "We'll get you next time!" or something else dumb, after you defeat them. The first time they attacked me, with two destroyers and two frigates that I thought would decimate my homeworld in the early game, I was shocked to discover that this elder, interdimensional race was using the same technology as me. Lasers and nuclear missiles on Antaran ships. Weird. 

- There are some aesthetic choices that I don't personally like. The Mrrshan are quite silly now. Basically just furries who use the word pride too much, and show a lot of cleavage for some reason. The new Elerians are generic, looking more like a minor race from a fantasy game than the techsuit-wearing telepaths of MOO2. And I guess the Bulrathi are nature protectors now? I never thought of them that way, but maybe I just missed that somehow. 

- There are various mechanical changes, some of which make sense to me while others don't. The main changes worth mentioning are the real time combat and the simplification of ship design. Also the fact that the game will update designs for you automatically, which steers the player away from thinking about their designs at all. It's convenient, but that convenience is bypassing something that was interesting, which is a bad thing. And the real time combat obviously results in some things being streamlined. I don't think ships have shield facings anymore. Energy weapons still have the envelopment mod, but since there is only one shield on a ship, all the mod does is increase damage to shields, which is boring. There are lots of little changes like that. 

? - Time to ramble: I think one of the things that Master of Orion has lost in its modernization is the ability to activate the imagination to the same degree. Older MOO games had to work with less, in a sense, in terms of showing this universe and its characters directly to the player - mostly text and single images. Adding higher fidelity assets and voice acting all over the place has taken some of that freedom of interpretation out of the player's hands and into the developer's. That may be a problem for people who had an image of this IP that is not in line with what they're shooting for with this game. 

I was tempted to assume that this 'less is more' approach is something that's kind of lost to history, as standards for presentation have shifted in AA and AAA development. But on the other hand, Amplitude's Endless series has done a great job of using development resources in ways that activate rather than constrain the imagination.

For those who have never played this game, the goal is to take over the Galaxy 1 turn at a time. You take over planets and populate them. You go to war with fleets of ships. You build economies, research technological advancements, and can engage in politics to keep people from invading your expanding Empire.  You are running all the shows, and it is so satisfying. This game will help you learn strategies to survive and thrive.  Build fleets of ships and build a spy to infiltrate the "Allies" you build.  There is so much to do and it all rides on your decisions. 

This game blew my mind how in depth it was. Being a huge fan of the Koei series Romance of the Three Kingdoms (mostly 8), I was looking for a game like it in space. My friend introduced me to Master of Orion 2 and it was so much fun.  What I love about this game is that you can get on a roll getting planets, but they are never safe at any time.  You can lose them and have to start over, but that's reality. Every move matters in the grand scheme of things. I like that you can win by various conditions, or by domination only.  I have spent too much time on this game, and I don't regret it. It does come with some negatives we have to speak about. 

 Please note that anything i'm about to say will not impact my score. This game is amazing and work the hours.

The bad of this game are in some of the functionality and in depth of options.  A good thing they added was multiplayer. The problem is that it didn't work for me and my friends on steam very well.  The first reason it didn't connect was because one of us used the mod feature, which has a lot of changes to the core game people enjoy.  If I download any mods and want to play with a friend who doesn't use my mods, we cannot game.  You can uninstall the mods, restart the game, and you will get the same error message. You must reinstall the game and restart the PC for it to work. The other reason is sometimes the other party just disconnects for no reason.  So if you are playing multiplayer, quick save/save all the time. Trust me.

The other thing is the tech tree, and is purely subjective, so take with a grain of salt.  If you want a more robust tech tree, look in the mods section.  Master of Orion 2 had one of the best tech trees i've ever seen.  In MoO, it's simplified and it's still very effective.  

If you want a game that will push your strategic mind, get this game. You will not regret it.

I came in with an open mind.    For years I've been searching for a light simple 4X game that is a worthy successor to MOO2.      Initially I thought this might be the game.

But it's like all the other ones out there.    The same conceits,  the same exact format, and same exact game-play as every other 4X game out there.

Let's start with the biggest problem:   Hyperlanes.

Every game has them now,  and they exist solely because the developers feel they have to have hyperlanes because every other game has them.    MOO2 I could launch my fleet in any direction.   There was no camping at a choke point and fortifying behind it.    That's the same strategy that works in all the other hyperlane based 4X games out there.   And I am tired of it.     One of the appeals of the open-format style of map is a threat can come from any direction.   You have to plan accordingly.    Hyperlanes take that out of the game.   So long as I stack fleets at choke points I've effectively won the game.    This shows a general lack of creativity – strategy that works in one game should not carry over to another game.   Especially when there is no excuse other than a lack of creativity – for a game that is based on MOO2 it should follow MOO2 closer.    If nothing else,  a complete map rework is in order.  Do away with the hyperlane model entirely and go back to an open map system,  otherwise the game is basically Stellaris Clone #471,3128.

Second:   The ship combat is fairly terrible.

I'm not here to watch poorly rendered ships pew pew with each other.   Nor do I want to click “AUTO RESOLVE” and have the random number generator tell me I won.    Cinematic space-battles done up with smash-cuts and predictable fighter-jet like antics are just jarring and out of place.     MOO2 had the best combat resolution – while I do not want stacks of pixelated ships to click on,  there has to be something better than watching the game dogfight dreadnoughts over and and over and over again.

Finally:   What the HECK is it with this trend of having an advisor utter “yes master,  right away master,  you are the best at what you do master no one is better than you master” every click?     Not the first game that has done this.   Took me awhile to figure out how to silence the infernal prattling.  I'm of an age and a generation where I don't need constant praise and reassurance.   It's sickening that this is the default setting and that it requires searching the menus to find a way to turn off the prattling.

There was a lot of negative feedback form the Steam Hate Police, so I didn't get it, even though I was a huge fan of the franchise, particularly MOO2 .

It took until 2021 for me to bite the bullet. 

You know what? The haters were dead wrong. 

MOO-CTS is a more-than-competent update of what made MOO2 great. This does NOT mean that it is a 'Stellaris' update. If your taste runs to endless spreadsheets, text adventures and micro, then Stellaris is the game for you. 

OTherwise, you'd probably find MOO-CTS  pretty good.

I bought this because I spent way too much time long ago playing the original game. It stays true to that experience. I did enjoy the  enhancements, such as the travel lanes, the choice of auto or commanded combat and the improved graphics.
BUT, it is still just a polished version of the original game from over thirty years ago. I WANTED to play the same game. Without the nostalgia factor, you will almost certainly be more satisfied with a newer design, with more stuff to do, more complexity and more DCL and updates (you probably know the game I am thinking of). 
That said, Master of Orion remains fun. The gameplay is fun and relatively easy to get to grips with, the species traits are fun, and the game is a decent challenge, although it does feel a bit more casual than the epic it used to be. There are lots newer games that are a lot worse, and the fact that I compare it to the likes of Stellaris even after the decades have passed is a testament to how good it actually still is.

In MoO2, I could select which character for the display portion of creating my own character. On this new Master of Orion, I couldn't switch the type. It was stuck on the very top (something beginning with an "A"). I couldn't actually create my own character regardless whatever I clicked on. At that point of finally getting through to this point of frustration, I had asked for this to be dumped from this Steam and refund my money for something very not worth purchasing. Steam said I did not follow their "rules" having gone beyond the point of two hours play time. I highly recommend dumping STEAM, period. I've downloaded all my games and will never purchase anything on STEAM again. Bye Bye STEAM.

i have rarely been more frustrated in a game. While i suspect that the reality of space battles is that the fights are logically balanced and make sense, it absolutely doesn't feel that way. During the fights in which I "have control" i have ZERO understanding of why my spaceships keep turning away from battle. Am i fighting? am I not fighting? is my attempt to direct my ship towards the fight doing anything, oh, wow, my shields just vanished, why isn't my ship firing anymore, etc. etc .etc. 

you're simply left in a space of not knowing if anything you do makes any difference at all, and if it does, there's nothing that explains WHY something you did actually did anything or not. 

Basically, i think that it's an attempt to make the battles look fabulously cinematicl. the result is absolute frustration and confusion. If i have to look up on youtube how and why fighting works, then there's something fudamentally flawed in the design.

More info.........
Imagine having numerous alien races at your disposal, instead of each one feeling unique they generally feel the same save  a few re-skins of the ships, different buffs that don't really make them stand out from each other but they do have talented voice actors. You may at times forget which one you're playing as, until your assistant keeps screaming at you every-time you discover something. I've never been so grateful for a mute button. 

Imagine a UI that looks amazing, but requires you to open numerous pages. Have a system of three colonised planets? Go to each one individually to build, constantly recheck the tech-tree by opening another tab in your tech tab, buy galactic shares from another tab inside the empire tab, and how about saving everytime you've built 2 or more of the same ships so it clogs up your production tab even if now they are outdated, you can't delete them so have fun trying to find your titan amid 30 other ship queues.

Do you like the News? Well you better because they will come on constantly like an YouTube advertisement telling you whats happening on your notification's just in case you couldn't see the brightly coloured icons above the end turn button.
Thankfully you can also use an 'adblocker' in the settings to stop those pesky news reporters.

Do you like being a Tyrant? Well you better because once you declare war on someone they in essence tell you to "Leave me alone and don't talk to me", even when they are on their last planet and your fleet is hovering above their devastated fleets remains with an arsenal of highly fatal spores locked onto their population. You could ask them for a un/conditional surrender but they are threatened by you and hence will block all communication with you, so your only choice to hear them one more time is to blow them out of existence. So they can complain about being defeated.

It is worth noting that you can solve some of these with mods.
On a arbitrary side note I also found it humorous that every time you were checking your Empire tab scrolling up and down would also zoom in and out of the galactic map.

BUT its GOOD. Why? Spies. Want to build a massive spy network and insert sleepers everywhere, who will topple entire empires? You can. This mechanic was so fun it kept bringing me back for more even though it is extremely exploitable. With a superior economy you will have so many spies in fact you can kill all their heroes simultaneously, make nearly half of their empire revolt and lose their hard earned colonies, steal all their tech so you don't need scientist or waste any money on science infrastructure. Use that money to get more spies. Leave them as counter-intelligence as they level up to lvl 5 while they capture your enemies spies and you ransom them for even more money.

It also has a RTS feature. Click on all your ships, get them to attack each enemy ship at a time, kill all of them. Feel like a badass admiral. Exploitable but fun. Until you become so cocky you send your small 10 ship fleet into an Antares portal, discover they have over 50 ships complete with Doom stars and your odds are so terrible that it forces you to auto-resolve. Lose your fleet. Then have another Antares fleet spawn in, go to your planet, bomb it with 40 bombs and still not kill your population, have another Antares fleet drop only 10 and kill everyone. Watch as they insult you. Build a bigger fleet and crush their invasion fleets. Watch them insult you anyway.

The Antares are perhaps one of the best parts of the game.

Voice Acting. There is Joker Bird-alien. A retired firefly pilot as a 1950's alien advisor. A disembodied Klingon narrating. And Rick's computer visualised in human form so people can stare at her. Plus many more. Needless to say they went all out. But maybe too much money went here and not on the UI. 

It can be fun but its hard to justify the price when there are many well crafted 4x games out there with superior game mechanics (eg Endless Space 2 has different game mechanics for each civ making each one feel unique. Something MoO sorely lacked.) Another is crisper more well thought out UI, opening a tab to get to another tab was just time consuming and tedious. Add on the fact they also locked one of the classic fav civs behind a paywall,  a move only a Ferengi would be proud of.

There are better games in this niche of MoO clones, well I guess this is technically not a clone but sucesor to the legendary franchise, but that's not the point. It looks pretty, but that's all it does better than MoO2. Interface is OK, but the old game did it better, ships move using jumplines instead of giving you total freedom, the buildings are placed on a globe, so not only you need to go into a globe view, you only see half of the buildings because others are on the other side of the planet... Diplomacy is bland, tech tree is bland. Spaceship combat is a pausable real time and it lacks precision which we had in MOO2 or even 1. Even GNN is bad, you hear and see the same jokes, get a bit of info and then there's a awkward pause while you wait for the scene to finish and get back to the game, it's like news show forgot to turn off a camera. They hired a fantastic cast of voice actors but it seem they just not cared enough to put any effort. 

Despite all those things it's not a horrible game, it's just bland, it makes you think that you could be playing a better game that will scratch that MoO2 itch. 'Uninspired' is probably the best way to describe this game.
