I see a lot of bad reviews for Master of Orion, and I observe that they've completely missed the point of this iteration of Master of Orion. This game is supposed to be played on a lighter level. 

Comparing rounds in this game to deep 4x games like MoO2 and Stellaris is like comparing a round of Starcraft 2 to Civilization 6. This is a better choice when you can only sit down once a week, or you're trying to get a 4x novice into the genre. There's only really this and Endless Space in that pocket.

They designed the rounds to average eight to twelve hours, rather than twenty to thirty. They designed it to be shallow rather than deep, so you can dive into the action rather than grind an entire session on building out a fleet or managing your empire's economic future (that you'll have to adjust solar system by solar system after 20 minutes because of research).

The game was actually very well fleshed out. Diplomacy and espionage are well done, to the point where it is entirely possible to win a game without firing a shot, or you can have minimal interactions with them and just attempt to wreck their day. Research actually manages to matter, but not be impossible to win without, battles can be as simple or complex as you want by controlling the fight. You can micromanage your economy for maximum profit or work it in broad strokes.

But... with all those options, unlike other 4x games, you can ignore or involve yourself as you choose, and not be punished for it. Mostly. Battles, unless you play a total war game well, I recommend leaving alone. Point is, you don't have to remember what your last twenty-five and next twenty-five moves were when you start up your save.

So get in there and have some fun actually getting through a game without playing it like it's a second job.

edit April 30 2021 - Playing the game on a huge map in the hardest mode, its not hard, the AI doesn't upgrade their ships, they all run beam weapons and obsolete shit to make it easy mode. When you go into a battle without AI running it for you the enemy ships just float across the map and wait at the far end. I have had a frigate take down multiple cruisers, which should be impossible. I still enjoy the game and only really play to unlock achievements now. Plus the trade system is broke as hell, early trade routes the moment you can afford to = win, pure and simple. you can make so many credits early game with that, or free techs. Generally by about turn 120 I am caught up (on super duper ultra hard mode) that the game is all but over. Hell, I gift the enemies credits to do trade contracts with them. You're only out the credits a few turns that way and the $$ rolls in.

Being an old PC Gamer I grew up on games like Wing Commander, X-Wing/TIE Fighter, Wolfenstein 3d, Doom, Civilization (Civ 4 is the best btw) X-Com, MechWarrior, MetalTech and a little game called Master of Orion and then Master of Orion 2: Battle at Antares. Note also helps that I'm a massive nerd who made sure I never missed X-Files, Deep Space 9 and Babylon 5. So I loved Master of Orion 2, hell I still play it now and then as it's just a classic.

Then we got Master of Orion 3 and it sucked the big one. I kid you not when I tell you I beat the game the first time around by just clicking "Next Turn" still it was a massive pile of crap and shows why you shouldn't make a 4X Space Civilization game too 'real' oh and aliens looking like actors in rubber masks is fine. Really look up the making of that POS. It made Star Control 3 look good.

Still I was happy when I heard that there was a new Master of Orion in the works. Hell I would read some of the early stuff about it and it sounded NGD had a pretty damn good idea of what they are doing! Hey look at the voice cast they got! Mark Hamill, Michael Dorn, John de Lancie, it's a game with Luke Skywalker/Joker, Worf and Q! Nah there's no way Stellaris will even be anywhere near as good as this new Master of Orion!

And it's just okay. Well alright let me put it this way... This is a very good game for someone who wants to get into 4X titles but if you are someone like me who spent late nights in 1997 making fleets to go kill that Space Dragon as I really want that planet it's guarding? You'll be bored.

It's just very simple, where I remember MoO2 offering up a number of things that I had to keep track of and look at. This just doesn't feel that way. This just felt kinda over all simple, I already knew what to do, I could just coast by as I knew what to do. Hell even playing on the hardest mode I had little trouble with the game. Just gameplay wise? It just felt like I had no real trouble.

The story is still the same, for those of you who never played MoO before? You run a Empire taking it's first steps into space. Alien races tend to have one thing they are really good at. You fly ships around exploring the galaxy, starting up colonies on new worlds. Try and keep the other Empires happy or go to war with them. And then there's Orion the homeworld of the galaxies big precursor race left behind with all of their super powerful tech. They also left behind a massive robot warship to keep the younger races off until they are ready.

The voice acting is very good, I mean after all look at the three names I put down there are more. The game has a nice look to it, vastly better then MoO 3. No real game killing bugs I found and it's pretty stable. I will admit it does feel much shorter then other 4X games I've played.

Now will I recommend this game? Alright... If you are someone like me who spent a lot of time playing 4X games and you really want a 4X space game? No I really can't recommend it. Go with Stellaris, you'll have a lot more fun and yes while there's a ton of DLC for it? That means there's a crap ton of new content for it. If you are someone who's new to 4X titles or maybe you have a kid who wants to get into them? Then yes by all means pick this up, it's a great intro to those games and something like Stellaris can be overwhelming to the new player.

This 4x is a slog to get through.  Let's just pretend you've never played MOO or any 4x game before. This is your first iteration into the genre.  It's  a poor first impression. The game has no depth. It is very basic in terms of forming fleets, upgrading ships, taking over planets etc.  A few annoying game mechanics like pollution removal and command points for ships just adds to the frustration. Yes, plenty of games have command points. However, i've im close to my limit and I need to build a few more ships to finish my fleet, i'd rather not have to do math to see if i'm going to go over my command point limit when those ships do finish construction.

Diplomacy is actually really fun. You see in real time the effect of a trade deal or forming an alliance. The animations during diplomacy are good too.  

Whats the issue? You have to download mods to make the game somewhat enjoyable. 5x and UCP mods are basically mandatory since the developers have abandoned the game years ago and players have to fix the tech tree and crush all those bugs.  The game is just plain boring. When you have games like Endless Space 2, another 4x turn based space game, why play an inferior product.  I suppose the big difference here is you actually use spies, which is interesting. Whereas in Endless Space 2, you have to hack all the time, which is annoying. Another quality of life addition i'd like to see is fleet power comparisons. If i'm about to assualt an enemy fleet, i'd like some idea of how difficult the battle will be before I fly over to them. 

Soundtrack is like 3 songs that loop over and over again. Sound design is a huge deal breaker for me as it adds to immersion. Endless Space 2 has an amazing soundtrack. This....wow....3 songs that loop. When you enter a war state with someone, it changes to an ominous sound track but again, it loops after a few songs.

Just overall lazy. The developers abandoning the project after a few years is testament to that.

Yes, with a hefty caveat - there's two mods that fix the game to be playable, in the workshop.

With the mods, it's a pretty 4X with a decent call-back to the original Master of Orion games.   It won't break new ground.   It won't stand up to something like Endless Space II or Stellaris.   It will feel familiar and it won't do wild wacky stuff to differentiate itself.

For what it is (which is a modern remake of MOO1 or 2), it's a good, pretty 4X that does everything you expect in a 4X.   Planets, ships, exploration, conflict, research, diplomancy and espionage, it ticks all the boxes and hits all the bullet points.   Again, with the two mods.   Species leaders and UI helpers are ell modeled and voiced, and the game has a very easy 'Just one more turn' flow.

The 'special sauce' in Master of Orion is the big bad, that comes out of portals every couple dozen turns and delivers a smackdown to a random player (strongly weighted towards the higher score players).   Middle-game, you can start fighting off these raiding fleets, but early on they'll just hurt whoever's in the lead and keep the power balance fluctuating.   Even into mid-game, you'll still need to put effort into fleet response and defenses, and in end-game you can take the fight to them.   Overall, the mechanic keeps the game a lot less smooth, and more interesting.

The game itself is alright, basically a clone of MoO II. The production quality is abysmal. Occasionally, starting a battle will cause the game to get stuck in an endless loop, editing ship designs crashes the game, an event like an Antaran fleet showing up freezes it up, or the game will simply not progress past a specific turn count because it gets hung up on opponent turns. I was unable to finish two out of three games I started. In the third I discontinued a promising conquest because battles with the fraction started to make the game freeze and had to go the long way around a military outpost attacking which crashed the game.

Supposedly, there is a community maintained mod that fixes bugs, but it seems that savegames are not compatible and to require manual interventions for every update. Unless you enjoy tinkering, save yourself the frustration and steer clear.

I wanted to like this game as MOO2 was so good. The problem is that MOO2 is much better. I would have preferred the game if they had just taken MOO2 as-is and updated the graphics. With mods, the gameplay here is pretty good. Problem is that the GUI is really tiresome. No mini-map and you need to get an individual planet view to control planet output and resource usage properly. So there is lots and I means lots of scrolling and zooming in this game. It started to drive me crazy after a while. There is a colonies list but you can't control the colony fully from that list. Also food can't be shipped around the empire with freighters as with the original so you have to micro that aspect too much. Also the tactical battles are pretty lame - you end up auto-resolving or just selecting all the ships and targeting each enemy individually. Nothing much to do there. This could have been a great game but some of the design decisions just made it worse than the original (which is still great to play BTW). Thumbs down on this one.

This isn't meant to be a 1:1 remake of earlier games in the franchise, and it isn't. If you accept it for what it is, though, it's still fun.

MoO is a good-looking game with a lot of little things I like, such as the humorous robot newscasters and the slick, beautiful planetary graphics. Other things it does are a little unimpressive, like the ship models flying in against a mostly static image when colonizing new planets. There's a lot of give and take, but fortunately, most of the options various players may have mixed feelings about (such as random events and Antaran attacks) can be turned on or off, as you please.

This isn't Stellaris, so don't expect deep diplomacy or incredibly complex gameplay. It's almost a kind of "4x-lite." However, I enjoy it for that, because as much as I love games like Stellaris, that's not always what I want to play; sometimes I want something more straightforward and requiring less attention and brainpower.

That being said, there are two real complaints: First and most damning is the lack of hotseat multiplayer, which I know is no longer the industry standard, but which has always been a staple of the franchise and is incredibly disappointing to see absent from this version. It's very much a case for me, as a lifelong MoO fan, of being unable to justify the purchase of more than one copy. I didn't mind buying it once, but while I'll gladly play with a friend who already has it, I'm not shelling out for a second copy just so I can use network play to get someone else involved. Second is that the inclusion of the Elerians, Gnolam, and Trilarians as a paid DLC is kind of a slap in the face to MoO fans.

Overall, I like this game for what it is and what it does. The price has come down a bit since I first bought it, and now I can say it's worth $35USD for the collector's edition, not least of all because you get MoO 1 and 2 in that package. It's not, however, worth the $42USD price tag that includes the additional race DLC, so get it on sale...especially if you want to play with friends.

I have played the game a lot, trying to figure out a path that takes a reasonable amount of time to play a game, I have come to the conclusion that there is none.  The game has lost the flow of Masters of Orion II and instead is a grind, no matter how you look at it.  There are several broken parts to the game that worked in the past (MO2).  Travel between systems takes a very long time, so when Antarans attack, you have no chance of getting there unless you have a fleet in system.  Entering and leaving a system take a turn by themselves and then travel between systems can take many turns.  There are only travel lanes between systems and not direct travel, so you have to follow routes to get to where you are going, making trips take even longer.  Another aspect that slows the game down dramatically is the idea of system defense.  Rather than have each planet defended, the travel routes of a populated system can be protected using defensive bases.  These bases create another level of combat, extending the time it takes to try and achieve conquest victory, as mentioned I have played many hours and have yet to achieve a conquest victory as I am not willing to take the 24-36 hours of game play it would take to make that happen and that would be the speed on "Lightening" mode...  Another aspect that is broken in the game is economics.  In the game you have a tax rate, which is directly tied to morale, if you raise taxes your people revolt in short order and there isn't enough technology to placate them.  You can augment your taxes by build revenue generating buildings, there are three of them in the tech tree and you need them just to stay in the black.  Every other building costs you and does not contribute to revenue and there are more of them than you can count, so you have to be real selective when building.  In the past Production was tied to revenue, but there is a definite disconnect where your facilities cost you and without the revenue facilities, you would go bankrupt.  Finally the espionage and combat are broken, technology doesn't provide you a whole lot of advantage in combat, it seems that fleets of frigates (the smallest ship) are the best way to go in combat as numbers appear to play more heavily than the combat and defense values of the ships.  10 frigates will almost always win against a Titan (the largest) and the one Doomstar (only one allowed at a time) you get is easily swarmed and killed by the computer that uses almost exclusively Frigates, Destroyers and Cruisers.  The Spy system works well, but is broken because each spy costs more than you most expensive buildings and you need 10 spies for defense, this often is the cause of bankruptcy as you need them to keep your tech, ships and colonies alive, but you can't afford to have them.  All in all it is a frustrating and pointless struggle with your revenue and an endless grind to play.

Updated review for release of this game

Second Update to review  tagged on at the bottom.

Review 1 From release

Open up with.. this is a redo of an old game to modern standards with its own vision.

Basically  this game feels like a spiritual successor to Moo2/moo1 not a reskin of moo1 or moo2.
I would even go as far as to say its Civ5 in space.. but done better in some aspects.

The building system,  ship design, research and races all feel reminiscent of Moo2 but with improvements, older players can just pick up the game with a small learning curve.

It takes the real time combat and star lanes from Moo3 and to me makes them work better, judge that as you will some like starlanes, some don’t, the debate over that will not be solved here as everyone has their own view. I do think it could use some form of off road with a large turn penalty 
The real time combat seems ok.. just ok. It could use more depth, more control over the ships, more detail in what is going on.. and a larger battlefield to begin with.. thankfully this is just a meta portion of the game and though it can be improved.. it can be overlooked.

The game adds some of its own twists, voice acting and a few other things like actually having to watch your finances to avoid going broke.

The AI is getting better at building and expanding.. but again its combat tactics and ship designs seem silly still.. but vastly improved over the earlier builds.

Diplomacy is ok, but could be better.. not enough options it feels and the AI's really seem to not work together leading to it feeling like a cluster of 1v1v1v1 with no cooperation between non player sides. That being said that has been an issue with many 4x games.

Really enjoying the games take on Spying so far.. id like more options here or more effect from existing options.. stealing tech really seems to be the only decent option... would like to see some form of optional automated spy option.. or some way to reduce the micro for those who dont want the micro.

Pollution control i rather like.. if you do not clean up your polution your planet devolves to a different biome. Some dislike this as they feel its too micro heavy.. I personally enjoy it.

Colony management still needs work (moving population in the Civ window is still not present)

More Tech is needed with a few more building options in terms of ships. Though that is a minor issue.. it just would improve the overall experience.

The game is stable, has had some performance fixes all in all improved with each patch.

However it still has work to be done and a ways to go before it becomes gold.

I still really am enjoying the game and still get that "next turn" feeling.. it still feels like a nice comfy chair that I am returning to after a long break.  

I still am quite comfortable recommending this game to new and old fans.. 
I will just say however.. this is not moo1 or moo2..  if you expect moo1 or moo2.. you will be disappointed.. this is its own game :)

Review 2, DLC and patches later... 
They never did really fix the late game performance issues... though i dont think they can (stellaris also suffers from this)

The combat didn't ever get improved..

The new Antaran content just felt toxic..  not like in Moo2 where it was somewhat fun.

Spy system and diplomacy just never really got improved either.. i ceased playing the game at the end of 2018 as it had lost its magic somewhere along the way..

The game is still good.. but its just good.. they could have done so much better.. and i expected them to take it to new and better places.... instead Wargaming essentially dumped a small DLC (3 new races) with a touch of Moo2 content into the game and have more or less abandoned it..

Everything this game tries to do ... Stellaris ended up doing better.


I still recommend it for someone seeing a bit of Moo nostalgia .. or a super casual 4x game... but if you want the glory days of 4x  id go more for stellaris

As the fourth in the Master of Orion Series. Master of Orion: Conquer the stars is a fun space 4X closer to MOO2 than MOO1 or 3.  I especialy enjoyed the the improved graphics of the cutscenes for  race startup and the voice acting of the diplomacy screens and advisers.   I might have prefered that warp travel was ranged instead of using warp lanes with defendeble chokepoints.

I gotta say... I played a bit of MoO2 back in the day, and this is a very good remake. Not too flashy while still looking good. Pay-walls for some of the cooler factions is a little annoying, but at least the price tag is low for the base game.

I almost want to recommend against this since games like Endless Space 2 and Stellaris are far more in-depth with their 4X gameplay, but it's just that which makes me recommend this: it's a simpler, more pared-down 4X, so it's a good game for learning the ins-and-outs... and get addicted to that "Next Turn" button.

This is a review you should read if you've played (and loved) the first two MOOs for decades (as I did).
Lets get right to it:

The graphics are great.
The voice acting is very good.
The diplomacy and interactions with other races in this game are good (and pretty fun).
The basic game mechanics in this game (not combat) are very close to both the old MOOs, with tweaks and improvements.
The tech tree is full and gives you quite a lot of options.
I really had fun with the above mentioned, and it brought back found memories.

Now for the unpleasant news:
The combat is not turned based.  It's real time pausable.  Based on your taste this may or may not be a bad thing.  I was very upset to see no turn based, but I grew "tolerant" of it in order to enjoy the other parts of the game.  You are able to tweak and build your ships to your hearts content, so this helps buffer the blow to the "no turn based" punch.  Combat is a wash for me, as some things I really miss, but a few things make up for it.

But the big blow to this game is the UI.  Uggg.  And I mean UGGGG!.  As anyone that's played this type of game before knows, the planet screen is where you spend most your virtual life, and boy is that a micro, tedius, mislaid mess.  First, every button you need to click on is in an oposite area of the screen.  You'll be moving your pointer to the far reaches of every area of the screen for every single little action.  Want to just use your right mouse button to get out of everything?  Too bad, because that's not an option.

Next, to pick what you want your planet to build or work on, you'll click on the build choice button (off course), but the building choices then pop up and block the ENTIRE planet info screen.  So you'll find yourself clicking back and forth, back and forth to get your planet info, then make build choices; planet info; build choices.  It's crazy tedium.

But worst of all is the Auto Build AI.  After you get a couple dozen planets, there no way you'll want to micro them all (especially with the UI mentioned above), so your only ticket out of micro hell is the AI "mayor" to do the busy work for you.  The problem is, the AI builder is AWFUL.  It will build crazy buildings, for no reason, in crazy orders, and in crazy locations.  And if your tight for money, it will bankrupt you building stuff you don't want or need (on EVERY planet). 

So your faced with a choice: Micro hell as your game gets more than a couple systems, or risk the AI taking on some of the work, and risk going bankrupt and/or having planets with just plain crazy setups on them.  

And this problem is multiplied by the fact that even planets in the same system as one of your colonized planets needs to have a separate colony ship built to colonize it; then a transport ship for every single unit of population you wish to move to new planets; then the micro or crazy AI of cueing up alllllll the buildings again (there is no blueprint or saved build cue system).  

The micro, tedium, busy work, and fiddlyness just eats away at the good parts of this game.

On sale, this game was a nice little "demo" to see how the game was.  I would have been very upset if I paid full price.  And I am glad I got it.  But if given any other choice then thumbs up or thumbs down, I would have to grade it a C-, which means buy just a tiny margin, I am forced to give it a thumbs down.

1) Allow players to buyout items in their que for a given planet.  It would vastly improve pace of play in the mid/endgame.
2) Allow players to see what the current cost of trade and research treaties are without having to open up a negotiation with a race (show it on diplomacy dashboard).  Again pace of play so you can tell who can afford it and who cant.
3) Research dashboard should show flags for other races that have completed major research milestones, especially the ones that allow for the tech victory condition. This game would have been great if not for the Artificial Idiocy governing combat. That one AI does everything it could to ignore your orders, fly needlessly into shield-negating plasma clouds or concentrate salvos on unimportant trash targets.
If you manage micro-managing your ships into flying safely while watching them like a hawk (you need to pause and re-apply your orders every second) you can achieve flawless victory in situations where the auto-resolver lists your chances as "low" (orange) - not in the least because enemy ships could get "stuck" on the map edges and stop moving. Eventually this grows so tiresome you abandon the game.

If this were 2016 and being asked to pay the original full price, you'd be seeing a "thumbs down" instead.  But at this late price point, I'm a nostalgic old fogie who appreciates the inspiration and work going into dressing up MoO 2.  I am still grinding out a learning curve about all the strategic number crunching, but I've moderately enjoyed the climb so far.  The extensive 'glam' of animation and narration is fun and helps make the RPG aroma linger pleasantly for a lot longer than it would without it.  Mike Dorn still gets a A for an admittedly overexposed job that makes me sick of his voice.  (Sorry Mike, you know we still love you.  Similarly for GNN...fun for the first game, tolerable the 2nd.  You're probably gonna turn it off after that.)

Acknowledging the good art and graphics, this game has problems. Like the ending of THX-1138, they just quit polishing the subject before the job was really done--probably because it was overbudget.  Let's assume I'm content with a nostalgic resurrection of MoO2, don't expect too much game mechanic innovation from the title, and am just going to let the animation and cut scenes fill the emotional void.  What they did is amazing job for all the in-game stuff...but only where player race selection cancels out.  Plus they set themselves up for a big let-down when the game ends...those final cut scenes are really underwhelming by comparison.  (Come on guys, I have to auto-resolve the big Antaran fight, and even then no cinematic battle scene??)

Yes, I get it...a dozen or so races multiplied by a half-dozen possible victory conditions is 70 or 80 grand, epic animation sequences.  But remember how little game mechanics innovation I'm asking for and then tell me not finding a way to make those epic climaxes happen was a good game experience design strategy.

Now let's say after 20 years I actually *do* want some core game mechanic innovation.  Yikes.  This was a timid project at heart.  To be fair, I'm enjoying the ship customization, and the battle cinematics are really admired and appreciated.  But can't the pirates have some racial variety as well, instead of using the same clunky WW1 submarines for every pirate from one end of the galaxy to other?  Same with all the races' space stations and missile silos.  If MoO "RPG" ambiance is what you're selling, all that design uniformity on every freakin' planet is killing my immersion.  The assymetrical game balancing also seems really undercooked.  I've always found the Mrrshans annoying, so that doesn't bother me.  Variety and diversity means some of these characters should annoy me.  But the cats really seem *unplayable* this time so far.  Maybe I'm just too dumb to have yet figured out why marines matter more than the 6th decimal point.  (Why can't we have some planetary marine fight cut scenes now in 2016, either?)  Customize my own Mrrshans?  Thank you, I will!  But that menu seems really underbaked and unbalanced to me, too.

I leave with the caveat that I'm still dissecting this game and maybe my perspective of "balance" issues will change.  But without those grand epic finale cut scenes we talked about to reward the monotonous effort, it's a lot to ask for trudging my way through the same old tired Civilization-style 4x visual vocabulary with arbitrary "star lanes" that don't bear too much logical scrutiny.

I got my money's worth out of this title, and I'm not feeling bad about the hours I gave "Conquer the Stars."  I had genuine fun revisiting these old friends.  But we're on the back nine of this course far more quickly than I wanted to be, and more quickly than the obviously hard-working, big budget game makers wanted me to be.  I hope the company learned what it needed to about project management and has more presentable goods for the future.  Including another MoO.  It's obvious this was a labor of love, and the studio deserves credit for keeping the franchise's divine spark alive for new audiences.  Let's impress the next generation of nerdy kids next time too, without JJ Abrams style hand-waving in the critical late stages.  Take better care of your titles and don't leave the essential polish up to the "mod community."

MOO: CTS is an excellent game if you can accept it for what it does.  It is a fun, well done, 4X with a modicum of complexity and depth.  You can get in, straight away, and start exploring, building, researching and conquering the stars.  It is fun and enjoyable.

It is not a complex, deep galactic empire builder.  It is not a deep, complex space ship combat sim.  It does not have a deep, complex diplomatic system.

I have a lot of respect for games like Stellaris.  That game IS deep and complex, but I think that complexity and depth comes at a price: fun.  I find MOO to be much more fun than Stellaris, and you may as well,

It's difficult not to compare this to Stellaris and the Endless Space games, and MoO doesn't compare well in any aspects. The systems feel sterile, the combat is unsatisfying, and Michael Dorn's narration is just off-pace. Overall the whole experience lacked depth or anything single feature that grabbed my attention and made me want to explore it more.

This is probably a great game for those who played the originals and want to relive those days, but for me there are just too many other games worth checking out, and far better space 4Xs to get deep in to.

Great re-creation.  DOWNLOAD THE UNOFFICIAL PATCH BEFORE PLAYING - it is pretty buggy in its un-patched form.  

Things I wish were better: a smarter auto-build AI making micromanagement less needed; better fighter mechanics and effectiveness (wouldn't it be amazing to have a mini flight sim built in so you could pilot one?!); some form of ground combat mechanics with graphics involved and ideally some control (command and conquer style or something).

I can't recommend this without extensive modding.

So, the raids are not random and are done based on a hard multiplier of the player's fleet strength.  However, how the game assesses fleet strength seems to be bugged.  So, certain custom ship designs can result in the game spawning raids over 2x as strong as what you actually have.

Other things:  
-  The pollution mechanic varies wildly and results in wasting hours with pointless micromanagement.  The buildings to manage it don't do much.  Balanced, well outfitted planets still become polluted.
-  Many of the buildings have been changed to the point of being useless cash sinks so you have to micromanage buildings across dozens of planets individually, wasting more time.
-  You Citizens are more unhappy an will frequently kill themselves by striking out of the blue.  Meaning, yes, more micromanagement.  And, the mood boost buildings cost more to maintain, naturally, and do less.
- Volcanic worlds are the new toxic worlds.
- Constructed planets are high gravity.
- The leaders appear to be randomly generated and are mediocre mish-mashes of 1 to 3 skills, occasionally with some empire wide skills that are OP when leveled.  So, no more epic leaders, including Loknar and Zanatus.

Oh, yeah, and space lanes.  Every friggin turn based space game has space rails for space trains to travel on nowadays.

This review is in English and Slovak language:
Táto recenzia je v Anglickom a Slovenskom jazyku:

Older MoM titles are legendary games. Any remake of such games carries the risk that the new game will not meet the expectations of what it would like to achieve. Unfortunately, the new version of MoM belongs to the category of the less successful successors of legends. The game has several conveniences that stand out from most current space strategies:
1. It is a turn-based strategy that allows you to enjoy the management of great empires more.
2. It has a quality diplomatic system with sufficient capabilities and adequate AI responses.
3. As one of the few space games, it recognizes the star system as a set of several bodies in it and not as one whole. This means that in one system, planets can be owned by several opponents. This is very realistic, unlike most other space strategies, where building a small base will usurp the entire system and automatically prevent you from passing through it (such as Stellaris).
Unfortunately, everything falls on two serious shortcomings:
1. The game is very unbalanced. Who is more technically and economically advanced has no rival. All you have to do is secure a head start in research and a well-functioning economy, and no one will beat you. The game offers the possibility of a certain balance, where the mysterious Antares race repeatedly attacks the strongest player. It's interesting, but overall it's a weak patch to balance the game.
2. Boring! After a short time, the game becomes so incredibly boring that even the most rock fans will turn it off! The game has almost no storyline and very few side interactions.
The game is not expensive and does not have many DLCs, but it unnecessarily pushes you to buy connected content such as purchase of a collector's collection. Although it is not a bad game, I do not recommend buying it, because nowadays it no longer meets the demanding requirements of the gaming community for this type of games.

Staršie tituly MoM sú legendárnymi hrami. Každé prerobenie takýchto hier nesie riziko, že nová hra nenaplní očakávania toho, čo by chcela dosiahnuť. Nová verzia MoM žiaľ patrí do kategórie tých menej úspešných pokračovateľov legiend. Hra má niekoľko vymožeností, ktorými vyniká nad väčšinou súčasných vesmírnych stratégií:
1. Je to ťahová stratégia, čo umožňuje si viac vychutnať riadenie veľkých impérií.
2. Má kvalitný diplomatický systém s dostatkom možností a primeranými reakciami AI.
3. Ako jedna z mála vesmírnych hier, rozoznáva hviezdny systém ako súbor viacerých telies v ňom a nie ako jeden celok. To znamená, že v jednom systéme môžu vlastniť planéty viacerí oponenti. Je to veľmi realistické na rozdiel od väčšiny ostatných vesmírnych stratégií, kde si postavením akejsi malej základne uzurpujete celý systém a automaticky znemožníte prechod cez neho (ako napr. Stellaris).
Bohužiaľ všetko padá na dvoch závažných nedostatkoch:
1. Hra je veľmi nevyvážená. Kto je technicky a ekonomicky vyspelejší, nemá súpera. Stačí si zabezpečiť náskok vo výskume a dobre fungujúcu ekonomiku a už vás nikto neprekoná. Hra ponúka možnosť určitého vyváženia, kedy sitá záhadná rasa Antares opakovane útočí na najsilnejšieho hráča. Je to zaujímavé, ale celkovo ide o slabú náplasť na zabezpečenie vyváženia hry.
2. Nuda! Po krátkom čase sa hra stane tak neskutočne nudnou, že ju vypnú aj najskalnejší fanúšikovia! Hra nemá takmer žiadny dej a len veľmi málo vedľajších interakcií.
Hra nie je drahá a nemá veľa DLC-čiek, ale zbytočne tlačí do kúpy spojených obsahov ako napr. zakúpenie zberateľskej kolekcie. Aj keď nejde o zlú hru, jej kúpu neodporúčam, pretože v dnešnej dobe už nespĺňa náročné požiadavky hernej komunity na tento druh hier.

If you want to learn the game, skip the tutorial (which I found to be confusing), and watch a few YouTube videos on How to Play Master of Orion: Conquer the Stars. Then start a game at the Very Easy level, and exclude playing with Pirates (turn that option Off); exclude random events (set to Off); and exclude Space Monsters (again, set to Off in Options). Once you start actually playing thus, you will find the game enjoyable and engrossing. It has all the charm of the original MOO, plus the extras that you find in MOO2. I just love picking and choosing research paths through the Research Tree. I am still learning to play this latest iteration of the classic game series, and when I feel ready then I will begin a more competitive game with all Options turned back on. I will try to write a further review later, after I have experienced more that the game has to offer. So far, I like it (e.g. the space map is pretty, if not beautiful; and the close ups of the Planets are nice and give more than adequate information about population, production and research in an easily accessible way). So, go ahead and give this game a try.

I love Moo1&2, and was hoping for a reboot like Star Control's. While MOO:CTS has most of the features you'd want from a MOO sequel, it sadly gets flooded with micromanaging many little details that get to be a chore. Managing the population allocation and the build queue is fine for a couple of planets, but gets to be a tedious grind when you get 15 and painful for large maps. Same with managing troop transports, and moving excess population around from fuller planets to newer colonies. Previous MOO games had these problems too, but after 20 years you'd expect some fixes to these problems which other games have done. The combat is pretty meh, and the spaceship tech tree is pretty boring until you get way into late game (in which case the game is largely decided by then). It is just too much work for a game.

The graphics and cutscenes are great, it's just too bad they didn't put that effort into making it fun before making it pretty.

I let it run for an hour, because the shields kept regenerating and the station started to get minor damage. I had to exit it. 

Basically, don't buy it. Even on sale.

Meh, I liked it at first and think it was well put together...and this one is 45/55 for me. It just crossed into don't recommend territory because of the following...and this is based on comparison to the dozens of 4X, turn based space games etc I own.

1: The AI is really dumb. All seem to speed build massive fleets and every time I am leaps and bounds ahead in technology, one race seems to suddenly gain EVERYTHING in the tree when they had been behind me 100 turns before. 

2: On very easy setting, there is always one race that sweeps through the galaxy with titan ships while I am still researching cruisers. I have yet to have a game where I see some advanced tech. I even modded my own version of the game...which brings me to #3.

3: ALL races use the same tech trees. The only differences are visual and the race traits...I found this when I was going through the mod files. It killed the game for me as it made everything seem the same.... 

4: Again, it started off fun...but by turn 300 or so and spamming tech and planet colonies, I was always WAY behind the rest of the galaxy. Other 4X games I don't have this issue.

5: Can't name fleets.... 

6: Would be nice to auto-turn.

Great 4X game. Scratches the itch. Wonderful AI, and amazing difficulty settings. The Diplomacy here is absolutely the best of any 4X game that I have played. The combat is also my favorite. It can do a great job, but if you want to tinker you can get a great advantage.

Honestly I DO enjoy this game. 
The Space Combat is definitely what I keep playing it for. 
Building all the new ships and the different combinations is fairly fun. 

However it is a fairly bare bones civilization building game. The visuals are certainly a good reason to play this. but, it's lacking the depth I wish was there. 
I find it to be a very unpolished game. And it's a shame since it's coat is so pretty. 
I bought the special edition, (which includes the original Trilogy) and even the DLC for this game. 

After you've explored what the game has to offer, the replay value falls off. 
I put in an extraordinary amount of hours after purchasing. (Had plenty of time after getting COVID) I was absolutely captivated. The Voice acting, The Lore (What little their is in Game), The Menu's and sounds/music. It all looks fantastic. The Large Battles are truly fun! The Designs and art style is rather superb! 

I got my money's worth. I'm more disappointed how little the game has to offer after it's initial learning curve.
The mechanics are rather shallow after you've figured everything out and played a few matches. 
Very good Ideas, I'm hoping the previous games, (While certainly not as visually appealing) have the depth I was hoping for.

I enjoyed:
- Revival of the races of games that I used to play in older games
- Difficulty at the highest rating -> early game

What seems bad:
- Technological progression - There are some points in the game where your power level just jumps to unreasonable levels. Most notably are the increased income (Galactic currency exchange +100% wealth) it's really hard to not accidentally get an econ victory. There is not a smooth transition at any point where it's a steady progression of technology. The power gained by a very few of them is crazy and can go from a losing situation to domination.
- Victory Conditions - Technology pretty much gives you access to all win conditions, some win conditions are completely unattainable. A conquest victory, for example, will always end in a diplomatic victory unless you keep on not voting for yourself in the galactic council. At that point anyway, when you are that large you would win anyway.
- Almost all enemies just mass a single fleet to fight, there's no attacking multiple fronts it's very basic. The game further rewards this with anti-missile defenses stacking, so the more ships you have the less missile damage you take, so it's better to have less fleets all the time.
- Game handles late game very poorly, I am not sure if this is an optimisation issue but turns start taking a long time around the point where you get 60 planets. I would actually suggest against playing the massive galaxies.

I would recommend this game only if you are looking for a bit of nostalgia with the older series, the ships are quite neat too. If you are looking for a 4X game, I would definitely suggest looking elsewhere as this is a generic entry level type.

its a complex and yet simple fun space exploration strategy game that is fun to play with others that have it. each game takes a really long time though. but i like that each person can kinda go there own way about doing things with research and weapons  and tech. most of the time no is running the same set up by turn 50 which makes things really interesting. If you want a strategy game that is in depth, and yet still fun to play by yourself or others look no further.  solid 7.5 out of 10

Such a fun turn-based strategy game. I'm not really a strategy game player for the most part, As my steam library will tell you, I prefer rpgs, survival, and team horror. That being said, I ADORE space and the simplicity of this game combined with a fun adventure into the cosmos with lovely art and endearing alien species made it a wonderful experience. Truly, if you're new to strategy games I would give this one a go. It's easy enough to learn while still being fun and challenging enough to warrant many playthroughs. If you're more experienced with strategy games I might suggest passing this one by and moving onto something like Stellaris. However, I will say, my brother has played probably 20 hours of this with me and he tends to prefer more complex strategy games but still enjoyed the game.

Great remake that feels true to the spirit of the originals.  The game feels very MoO, with elements of Civilization thrown in.  May purchase DLC in future after many playthroughs.
Combat can be complex, easy, or super easy let the AI do an instant battle.  Letting the AI do the battles feels like you win according to the predictions, not like some RNG games.  Multiple win conditions (Military, Economic, Technological, Diplomatic via the galactic council, Eliminate the Antarrans (technology/military), or good old fashioned Points after a # of turns.  Great voice acting.  Great animation, racial specific fleet looks.  Diplomacy is midway between MoO and Civ, which feels good for the most part.  Ship building can be made very easy or pretty complex, even to the point of assigning ships different roles such as sniper or brawler.  AI recommends upgrades by roll and you are prompted to tweak blueprints every time you get an upgrade, so you can't forget.   Many buildings and technologies have changed in function, as have many racial abilities.  Have not played through all races, but the new racial abilities have still felt "right" so far.  Most of the base races are included in the base game, plus a second human race, a few are $DLC.  Planets and building feel mostly like MoO2, not the overcomplicated system of 3.  Evidently friendly to the MOD community (not a selling point for me, but maybe for others.  Very helpful community on the community page.  Developers still involved in game, which is mainly a plus.
Few downsides:  Buying some of the "core" races.  Help menu not in game.  Evidently can be found on Steam under launch options.  Just like Civ, some of the unfamiliar terms are never explained in game that I have found.  Tutorial needs polishing, there are times it hints at the next step, but it is unclear the next thing to do, so you have to click every interface, button, planet, ship until you get where the tutorial wanted you next.  Some of the buildings/technologies that have had their purpose changed feel wrong, some feel unnecessary.  If I colonize a mineral poor-ultra poor, I know it is going to be a weak industry, I shouldn't be able to "fix" the planet by just 'building' Crust Prospecting.  Pollution feels weird, but is relatively easy to figure out.  I suspect I will find the sweet spot in multiple play throughs.  Food system is not obvious once you go beyond the base needs of feeding planet.  Transporting colonists is a lot more annoying, but realistic.  Developers still involved in tweaking game does mean that your favorite features could be tweaked away at some point.
Edit:  Changed info about help menu, reinforced that Developers are still active with tweaking game.

TL:DR - Terrible game. Get Endless Space 2 instead. It does EVERYTHING you probably wanted from this game and then some. 

If Wargming recreated Master of Orion 2 mechanics and added tactical combat, then maybe this would have worked.
Instead, the developers that gave us World of Tanks, World of Warships, and World of Warplanes have given us a Master of Orion game where tanks are infantry with a different icon, the starships 'fight' about as awkwardly as a teenage couple dancing at a Catholic School prom and the end result is about as clumsy as the aforementioned couple trying to deflower each other in the back of a car with a messy, cringey, and guilt-ridden shag, and starfighters are as useful as an ejection seat on a submarine. 

Now about 2 years after release, where do I even start... 
- AI doesn't build any warships. They s*** out nothing but troop transports that just orbit around their homeworld. No joke, don't be surprised to send your battlefleet over to the Bulrathi, Sakkra, and Klackon homeworlds without running into a single enemy vessel and then encounter a fleet of several hundred troop transports. I think the AI thinks they are playing Starship Troopers. YOU CAN TAKE OVER THE GALAXY WITH A HANDFUL OF FRIGATES.
- Even if the AI do build warships, the ship designs they use are so god awful that you can take out Titans with a few frigates in an auto-resolve battle. THE AI SHARE THE EXACT SAME SHIP BLUEPRINTS, BASED ON A SINGLE F***ING TEXT FILE. YEAH! THE SAKKRA, MRRSHAN, MEKLAR, ALKARI, HUMANS... ALL OF THESE EXTREMELY 'DIVERSE' CIVILZIATIONS OUTFIT THEIR SHIPS IN THE EXACT SAME WAY. YOU CAN TAKE OVER THE GALAXY WITH A HANDFUL OF FRIGATES.
- Diplomacy? What diplomacy? "Would you be interested in a trade agrement with England?" YOU CAN TAKE OVER THE GALAXY WITH A HANDFUL OF FRIGATES.
- Espionage involves more RNG than tabletop D&D and more nonsensical and unfair BS than XCOM aiming. YOU CAN TAKE OVER THE GALAXY WITH A HANDFUL OF FRIGATES.
- The AI in this game would have a hard time beating Halo Wars on normal. Wargaming took the AI algorithms from the AI the Galactic Empire used to run their wars. Or they stole it from the 12 Colonies of Man. Take your pick because it makes as many monumentally bad decisions as those two. I have seen Psilons (good thing WG is Belarusian so they can't be sued for trademark infringement) the super sciency types get their homeworld wiped out because they couldn't finish the research project to stop their sun from going Supernova... I managed this feat consistently with the KLACKONS just by moving some pops around. YOU CAN TAKE OVER THE GALAXY WITH A HANDFUL OF FRIGATES.

Now, go take over the galaxy with a handful of frigates. 2/10 don't buy this game. Go buy Endless Space 2 for a taste of Master of Orion.
Does not try to be anything else than a modern version of MOO2. If you liked MOO2, you will like this.

I thought about writing a very long and in depth review, but instead ill keep it simple and compare it to another of my favorite games.  If you've ever played Stellaris by Paradox Interactive, and thought "I love this game, but sometimes it's a little too much for a casual gaming session."  Then MOO is for you.

The concept of grand 4x space gameplay is here, and it's just deep enough to be engaging without being overwhelming.  This is the perfect game for me to play while the kids are in the next room, or you're 'watching' netflix, or just in general have your attention split.

This is one of the best Orion games (actually each of them is the best) and the best space 4X game I have seen. A mix of the best features of Orion 1, 2 and 3 in a modern setting. We have Orion 1 mood and feel with Orion 2 commanders, Antarans, research, ground combat and Orion 3 space battles with more meaningful tactics. And it was made by Wargaming (yes, World of Tanks, you guessed it right).
That there are space lanes - in my opinion it is even better - your empires are more consistent. And all other space strategies have space lanes.
And if you complain about Antarans attacking your new colonies... well, send them a touching letter. Wake up their ancestral empathy. Maybe before they finish reading, they start crying and show you some mercy. Or die laughing...
Antaran DLC with Elerians and other races is very nice. And there are also mods.

TOTALLY BROKEN: this http://forum.masteroforion.com/index.php?/topic/867-total-game-breaking-bug-disappearing-ships/ still happens.  This was reported 5 years ago, it's not fixed, it's a game breaker Priority Critical bug.  This happens very rarely, so it's likely a race condition or a variable that in a buffer that can be overwritten, and I've never seen it happen during the first 100 rounds.

My review isn't because the game is bad. It's because it's extremely unbalanced with the Antares race appearing way too early and just obliterating you, especially if you decide to start pre-warp as a civilization. Strangely enough, the original had this same problem, which meant that if you were lucky and the Antares' race didn't decimate you early, you became overpowered and could devastate them. But it's one of those either/or balance things that really makes each game feel badly designed.

The rest of the game is done really well. If they could have set-up a system to where you could turn off Antares, or made them less likely to just start attacking you out of nowhere when you're still trying to figure out how to grow seeds (or whatever tech you're on), it might have been one of those games you'd play over and over. Instead, I played it over and over, just trying to get to a point where I could lead to a state where the end game seems possible.

its mad dope

An unworthy succession to a great older 4X franchise, with some nice animated graphics.

The 'ascension' or victory by research feature addition means the AI always wins on a clock cycle and the game ends with the winner being the first race to reach the end of the tech tree.  Usually this occurs right in the middle of the most sophisticated endgame conquest and diplomacy portions of the game. It ruins the entire concept here. The Galactic council never votes, politics is near meaningless, conquest victory is impossible, the game ends before a deathstar can be constructed or used...  Just a big banner every match:

500 turns: AI WINS

Or you do, if you win the tech race.

The entire game reduces to this one algorithm. Fun maybe twice, zero replay.

Sadly the tactical combat is also completely bugged, the camera auto centers snapping back from the focus you scroll to, ships do not obey orders, ships do not fire on targets ordered to, ships forget the targets assigned, and at scale, the battles crash and lock.  Individual ships can't even be selected and commands just cannot be issued. It becomes impossible to fight protracted battles, use any kind of tactics or special ship equipment, and all the space battles are reduced to production pawn trades.

This relegates the player to use of auto admiral and auto resolve simulation for the best parts of the hi tech fleet battles, completely trimming off what is teased as one of the best parts of this game.

Fails at the concept, trite and disappointing.

[b]Bottomline:[/b] Want a nice looking 4X with cool characters and eyecandy, where you spend most of your time doing "emperor" stuff? Get this one.
Want a babysitter / accountant simulator where you spend 80% of your time looking at numbers, and all you actually do is change those numbers? Then steer WAY clear of this one!

The game is complex enough to feel like a "real" 4X. Yet simple enough to allow me to concentrate on grand strategy, wich sectors to colonize, diplomacy, warfare, you know, 4X stuff! instead of spending 80% of the time burried in spreadsheets looking at numbers.
In other words, you feel like the leader of an empire, not an accountant.

Another aspect of the game i really like, is that every race/faction is really and [b]visually[/b] unique. With completely different looks, animations, voices (they actually talk here), behaviour, ships, etc. In contrast to other 4X games where besides the single picture of the race, you need to go look at a bunch of numbers to see how they are different.

The visuals are nice, voice acting in excellent, music is good, the map is nice. The UI is simple but functional.

I also adore the fact that here you can actually do whatever the hell you want. Wanna go to war? go for it! no need for hours of building pre-requisites. Want to design new ships? sure! no need for a level of "experience", etc. 
I also like that for me the game strikes a good balance between micro and macro management. 

It does have a few bugs, but none that "break" the game imho. And even still there is the "Unoficial Code patch" (UCP) available on the workshop that corrects most of the bugs.

For a 4x conquer game, this game has an incredible backstory and an amazing tech tree.  I wish the tactical battles were as strategic as MOO 2, but they are infinitely cooler to watch.  This is so addicting!  I can't stop playing it!
This game was amazing. In a couple of days i racked up 40+ hours of gameplay. Such a fun game it is worth the price. Getting the extra packs is awesome too. Buy it if you have not yet

Precondition: I played only MOO2 before this game, and even I'm not a big fan of it, I played more than 100 hours in my childhood. 

Another note: I used other reviewer recommendation and installed mods from the start (played half an hour unmodded): 
-5X - The Ultimate Balance Mod
-Unofficial Code Patch
-5X UCP Compatibility Mod (5XCPC)
Game is supported by the community, so keep track on mods update. They done pretty well. They do not change game noticeably, but just a lot of QoL, balance and stability.
(to install just find them in Steam Workshop, press "subscribe". also follow instructions for UCP. for reorder - in game go to mods section and press arrows (sadly no clear instructions on that)). 

So, main part now, what I found good compared to Moo2:
- Diplomacy I feel somewhat better. And AI have stronger demand, no just demanding system for nothing
- Spy system is much richier and deeper too. 
- Planets have more "unique perks" that gave little bonuses (strongly recommend taking look at DSMP mod which bring even more specials). 
- In tech tree you see technologies which require making choice, and tech that are granted by default. And choices is like 2 times less tha in MOO2 (sounds bad, but for balance sake I feel it like good decision)
- more Custom Race perks;
- More generation options for Galaxy; 
- Different win conditions (conquer, economy, science, Senate voting, etc), which are customiseable.
- Tactical combat is always on, and you could auto-combat any battle (without actually run in tactical view!). God bless this auto-combat. 


Questionable decisions (I'm ok with them, but MOO2 fan may find them annoying):
- You can't move between any star systems. Fuel system is removed. You move only between stars that connected by galaxy generator. You could travel between any stars if you build warp gates in controlled systems, and that is not one-turn either (same linear distance/drive power calc).
- You need to move fleet between planets and "warp points" of star system and that takes 1 turn.
- Tech tree now has partially interconnected branches instead of 8 independent. You can install mod which try to address that, but fix is not even close to MOO2 system. 
- Antarans feels for me annoying as a hell on Warp and Pre-warp.  Maybe with Progressive sciense start they will be ok. (played only twice with them so not placing ino annoying part - you could just disable them)
- Research overall feel waaay too slower (even with "fastest researh" on game start tuning). I felt like research speed comparable on fastest res game setting and race with 60% res bonus. Maybe because there more res. stages itself.

(Steam limits review to 8000 character, read 1 comment for the rest)

I'm revising my review to say that I tentatively recommend the game to people who are looking for something close to MoO2. For some reason 4X space games these days tend to be in real-time, which doesn't make sense to me. A game like this should be turn-based, and unlike some of the other 4X games floating around you can actually control combat.

There are some issues with this though, and overall MoO 2 is a better game. What this game needed to do is make some small changes and update the graphics and interface, but a lot of what they changed feels kind of shallow. I can't quite put my finger on it but the game is just missing something.

The custom race options are a bit...off. One change they made I actually really like is to reduce the effectiveness of the Creative perk by having fewer either/or tech choices, but the price of a race being creative is still high. To be fair it also includes a high bonus to research, but since it's the same bonus you can purchase independently I'd rather have the option to JUST get all tech options.

They do that a lot in this game, many of the traits are just combinations of cheaper ones, it just feels weird. There are a few new, unique traits that definitely add something, but the government portion is gone and something valuable is lost as a result.

The game is visually appealing in general, not mind-blowing, but definitely not ugly. I wound up turning the sound off and don't really miss it.

To me this is a good 4X space game if you don't want the complexity of something like Galactic Civilizations 2/3 but still want to do some empire building. I would be really interested to see if they build on this.

True to it's origins, for the most part. While I'll never be a fan of the whole terrain in space nonsense, I can understand how it creates a scenario where you don't have sprawling undefeatable player empires all the time.

I was hoping for a spiritual successor to Master of Orion 2 that captured the magic of grand space battles with some modern game design quality of life improvements, but instead found a watered-down 4X where visual appeal clearly took precedence over playability.

Master of Orion 2 forced hard choices on the player and made various strategies required, depending on your focus. The tech tree allowed only one choice per node, and while some were obvious, the benefits of the option not chosen couldn't be ignored; thus, stealing tech from your neighbors was encouraged to close the gap in power between you.

Ship design was a core mechanic of MoO2 where the choices you made dramatically affected your ships' performance in epic space combat. Both the epic space combat and the ship design are moot; most battles are resolved with auto battle, and the real time aspect makes control annoying, so you just hand it over to the AI anyway and watch as your ships make some bone-headed choices that could even cost you the battle. There's also a "best" ship design at each tier. Of course, the auto-upgrade variants sometimes decrease your ships' stats, which just doesn't make sense. It's like the numbers are pointless.

Colony management is a nuisance. It wasn't great in MoO2 but at least I could ship pops between planets without spending several turns worth of production! Now, you can't even build freighters to deal with food-poor planets, and need an early-ish tech to make your third colony survivable if it's not on a food bearing planet. Interplanetary administration isn't a valid replacement, since it only applies within a system.

There are plenty of other mechanics I disliked, but the biggest issues are those above. Stellaris, for all its faults, did it better. And I wasn't a huge fan of Stellaris' overly complicated mechanics.

Back in 1993, I played this turn-based strategy game called Master of Orion.  I thought it was great and had never played such a game.  I was quickly a fan.  Three years later, its sequel came out.  Master of Orion 2: Battle at Antares was even better with improved gameplay and graphics.  There were over a dozen races to choose from with unique traits to determine your play style, or you could make your own race.  Needless to say, I logged hundreds if not thousands of hours playing this game.  Then there was nothing for several years until Master of Orion 3 came out in 2003.  We won’t talk about that game.  I feared the series was done until I stumbled upon Master of Orion: Conquer the Stars.  I did not know what to expect given how bad the 3rd installment was, so I was hesitant to give it a chance.  Whether you are a fan of the original series or new to the series/genre, you will not be disappointed.  

For fans of the original games, you will immediately see similarities to Master of Orion 2. All of the races from the second game are back.  The available technology is also similar with some additions.  You can expect many of the same features of MoO 2, with cleaner graphics and better AI for the races.  This means your allies won’t be as erratic as they could be in the original game.  The gameplay will also be familiar with some upgrades, such as the paths to victory.

The goal of the game is to win, obviously, but there are several ways to earn that victory.  Technologic, diplomatic, economic, conquest, or just being the best overall with the excellence victory.  Which path you choose will likely be determined by the race you choose, since each race has unique traits that will give them an edge on specific paths.  That does not mean that you can’t choose conquest victory as the Psilons.  After all, their technological advantage can just as easily be used to annihilate your enemies as it can be used to earn a technology win.

There are 14 races to choose from.  As I mentioned each one has different stats and traits.  Definitely consider these to give yourself an advantage in their strengths early.  The developers put a good amount of effort into making each one as unique as possible.  You will probably find yourself playing this game over and over as each of the races.  If you prefer, you can also make your own race.  You choose one of the existing races for the skin, and then select from a list of advantages and disadvantages.  You can also use the custom race option to ensure you don’t have deal with any race that is particularly troublesome.  

For the full review and others check out https://corillium-vgr.blogspot.com/

I played the original MOO back in the day and still load it up on Dos Box from time to time. When I saw this new version I was very excited. Then I played it and found endless frustration at having manage every single little detail of what my colonies were building.  In the original game you divided up you production points to research, population growth, missile base construction, or Ship construction. This version expands that to so many endless buildings that I never felt I could enjoy the game of exploring new solar systems and building up my colonies and fleet of ships to attack my neighbors with. Heck even to get to the point to where you can build the large battleship class ships you have to go through an exhaustive research tree. The original Orion had all ship classes available to you from the outset, then it was up to you to outfit them and develop better weapons to do it with.  This game falls so much shorter than what the original accomplished with less impressive graphics. What a shame.

I was really hot for this game when I heard about it, having played the original 2 games on release (and bought and tried the 3rd game which turned out to be a screensaver at best).  I bought the super deluxe collectors edition with the original series of games, the digital artbook, the soundtrack, etc..  There were some vid problems at first, probably caused by my machine being 7 years old at the time of the games release.  But they did regular updates and this problem was greatly alleviated, though not eliminated.  In fact, I was playing it pretty steady from about early September, 2016 to mid-December, 2016.  At that point they had an update, and they made the last three races and the Antarans available as DOWNLOADABLE CONTENT.  I wouldn't have minded this, but they wanted me to pay for it.  WHAT THE FUCK?  I paid for the full deluxe edition of the game in pre-release and I have to pay MORE to get the finished version of the game?  No, I will NOT!!!!  So at this time, I have not played this excrement for probably 2 weeks or so.  I will not play it again until the DLC becomes free.  I recommend everyone stay away until this issue is resolved.  I'm not the only one complaining about this.  I'm sure they know of our displeasure by now.  ************************************* UPDATE ************  Well they had the DLC cheap during a summer sale at some point so I went ahead and got it.  I've played the game and it is playable.  All the bugs seem to have been more or less worked out.  So I've changed it from a negative recommendation, to a positive recommendation.  I have been playing other games more than MOO, but I still have it and will get back to it unless I have a heart attack and die.  Or Covid-19 gets me.  Still not happy I had to spend a few extra bucks for the final 3 races, but what the hell?!?!?!  RIGHT?!?!?!  Play it, or don't.  Better graphics than the original MoO2 which it most closely emulates, and it does have entertainment value.

MOO1 and MOO2 were among my favourite games as a kid.  I don't remember them well enough to say how this new MOO compares apples to apples, but in a way that doesn't matter.  Gaming has moved since MOO and MOO2 came out, and what was great back then would not necessarily be great if it were released now.

As it stands, this new MOO lacks content.  Having played through the game once, I feel like I've seen and experienced everything it has to offer.  There's no different path I saw that I thought, "next time I could try that".  No different abilities unique to other races that leave me thinking they would be interesting enough to try.  No different aspects of galactic exploration or exploitation that I noticed and could aim for on a new play through.  It will just be the same as my first play through, with slight tweaks.  I can already see what the game will be, how it will play out (and if I'm wrong, then the game did not communicate that at all).

For what it's worth, I did find that one single play through entertaining enough.  I don't expect a game like this to compare with the depth of, say, Stellaris.  However, I would have liked more depth, more variety of play styles to experience something new.
Every bit as good as the first version! Excellent graphics and cut scenes. This game would easily adapt to a tablet. I hope that happens someday.

Negative:

To play all races you need DLCs.

Space combat - even when you click on "no AI - 100% control" your ships just do what they want, start firing here and there and move despite you saying hold position, very annoying.

Space news - make fun of the whole lore, diminishes the overall thrill of the game. You can turn them off but then you miss some useful information.

UI - several unnecessary repetitive clicks when micromanaging. Can I click on this planet as hyperlink to go there? No, first go to F1, Empire management, search the planet click on it.

When you click on "fleet needs orders" the camera always completely zooms in, so you have to zoom out to see where to send it EVERY SINGLE TIME.

Your ships can't do interstellar space travel outside of star lanes (what I wouldn't mind) EXCEPT for mini missions when they get a signal from somewhere out there, THEN THEY CAN and often get close to another star but can't do that one more inch to explore that star, what a dumb concept.

Overall this game is just a full priced beta, they simply didn't finish it. Play MoO2 instead, trust me. I mean even when you invade a colony with troops you don't see ANYTHING except of a message, so unrewarding.

I regret this purchase even though I just bought it to get the summer sale discount.

Review Update:

I decided to give Master of Orion 4 another go. 
Heh.. it's still hard to call it that, they should've given it another name.

This time I'm using a mod called "5X - The Ultimate Balance Mod" by Spud Dastardly.
The mod makes the game notably better.

The races are now more like in Master of Orion 2, and the custom race editor is much better now - It's fun to tinker with. 

There's also techs that make planetary specials better. (they were pretty useless before)


Now that I've tried it, I think the only "real" way to play this game is with this mod.

Too bad the biggest flaw of the game - namely the absolutely awful combat, is still there.
And the game is quite poorly optimized to be honest; it's not that good looking and it slows
down alot after you hit the 500 turn mark, and lategame combat also gets hiccups. 

It's a good game, but it's not great. (At least it's better than Master of Orion 3.. haha)

============

Old Review:

This game is [b]not[/b] Master of Orion.
It should not be called that. They changed the game so much that they should've just named it differently.
Yes, I am one of those who played the original games years ago.

Ok, so it is not Master of Orion, but it is an okay 4X space strategy.

This game feels more like a combination of Endless Space and Galactic Civilizations, with a very dull real-time combat where you cannot change the outcome much. Doesn't matter if you just watch the battle or command the ships yourself. 

Now, the real-time combat can be done right. For example StarDrive 2 has significantly better real-time combat where you can actually change the tide of battle by moving the ships smart. Even Endless Spaces' autocombat system feels better than this.

So yes, this is the biggest problem for me with the game. It lacks the turn-based combat that made the original two Master of Orions so great, and it does the real-time combat all wrong. I can handle the changes in the travel system (star lanes like Endless Space) or the (way too) slow game pace, and the tedious espionage system. But the combat system is just.. meh.

However, I do like the game. The poor combat system does not kill ALL the fun for me. I enjoy the colonizing & research phase of the game.

If you like Endless Space, then you should get this game on sale. I do not think this game is worth its full price, but on sale? Definitely.

It's OK, but it's not great. And it's definitely not Master of Orion.

They had the budget to hire well known voice actors; why didn't they hire Steve Barcia and Ken Burd to oversee the project? Maybe next time.

I have loved the MOO series from the start.  I was not a fan when they shifted the combat from turn based to command overview, at first it seemed...  cheesy.  But the way they carried the heart of the game is still there.  I love the ability to create custom races.  The various races and ship designs are also great.  AI is still has hard as ever.  Voice acting is great and adds a good flavor to the game (though as in the original, sometimes the amount of GNN reports gets in the way, but I just skip them).  Solid progression in Tech, Building, exploration and conquest.

If you are a fan of 4X games, this is it!

Compared to it's peers - I've seen other people claim this is a "junior" 4x game.  I find that a bit unfair.  This game seems to strike a good balance of learning curve vs. playability.  There are more complicated 4x games out there, and their leaning curve is quite high.  In comparison, I watched several hours of videos trying to learn Stellaris.  When a person making the Stellaris video says something like, "this game isn't friendly to new players" that tells me that maybe the time investment to learn the game is a bit high.  This game seems more "fun" and still provides a challenge and a reasonable learning curve.
As a stand alone game - Master of Orion has good graphics and music, and the voice acting is even better.  The list of voice actors is impressive.  It includes Alan Tudyk, Mark Hammill, Michael Dorn, John De Lancie and Robert Englund to name a few.  The interface feels polished and uncluttered.  Perhaps most importantly, within 2 hours, I was having fun instead of feeling frustrated.  Obviously, with only 6 hours under my belt at the time of this review, I've not experienced the whole game (it does take a while), but I'm looking forward to the next 6 hours instead of dreading it as with some other 4x games.  I don't regret the purchase, and I can't say that for some of the other 4x games in my library.
Excellent game
Awesome modernization of MOO2.  They added a lot of great quality of life features I've enjoyed.  I've owned the game 5 days and already have 57 hours played!
Solid single player game play.  Not quite as riveting as Civilization series, but good.  Brings back memories of classic MOO without the clunky graphics.

Fun game, brings back some ooold memories. It's your typical 4X affair, with a simpler map. If I had to point out one big flaw, the tutorial teaches you almost nothing about the game. It highlights a few buttons, gives you tiny bits of information and then sends you on your way. There's no accompanying "Civopedia" that I could see, so the learning curve is considerably steeper in that regard. I struggled to understand the victory mechanics until it was far too late in my first game. A solid in-game reference would turn a good game into a great game.

This is a wonferful fresh take on a magical classic. It seems they used the Civ V game engine to build this on, and we see many of the mechanics and interface elements being inherited from civ. What we have then is basically a remake of MOO2 on top of Civ, and that's a fun mix.

The game unfortunately feels unfinished, with many bugs and unpolished features in the basr package. Fortunately, two wonderful mods were published that address this and transform the game into what it really should be (5X mod, UCP mod). With these two, the game is a great piece of work, with tremendous depth and replayability.

This is the best game I've played in years, I'm psyched to have discovered it at this stage where mods make it as complete as it deserves to be.

This is a buggy, annoying game, that could have been great, but it's not.

When I first played it the tutorial was completely broken by design, in that it wants you to follow a specific path, and won't let you even quit it until it's done. At one point when playing it I got completely confused as to what to do because it told me to settle a planet that the game told me not to settle.
No way I am playing through the tutorial again to confirm it's still broken though. It was horrible.
The entire time I was TRYING to play through the tutorial, and getting extremely aggravated, the voice of the tip adviser kept going off, saying things like "Excuse me, Mr President." There are even more of these alerts than during normal game play. If it was not possible to turn off voices, I may not have continued to play. I have not become so aggravated with a game for as long as I can remember.
It's not actually a tutorial, as you simply follow the instructions, with little or no choice in your actions. You're better watching a video. It's way less aggravating.

I myself was a big fan of Master of Orion 2, and MoO 3, to a lesser degree. I didn't dislike Master of Orion 3 because it didn't live up to the previous game. There were things in both games I disliked, but there were a few things I liked better about MoO 2.

This game not only doesn't live up to the previous installments, but it's buggy, and makes a few changes that make the game less enjoyable. The designers seem to have completely abandoned it as well, which I think was a huge mistake. This game is ripe for DLC & online play, IF they fixed it, and continued to work on it.

Cons:
