This game is not all bad. If you have a kid that likes sci-fi and you want to introduce him to 4X games, this might be a good choice. The graphics are remarkable, and they have an all star cast of voice-overs. Because the game-play is a bit lacking though, all the fancy graphics and voices just felt like shine to me.

This game wasn't ready to come out of Early Access when it did, and they abandoned it. They have a very fancy start to a good game, with a few poor choices that nearly cripple it.

Even after years they haven't fixed anything it seems. It's really just boring and dull.

Most of your time will be spent choosing the next thing to build. The auto-build also disables itself any time you add something to the queue. It feels like you're micro-managing through much of the game. It gets really boring.

After years of owning the game, I have never played through an entire game. Rarely I'll open it again and try it out. Now I've simply uninstalled it to save the space.

The page to manage multiple colonies at once, the "Empire" tab, is crippled, so you're constantly going through every planet, which is annoying.

The research suggestions however, are one of the best changes they made, and really help speed up your choices in research.

The auto-turn is also very poorly designed, and it can blaze past important things, including hostile forces. It only stops when you NEED to do something, so you have to keep your mouse hovered over the button.

The ship combat AI is a pain. Trying to control a fleet with a mouse sucks, so you'll likely just click to auto resolve it most times.

One of the things that is very subjective that I disliked is the races. They're a bit too heavily modeled after real animals. Some of the choices seem straight out of a kids movie.

There's also DLC races available. I think their presentation was a mistake. I would have preferred a button to get additional races. As it is, it just makes the game look incomplete, unless you pay more.

The GNN news updates are just plain stupid. In previous games they were a little silly, but nowhere near as bad as they are now. At one point, when talking about a population boom, the male robot actually asks "You do know where babies come from, don't you?" Seriously? 

The whole game has a very cartoonie and kiddish feel to it.

The research tiers are almost exactly the same as from previous games. They likely just copied them and made some minor alterations. Some of the alterations are nice, others not so much. It would have been nice if they had further expansion, and not gotten rid of the previous colony base.

Not having a colony base that allows you to easily and cheaply settle colonies in the same star system makes the game far harder for no logical reason. You would not build a full colony ship that's capable of traveling to other stars to go to the moon.

This game was released before it was ready, and abandoned. The production company should be ashamed.

I dearly wanted this game to be good. It has a lot of things going for it: it's using the name of the series with the best 4x game ever made, it was made over twenty years after that title, and it doesn't call itself "MoO 4" out of respect that no one will acknowledge that the abortion of a game called MoO 3 even exists. But it isn't good. They reinvented every wheel, and it's poor.

They hired big-name sci-fi voice actors for this. That's cool and all; much love for Mark Hamill, Michael Dorn, and John DeLancie, their characters are fond parts of my childhood. But no offense to them, this game just doesn't need them and doesn't use them properly. I'm certain they didn't do their work pro-bono (nor should they be expected to), so that's money that could have been used to buy the developers copies of MoO 2 and have them actually play it. 

The interface in MoO 2 was excellent in every regard; buttons and choices were unobstrusive and intuitive. And if you weren't certain, you could right-click on any button in MoO 2 and a detailed tooltip would pop up. The interface in this game feels like it was made for consoles; big blocky buttons with big ugly pictures on half of them, and the rest try to be minimalist and fail at their actual purpose. Rather than having a list of the names of buildings you can build on a planet like you did in MoO 2, now every building has a huge clunky 3d model under its name taking up most of the space in the list, and the buildings barely look like anything distinct or even related to what they are. 

Movement is restricted to hyperlanes, the same method that the developers of Stellaris eventually forced their players to use because they couldn't figure out how to make any other movement system work. It is lazy, it is boring, it is limiting, and - given the degree of freedom present in MoO 2 - it is insulting. 

I could go on and on about how bad this game is in comparison to MoO 2, but it's bad for my blood pressure. Luckily I still have my original MoO 2 disc, heck I played it just a few months ago before I even got the reboot. This game isn't so bad that the fans will deny its very existence like MoO 3, but it still has no reason to use the Master of Orion name.

Master of Orion is a beautiful game. It is filled with stunning visuals and professional voice acting. I have yet to encounter a game that's a tenth this well presented.

The problem is that the lack of strategic options, particularly in the early game. You spend far too many turns going "Can I do anything? No? Okay, I'll hit the end turn button then." You never have to deal with internal politics or trade lanes. In MoO, an absolutely amazing system might have five planets, and a couple of gas giants or asteroid belts for your space miner to work on. In contrast, in Civilization IV, a single city might have eight tiles around it for you to make decisions about- assuming it hadn't expanded its culture, in which case there would be twenty. In GalCiv2, ethical decisions crop up virtually every time you settle a planet and punctuate the time afterwards. There's simply more to do in those games compared to MoO.

An interesting game, but there's several problems with MOO3. I have always thought that the game cheats, you just cannot produce the number of ships and buildings in early game as the NPCs do, but they do. 

Most of the mods do not work (ie make the game freeze) so check them out carefully. 

The other complete disappoint is fighting the Antarans, it's just a mass battle, you build up this fleet for 200 turns and then after the battle, there's a very short sequence, then the game just ends. MOO3 is not Mass Effect, more's the pity. There should be an Antaran planet or planets to investigate, the player is given a sequence of returning from Antar (?) with tech, but then the game ends and there's no explanation of what it is. Has a very nice and simple UI, fully voiced advisers, relatively simple blueprint system for ship building- not too many customization options (cosmetically) but nothing a mod or two can't fix. Being able to play the original races, alongside the Terran Khanate, is fantastic. I've run into 0 problems with the base game, and would definitely recommend it to those returning to the series, especially if you enjoyed Master of Orion II. For newcomers, there's plenty of settings and tutorial hints for you if needed. 

I think my only gripe with it is how difficult the Diplomacy system works, as AI will never accept a fair deal, but unless you're going for achievements specific to diplomatic victories- it's far more fun to glass the opposition.

Also you can have your leader be Mark Hamill (Alkari) or Robert Englund (Khanate).

At present I would rate this game between 3.5 stars and 4 stars.  I primarily do this because although this version is of the game is aproximately 1/2 way between MOO2 and MOO3.  If you've ever played MOO3, you remember that it was a colossal failure; whereas, its predecessor MOO2 was a smashing success.

This game kept the much of the battle system from MOO3, I preferred the tactical turn based style of MOO2 - it made more sense as far as weapon recharge time and range dissipation.  With the present system, it is very difficult to correlate what a weapon recharge rate of 2 will actually mean in combat.  The ability to assign ships to a role was present in MOO3, but also not that useful; so its appearance in this version, did not add to the game.

The return of the MOO2 races in this version is a great highlight.  I love the return to fun animations, as well as the back stories and the inclusion of how a races religious or ecological outlook affects their game choices.  Those who remember MOO3 will recall that an aspect like this was rumored to have originally been in the game, but removed prior to release.

The inclusion of space pirates, was a wonderful touch, as it brought back memories of the barbarians from the civilization series - pesky little annoyances that granted various rewards when you eliminated their home base.  I sincerely like this as it tied into other great game series.

The GNN has good humor and there are also fun jokes in the tech tree if you know were to look.

Colony management is more complicated then in MOO2, and honestly I don't like the diminishing returns for assigning multiple population units to a single task.  However, I do have to admit that, that aspect is probably more true to reality then people would like to admit.  That said, colony management is massively improved over MOO3.

I do like the idea that different races want a different planetary environment, this game touches on that without going into as much detail as MOO3.  MOO3 was just over the top on this point.  This game could have gone a little farther on this point and it would have been positive.  One thing that I don't like is the lack of description on what some racial traits mean, such as subterranean or grasslands.  What is the advantage of these if I am making a custom race?  MOO2 was simple in that subterranean meant twice the population limit for the planet.  I am unsure what it means in this game.

This review is written after only playing 38 hours of the game, so it may change as I
Maybe there are better 4x space strategy games but this game has a lot of production value.

Where the classic was a milestone in game development in its day, the new version cannot really come up with innovations. In fact, I miss some features. The game mechanics are nearly identical but technologies are missing and the limitations in ship design are just annoying.
All in all, the game is lost in the mass of 4X games. There is really nothing unique, nothing you haven´t seen before. In addition, some graphic "improvements" seem carelessly implemented. I have the impression that instead of the enthusiasts of the original, the lovers of the fast dollar were more accommodated here.
Not recommended for fans of the classic, but maybe for someone you wants to play the most basic 4X game.

Awful. Save your money. The original MOO from the nineties was better. This one is a cluenkier version of the same mechanics, races, and research as the original, with prettier graphics. It even lacks some of the functionalities such as rally points for fleets. And absolute nightmare if you want to play large galaxies.

An Extremly well made Reboot of the Master of Orion series, and I say reboot.

It primarily boosts the graphics and keeps the spirit of the original first and second game intact.

however there are things that could be better and definatly things could have gotten improved upon, but over all it is a great game.

It was fun for a while, but I do not feel the need to go back to it.

After some time it just reminded me of how much more fun playing MoO2 is. Mostly, because the remake has considerably slowed down the pace bringing the endgame to a crawl. In the time I finished one game of MoO (the remake) I could easily play through three games of MoO2.

Honestly, it's not bad. With the updates and all of the DLC installed it's basically a fancy version of Master of Orion 2. There's not much new here from Master of Orion 2 other than a few victory conditions. I would have especially liked to see more new races other than "angry humans" but the game is pretty good as it is. That said, you do really want all the DLC so you're not just stuck with the races from Master of Orion 1 as the 3 races from 2 and the new race are all DLC. It has very reasonable achievements for a 4X game if that's your thing, all but 1 can be done solo and only 1 seems to require any luck. It is also a very simple 4X game but honestly, if you want something like Master of Orion 1 or 2 this game fits that very well. Almost too well, since as I, mentioned there's really not much new. I would like to see a follow up or even more races added but I doubt that'll ever happen given how old the last update is.

If you want to get the game, get it on a big sale.

Amazing game! I used to play when I was a kid and not disappointed in the newest version. Play the tutorial or just find a Youtube video for a quick start guide. After that, just dive in and learn as you go by your adviser. The system upgrades your ships with new technology rather easily and the worker placement on each planet your colonize is easy to comprehend. I got lucky as my first game was near unstable warp points that needed technology to pass and a large eel guarding another system. Only one race contact me until towards the end during the 500 turn game. The tricky part is making sure you have enough credits to keep everything going -- sure you can build every technology you discover on a planet, but do you really *need* it. Oh and the galactic news broadcast that interrupts the game is fun and give you a break from grinding too hard!  My only warning:  its addictive, the start playing in the evening, next thing you know its 3 am and you forgot to eat dinner!

Steam had this on sale so I bought it…. 

…. And now a few things make sense…

… And now I see where a lot of really annoying mechanics and overs simplifications actually came from! I found myself repeating myself with the words “ah so YOU are responsible for this idea are you??!?!?!?!” I did this several times over the last 2 weeks where I put just over 40 hours into this game.

My first play through was one empire, picked at random the Elerians; a psychic, gender split race that seemed quite interesting from the get go. After winning through an economic victory (although at the time I was no.1 for military, technology and antarian victory conditions), I decided to continue playing to see what else I could achieve. 

I found this race to be totally overpowered and broken in two ways: 
-	Firstly, being psychic… this race doesn’t need scouts. They can see literally the whole galaxy for the entirety of the game. NOTHING is hidden, you can see every base, ship and colony without exploring them. BOOM! Military strategies can be implemented at the most opportunistic time, you’ll never have a coloniser ambushed by unexpected fleet, you’ll know where all the best, most valuable choke points and planets for colonisation are. It is basically impossible to loose playing this race. 
-	Secondly, again because this species are psychic… they don’t need to invade enemy planets, garrison them to indoctrinate or pacify the citizens or use inefficient troop transports. You see, because of their psychic trait this species can simply initiate a “mind control” attack using any ship of battleship size of larger.  

But apart from inherent OP nature of some factions there are other issues with this game: 
- Un-Skippable voice overs and introductions: Picking a faction, starting a game, choosing research options, colonising a planet… OK I admit you can “skip” these, but there is no option to just not have to go through the whole process and just cut out the whole, “fade, load, skip, fade, load” process. 
- Annoying level of micro management. You can only que up 5 improvements to a planet at a time. In a game where the colonisation is a continual process (either because new tech makes a planet viable or because someone bombed a colony into dust). This is a nightmare, especially when the “automation/ auto build / colony focus” feature makes some bizarre and useless choices; such as when I told my 1 pop colony to focus on food and the first thing the AI built was a recyclotron….    
- No process for manufacturing entire fleets at a press of a button and having automation split the constructions between different ques, more micro! I’ve seen independent games have better functionality and automation, why couldn’t a triple A title do the same? 
- Space Combat is atrocious. Ships won’t use special abilities, the camera fly’s across the map regularly, when ordered to attack a target your ships will move up to range, come to a dead stop and shoot until they die… there is no consideration or visible representation of firing arcs, only guns mounted at the front or given full turret facing seem to count, it is quite frankly…  Retarded.       
- This game chugs like a bastard on late games with larger galaxies- which is odd because it is so dumbed down there should be too much calculation going on to slow things down. 
- The bugs, I’ve had pirate bases spawn on top of planets I’ve colonised and constantly die in waves to the space station, batteries and ships stationed there.
- The game freezing at odd moments after bombarding a colony, opening a construction menu or any other tab that needs a second to load. 
- The inability to rename individual planets. I mean at some point you’ll have over 50 colonies and they will merge into one, if you can’t rename them so as to better remember what each one does and what you want to do with it as you progress through the game, well you are going to be writing things down a lot.
- With the items you can rename- (ships and systems) naming function having a very limited number of characters, so best use short names or come up with some abbreviated terms “planet killer” is too many characters, but “plnt kllr” is just about ok. 
- Only one of each “improvement” allowed on a planet, why? These places are freaking huge, and one subterranean fungus farm isn’t going to be as space intensive as a space port or an orbital dock yard is it? Why wouldn’t you just spam out a couple of these things to keep a colony fed? 
- Pirate raiders spawning on a base, 2 turns after I bomb said base into scrap… 
-The constant notifications of “Threatening Fleet Detected”… which turns out to be a space monster sitting on a planet 3 systems over from me not doing anything at all… why waste my time like this? How easy could it be to code out neutral space monsters from the warning alert? 
-The Idiotic pirate fleets throwing raiders and marauders down a star lane singularly at my space station for 100 turns until they learn they can’t beat it…. Turns out they didn’t learn, another empire came from the opposite side of the system and wiped the pirate base. But how immersion breaking is that they have about 1/10 of the power of a simple station, yet continually throw themselves at it? 
- Trade deals last 20 turns and then have to be re started? Why not allow the empires to determine their own deal length? Why not permit a continuing deal? Why add in an extra layer of “click, click, click” where I lose any interest in the diplomatic text and avatar animations? 
- Ship design “upgrades” will actually replace the mathematically superior designs with new ones based on the newest technology you have no on DPS or effectiveness. Resulting in a lot of dicking about trying to fix things after the game has broken them. 
 - Diplomacy- when the AI takes their turn to make a diplomatic offer to you, there is no facility for you to make a counter offer or negotiate their offer- you have a binary agree /disagree choice- considering the AI is open to negotiate during your turn, it’s weird that you cannot do the same in return. 
- Recruitable “leaders” who have relatively minor powers/abilities have wage bills in the BILLIONS of credits… more than it takes to run a battle station… Why, in a setting where colonies contain literally billions of people (I’m presuming that each little pop carton is a billion people) is one particular individual worth so much, and why is it only that one individual has that level of skill? 
- Why do all these ships have infinite fuel and ammo and crew supplies? Why, if ammo is infinite do I have a limit in the number of bombs I can drop on an enemy colony per turn? 
- Why do transport ships last a total of one turn and then as soon as they are used to deliver troops or population do they then disappear? I mean couldn’t I take them back to the point of origin and fill them back up? 
- Why can’t I design the bases and space stations my empire uses? 

As you can see, I have “some issues” with this game, in fact I fucking hated playing it. Every mechanic, every rule or facet of the game seemed to be designed to just be as pretty, simple and easy to play as possible. The design philosophy seemed to be “give the fools the shiny pretty things… that should stop them from having to think about things…” 
I think my issues with the new MOO sort of encapsulate the issues with modern AAA games as a whole; shiny, pretty, fast game play. About mile wide and an inch deep no thought, no tactical or strategic planning- just keep clicking on things to hear the soft chime noises and get that dopamine hit. I appreciate this is an unpopular opinion, and as the saying goes- “opinions, they are like arse-holes, everyone has one, no one really wants to see someone else’s” but lo’ the number fucks I have to give is zero. I am sick of this over simplified crap.

The game for the most part is still fun to play like the earlier versions. I have played this for over 20 years. The first ones were masterpieces of logic and game play.

The game now is written by folks that are completely clueless as to how to create an interface. There are tons of this problem that will give you carpel tunnel if your not careful. I will give one example.

Any one that knows anything about a 4X turned base game knows that there will probably only one user in the house. In order to re start a game with the same specs (in other words re generate a new map) you have to go all the way back through all of the menus from the start. About 15 clicks and 8 pages later you can start a new map. There are many places in the game that reveal total ignorance as to how an interface works easily instead of completely complicated. Hundred ship fleet? Need to click each ship to divide that up, up to a hundred clicks, and so on and so on.

So you young guys writing this stuff take a lesson.

First page you see says in this order.

CONTINUE; not go to choose single player or anything else and click 15 times, just continue.

RE START,  this means push one button and restart with a new map of the same game. Not click fifteen times and go through whole damn menu with 8 pages again.

NEW GAME or, CONFIGURE NEW GAME. This means start over and or do something different. It is that simple.

Would I recommend this game? Yes I still play it despite the completely illogical and mid 1990's use of the PC capabilities. Just have people write this stuff that have actually played it.

I wanted to give this game a positive review first but this games have a lot of issues and devs show no effort at fixing them.
1) Retreat.  In MOO1 retreating was a good and safe option you could always successfully retreat at the beginning of battle and most likely retreat mid-combat. This games alongside witch real time battles introduced ridiculously long wait time before you could retreat so to actually retreat from battle you will have to survive A LOT of hits making this option practically useless.
2) Aggression outside of war. I know perfectly well that this "feature" come up directly form MOR and MOR2 but this is REALLY bad example of inheritance. What the point of declaring war if you could do full-scale space battles in "peace-time".  And this does nightmare combo with issue 1.
3) AI aggressiveness. I was really surprised with how bold and aggressive ai empires act in this game.  In my experience, AI empires don't give a shit about good relations with player and tend to forcefully break into your territories, demand stuff and even declare war to friendly player.

MoO 2 is still the gold standard of 4x gaming in space, and this is pretty much MoO 2 with a face lift.  Which means some people will complain that there's little new to justify the price, but I'd guess those people would whine if there were too many changes.  The dev's were damned if they did, damned if they didn't.  I'm enjoying it, and on sale it's an easy buy if you liked MoO 2.

The new:
[list]
[*] Real time combat.  There's formations that give bonuses to attack & defense for certain weapons, or a speed boost.  In the end, taking control matters as I can win when outmatched by using tactics - aka running away at full speed & slinging missiles at ships that would otherwise pulverize me up close.  But my actions do make a difference, it's not quite total war but it's nice.  And beats the old MoO 2 end game battles that would take forever to try and manually control 100+ doomstars.
[*] Warp-lines.  No more going from star A to star B, now there's warp connections that your ships travel between which can lead to bottlenecks to expansion, more severe on certain galaxy shapes like spirals.  As a result you can now fortify choke points with defense fleets & outposts.  But the Antarans can show up anywhere - so don't neglect your heartland.  You can eventually build a network of jump gates to vastly increase travel speed along a far flung empire & respond to threats.
[/list]


The old:
[list]
[*] Research
[*] Planet & population management
[*] the races, the Antarans, the Guardian
[*] It's mostly just old MoO 2
[/list]

It's a streamlined & simple 4X that doesn't stray too far from what made MoO 2 so great.

I have over 1300 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #64 - Master of Orion

I do remember the Master of Orion trilogy from years ago, and I had always heard good things about it, but I never did get around to playing any of them.  And now that I've played this reboot, I kind of regret that, as I definitely feel like I have missed out on something good here.

The game opens with a quick cutscene, after which I play around with the options a bit, mostly the usual cranking up the graphics options.  I looked at the gameplay options, but I ended up leaving everything as their defaults just because I wasn't clear on what many of the options actually did.   But it definitely left me with the impression that there was a lot you could tweak.

You get several options for starting a game, but since I'd never played any of these games before, I went with the Tutorial Match.   What this ends up doing is giving you a bit of a on-rails experience with the start of the game.  At first it was a little confusing because I would try to click things that wouldn't respond, but once I realized I was on-rails, it wasn't such a big deal.

You start out with a colony ship which you use to settle on a new planet, along with a couple of scout ships.  The scout ships you use to explore the current star system and beyond.   So far, this is pretty standard 4x style gameplay.  If you've played other games in this genre, then it will feel pretty comfortable. 

You start out with a single planet, but then the tutorial will have you use the colony ship to colonize a new planet.  It warns you at the same time that it's not a very good planet to colonize.   Each planet in the system is rated based on it's size, what biome it is, and what minerals are available.  Picking a bad planet means that you are limited in how far you can develop it.  This is why you also have the scout ships to start out with, so that you can uncover some better planets to colonize.

Next the game introduces you to research, which again, if you've ever played any of these kind of games before will be completely expected.   You select a technology to research, which unlocks various new benefits and opens up more technologies to unlock.    Some research items will take more time than others to unlock, but you can also influence this by how you distribute your population.  

Your population is distributed across 3 areas: research, food, and production.   Research influences the speed in which you can complete your current research task.   Food will impact your ability to grow the planet population.  Too little food and your planet will starve.  More food will decrease the time before your population can grow.   Production determines how quickly you can build new ships.  Right off the bat the tutorial has me build a Frigate, as the colony and scout ships are pretty defenseless.  

At this point, the tutorial starts introducing some of the other aspects of the game, like the Empire Management screen that gives you an overview of your empire.   Next is espionage, which apparently lets you train interstellar agents to spy on other empires.  But at this point in the game you lack the technology to do any of this, so the tutorial is just kind letting you know it's coming.  

Then comes fleet management, where you can get a view of all of the different fleets in your empire.  At this point I just have my 2 scout ships exploring the nearby star systems.  The Path To Victory screen shows you the different ways you can win the match, which I'm sure is influenced by the kind of match you choose to play.   This reminds me of the Civilization games which also give you multiple ways to win.

After introducing all of these screens, the tutorial lets me get back to playing.  I build my frigate, and not long after the tutorial introduces your first enemy, which is a pirate ship located in a nearby star system.   I'm directed to move my frigate into a position where it will guard the star system and be able to intercept the pirate ship should it come.   

You can set your scout ships to Auto Explore if you don't want to micro-manage them.  Doing this will allow the scout ships to continuously explore new areas.  The scouts will analyze each planet in a star system before picking a random unexplored system to move to next.  Another thing is that scouts can also uncover anomalies which are like random events.  In my case I found an abandoned container that gave me some credits.

You earn credits by taxing your population.  You can change the rate at which you tax your people, but the higher the tax, the unhappier your population.   You can spend credits to allow for something in-progress to finish early, such as a research project or ship you are building.

Not surprisingly, that pirate ship moved into my primary star system, where my frigate was waiting for it.   You get a few different options for the battle.  First is auto-resolve, which is the quickest option where it will immediately do some calculations to determine the outcome.   You can also take command to take a more hands-on role in the battle.  

At this point I'm about 30 minutes into my playthrough, and the tutorial is increasingly off the rails now, leaving me to explore and manage my systems.   When I ended one of my turns, I got this really strange interlude from the "Galactic News Network" where a couple of robots are giving the news.  This is done as a way of conveying random events which will have an impact on your empire, such as a population bonus.  I say it's strange because it's all very tongue-and-cheek, and up to this point the game has been very straight-faced, so it was kind of jarring.  I did notice though the game gives you the option to disable GNN if you find it annoying.

One nice feature, among the overview screens is a Planets screen which will list all of the known planets you've found that aren't colonized.  So that definitely makes it easier to find a good candidate to settle on.  I also discovered as I uncovered more planets that they will sometimes have a special feature that can give a bonus, such as increased production.

Besides ships, you can build other types of facilities.   You can build planetary buildings to speed up your ability to research, grow your population, or build other things.   You can also build space-bound items such as a star base, or a missile base for defense.  Or you can build a Space Factory, which you can setup somewhere in your system and use it to build other projects.  Unfortunately, this came at the tail end of my hour, so I didn't really get a good sense for what else you could build.

Overall, I thought the tutorial did a great job at introducing the game in a way that was not overwhelming right away.  It makes it very easy to pick up and overall a very accessible game.  I had a ton of fun playing this.  And that is the surest sign to me to give a game my recommendation, when all I want to do is keep playing it.  I was not ready to put this game down after an hour. Another good sign is when I spend more time writing the review than I did playing the game.  I came out of this not only with an appreciation for the game, but a renewed curiosity about the original trilogy.

I always include my disclaimer at the top that these reviews are a first impression.  But that's especially true for these types of games, as they tend to run pretty long, and I don't feel that I uncovered a whole lot in the first hour.   So do please check out some other reviews in case there are some later game annoyances that I did not come across.

Now my main complaint is the game time. I know that a part of the problem is me as I also have problems with civilization which can take me 30 hours to play on a tiny map in civ 5. Here I started a new game where I put the production to the fastest speed, and after 6.5 hours of game play, I only have 3 planets. I used the smallest map, and personally, I find it too big. I know some modders are making maps bigger than the the biggest map. So the problem is probably me.

There is a lot of micro management in the game, which means a lot of meaning less decision by positioning workers, and selecting buildings to make. I don't know if aging made me more allergic to those kind of mechanics. Or if it's me who have less time than before to play long games and would prefer a game that plays completely within 5 hours. From my memory, master of orion 2 games too me probably a dozen of hours. So Moo2 might be faster to play.

There was a time when I thought I was going to just wave my hand dismissively at the problems and recommend this game.  I did, too.  I played a bunch of it, and it can be fun, at times...but there are glaring problems, and I really can't recommend it at all.

Firstly: This game is incredibly buggy.  Let's run down some related problems, in order.

1: Single-threaded (it seems) game can only use one core to process all that happens in a turn.  This means turns take longer and longer to process, especially in a large galaxy, and it's absurdly slow.
2: If you keep colonizing and conquering as you get new technology, each, half-hour-long turn will be spent managing population, production queues, sending fleets out, etc., and that's before Antarans make you panic and have to shift everything around and lose a colony.
3: At some point, I'm not sure when, the game just...crashes when you try to load a game.  The turns come fine in order, but if you don't want to keep your computer on through a whole marathon game session (which may take multiple days, if your galaxy is big enough), you go from slowly trudging through the game to being unable to play it at all.  Guess you're starting over!

I got this game because of a youtuber by the name of Mal a few years ago. I had my fun but man the game in vanilla just eats at you after the first time you manage to complete a run, bout 7-10 hours on a medium galaxy with the default turn limit for score victory and without the Antaran raiders attacking you. The Antarans generally attack the race who is leading in one of the win conditions, empire management (score). They attack the race's world with the highest defense rating (if your fleet is there that's where they go). If you plan to aim for a conquest victory they will make the game quite hellish until around turn 250 up which is past the 5 hour mark where your ships assume enough mass, armor, and weaponry to do something. Often you'd need orbital defenses to be the meat shields they are in vanilla else your fleet would still be overwhelmed as the Antarans do indeed scale by turn rather than the leading race's military or score. They can and will swamp your ass with over 70 ships many of which may be destroyers and above. Without mods to make orbital defenses worth a damn, they will kick your ass allllll the way to end game when you finally get battleships upwards or manage to cheese the Orion world's guardian (essentially a battleship) for advanced weapons and armor and an uber planet.

More on ships, there is absolutely nothing in the vanilla game that can compete with just spamming an overwhelming amount of missiles. Just get bigger ships with big payloads of absurd numbers of missiles and there's any naval battle instantly ruined by cheese as the AI hybridizes their weapons and will RARELY build a ship rated above cruiser and just build up a bunch of low weight frigates, destroyers, and cruisers showing that their navy is braindead. This actually counters your spam as missiles do not inherently find new targets if their target has been destroyed meaning they fly and go boom in the void of nothing. However by end game your tonnage is so high that they cant possibly hurt your battleships upwards and your ships that are cruisers will always take 4 or more enemies down before they die due to the enemies' bad AI and game's horrible blueprint auto designer. Also there is a guidance system that completely removes one of the 2 weaknesses of missiles. The enemy will never use ECM so that might as well not even be a damn weakness. I mentioned this before but the only orbital defense worth a damn is the star base and its upgrades, not because it actually serves as a defense platform, but because it wields the health of a battleship and acts as aggro to the retarded enemy ai. Mod the ai and orbital defense to make both actually intimidating. 

From my 30 or so vanilla hours i haven not observed any distinction between racial ai. They all act the same and is displayed in the worst possible light when the silicoid, a race who does not eat, asks for food related research. No empire takes advantages of its traits nor acts in character, i.e. humans being diplomatic traders. Often no one does trade deals, research exchange until you go to them and they often request retarded demands like colony cessions for something like a trade deal a simple non aggression pact. A MUST MOD for any real enjoyment.

Management is fine for the most part. Taxing is the issue here as you lose out on a lot of money because taxes are empire wide rather than planet specific. This means some breeding world will mint a pretty penny while a production world will always get ungrateful striking cunts because production builds pollution (elaborated in a bit). Pollution in vanilla spirals UNBELIEVABLY out of control. If you find a godsend of a system with a ultra rich planet with sister planets that are abundant or even poor and manage to make it an industrial powerhouse of a system, you will ALWAYS reach near max pollution.

If you do reach max pollution, you degrade the planet's biome, and the side effects of pollution is increased need of food and decreased happiness of civilians (them getting miffed about your already low 3 currency per pop rate), which leads to striking, reassigning people to food, and having to stop building that flagship you wanted to clean up the pollution, You will do this twice or more for any ship above cruiser on the tech tree and also for terraforming a damned planet. This snowballs ridiculously and you waste enormous amounts of money per planet for pollution processing buildings that dont even solve the problem; it only applies a miniaturized stop gap bandaid. My advice there is to just get a mod that reduces the gain or just get the core waste dump mod which makes that building (it is an end game building so no worries about busting scaling there) just negate all pollution altogether. I dont even remember which mod does this but it makes it so terraforming a planet counts toward pollution cleanup instead of pollution creation. Modding alleviates most of the grievances aside of how long a game takes to play out which is something i'd rather never experience again thanks to Bethesda. This game takes quite a bit of modding to make the game replayable after the 1st playthrough.

I'm just gonna stop here as there is just too much more to say and i've been here for a half hour typing this already and tell you unless you're willing to visit the steam workshop for mods to make any run past the first enjoyable, Don't buy this. Also the multiplayer is very much dead, and it'll be a crazy day in hell before a friend on your friend's list decides to play this with you due to it being a less popular 4x game. Despite me enjoying the game a considerable amount, Bethesda has taught that you should most certainly should not require a modding community to make a game worth playing and this game certainly would not be worth touching if it didnt have mods. 

Buy on sale if you must.

If you don't already know, the original MOO II was regarded as one of the best space 4x TBS games ever to be made, if not the best space 4x ever, at least until more recent games like Stellaris, Distant Worlds, and Endless Space 2 took top spot.  The 4x community have been asking for a new MOO for a looong time, and we finally got it.  

What this game does well is stick to the old formula that made the original such a great game. It's a very simple 4x game compared to the more recent "complex" ones, and that's not a bad thing.   Depending on the player you are, you may love or hate this.   What it doesn't do is add much of anything new.  There are some minor changes and additions (added star-lanes, buildable "starbases"), but nothing drastic that changes how the game was played, except for maybe combat.

 The one major thing they took out was turn-based combat.   Instead, they put in real-time combat when battles happen.  I personally love it, it allows you to just watch the AI battle, or if you want, you can take command (or have AI assist) of your units and have a say in what you want to do.  While MOOII turn-based combat was fun, it could really take a loooooong time to get thru one battle during mid-late game.  Having 30vs30 ship battles went horribly slow for turn-based combat.  Even if you let the AI take over it would take quite awhile.  This newer combat system works well, and it does it's purpose.  It's a much needed face-lift to an old classic.  

The one void here, that newer games do well, is exploration and story. There are anomalys to discover with little stories behind it, but nothing compared to something like Stellaris.  This game also doesn't feel as big.  You have games like Stellaris and Distant Worlds which really make you feel you're in this huge universe full of hundreds of stars.

This game is perfect for those who want to dip their toes in space 4x, nothing will overwhelm you like some of these newer, bigger, more complex 4x games.  You can sit down and easily learn how things work right off the bat.  This game is also good for veterans of the genre.  It's just a really solid 4x game.

Master of Orion is essentially an updated verion of MOOII with some minor improvements.  The graphics are great, the voice acting is fantastic, and it's still the same game I've always loved playing.

First of all - this game is absolutely unplayably buggy on Mac. As in, it crashes every few minutes. It shouldn't be available for sale for MacOS and I wish I hadn't attempted to persevere, since I'm well over the 2 hour refund window now.

As far as gameplay is concerned - it hasn't changed all that much from the early access game I played a couple of years back, which is to say, it's an extremely perfunctory, phoned-in remake of MoO2. It's not dreadful, but nor is it terribly exciting, The gameplay is *very* slow, the AI is very passive (and often just plain irrational), it's unbalanced as all heck and generally lacking polish. Tons of minor UI bugs, unclear description text and misleading numbers - as an example, Elerians receive bonuses to beam weapons, however, it's impossible to discern in-game what exactly qualifies as a "beam weapon" and what doesn't. It also runs like an absolute dog on my modest Macbook Pro, even at lowest graphical settings - which for a turn based strategy game is very silly.

It's a real shame, because had the developers spent a few extra months doing QA testing, optimising, and refining - or even provided some decent post-release updates - this could have been the definitive entry in the MoO franchise. Instead it seems they've just grabbed the money and run. It's definitely not worth its exorbitant price tag; much better to grab the vastly superior Stellaris or reinstall MoO2. If you must indulge your curiosity, wait until it's on sale for $10.

I have mixed feelings about this iteration of Master of Orion.  I am a huge fan of Microprose's games, and while this game does have the nostalgia of them, it doesn't have the gritty feel that MoO and MoO2 had. It feels like it was marketed for a younger audience, which typically doesn't go well for 4X titles.

I enjoy playing World of Tanks Blitz and thought Wargaming is promising gaming company so decided to try Orion. However the game appears boring, graphic not impressive. I suggest that Wargaming better focus on tanks as it seems to be the only thing they can do well.

(I play offline, and have played a lot more than is listed above.)

As an update of an old game, this isn't bad.  It brings in a lot of good ideas from post-MOO2 4X games, but keeps the essential nature and feel of the original.  That said, it crashes (rarely) and can be very slow (common, late game).  The interface is unfinished, with information missing in many areas and poorly handled interfaces in some areas.  I can't recommend this game for anyone other than MOO2 aficionados. 
 The game is certainly playable, and is in a state that is what passes for a newly released game these days.  However, the three years after release should have seen the crashes, slowdowns, and missing or poorly done interfaces fixed, and that hasn't happened, and (at this point) likely won't.

Summary: The game is fairly easy to learn, but hard to master. It has a ton of polish put into it, and feels like a mostly faithful re-imagining of Masters of Orion 2 (the best of the original series). The game has some draw-backs and falls a little flat in areas compared to other 4X titles that have been around for quite some time. That said it's still a solid game, and worth the buy if you're looking for a new 4X experience.

Details:

The 4Xs:

eXploration - Exploration is the one X that feels like it falls the most flat. Even larger map sizes ultimately feel pretty small. This is likely to prevent overly long and uneventful games. I don't mean small as in "it takes very little time to get from one side to the other" I mean small as in "there isn't a lot of interesting diversity among stellar objects". Planets tend to fall into "when will I colonize these" tiers, and unless you're on a higher difficulty most races seem to want to just expand as much as possible because population is EVERYTHING in this game (I'm only 20hrs in, but also I've played a TON of 4X games so make of that what you will). 

eXpansion: The way that systems are constructed in the game makes expansion feel a little strange. In the early game you're mostly scouting out places to plop down, but good early game roosts are few and far between (at least for the races I've played). Late game it becomes an exercise in getting 3 pop ready for transport, and a bit of credits for the first few building buy outs. Wam, bam, new functional colony within a matter of turns. You can definitely start getting things going FAST if you've set yourself up to do so. The biggest issue with expansion in the game is that since the maps are fairly small you're more immediately thrown into conflict or diplomatic relations.

eXploit: Plenty of resources to exploit here, and its nice that there are a few juggling factors to it as well. Pollution feels like a great balancing mechanic for reaping to prep for war and recovering when its time for peace. I love the back and forth of it. That said I can see it becoming less engaging as I get better at that balancing pattern.

eXterminate: Combat in this game is enjoyable. Space battles are mostly smooth and share elements with combat from Sword of the Stars. Ship customization is a lot of fun, and weapons feel mostly well balanced against others in the same tech tier. The game doesn't feel the need to add a third pointless dimension to combat which is nice, but still allows you to exploit advantages like range properly. Once you engage your opponents in their range though it turns into Gratuitous Space Battles as ships fly around chaotically it becomes harder to perform meaningful tactics. If the developers had added a few more weapons (like mines) it would have been an amazing experience. As of right now its just "pretty good". Additional ship hulls would have also added a lot to the flexibility of combat. Instead you'll be playing a lot more with lay-out and saved ship designs. That all said the Auto-battle function works fairly predictably so while you may not have as good of results as you could achieve through manual control for those who don't wish to engage with the system, auto-battle seems mostly fine.

The Population Problem: So far my experience with this game has been that Population is one of the most important things. Its practically impossible to run an empire as a "tall" empire because planets have max pop limits that are reached fairly easily, and its also impossible to run low-pop empires because you just don't have the credits, production, or research of larger empires. So the game practically forces you to expand constantly. This also means that races with bonuses to population growth or food are REALLY good compared to the others. A racial bonus to research just doesn't compete well with an empire who grows much faster and therefore can compete just as well with you on research... but also crush you on every other front. Its quite possible that there are counter-strategies to this, or a draw-back to large pop-empires that I'm not yet aware of but after 20hrs of play I haven't found anything. 

A Lack of Racial Variety: This isn't a complaint about the number of races, its a complaint about meaningful gameplay differences between races. Across the races I've played most of them encourage similar strategies (partially because of the population issue). There also aren't significant tech differences between races. Maybe I'm just spoiled by the first Sword of the Stars, but I miss unique race-ships, technologies, travel styles, etc.

The game is okay at the last development build before the budget for improvements ran out.  To make it great though just look at the following two mods.  They have a compatibility patch that allows them to work together.

[url=https://www.nexusmods.com/masteroforionconquerthestars/mods/6]5X - The Ultimate Balance Mod[/url]
[url=https://www.nexusmods.com/masteroforionconquerthestars/mods/30]UnofficialCodePatch[/url]

These mods make the game great.

Master of Orion is incredibly unstable and needs a far more experienced development team to comb through the code and find all of the errors. Rife with glitches, this game does not crash per se (animations and sounds still work), but it does get stuck after performing certain actions, requiring users to force quit through Alt+F4 or the Task Manager.

I have encountered three of these glitches in the past few days: after closing negotiations with the Klackon, upon beginning a large battle with 20+ ships, and, most recently, upon retreating at the end of a battle with some Antarans. I've probably seen more glitches like these, but I just started playing again after an absence of about two years and can't remember any of them.

Furthermore, the game speed and framerate drop significantly as larger games progress. I understand that an old RTS like Supreme Commander (2007) has issues trying to render 2000+ units (plus projectiles, shadows, bloom, terrain, etc.) on one map, but a relatively light 4X from 2016 has no excuse.

Gameplay, on the other hand, is enjoyable. (I don't have a good reference point to which I can compare MoO, so your mileage may vary.) The graphics are good enough, the art style is fantastic, and Wargaming tapped some pretty big names for voice acting.

If you can tolerate a few game breaking bugs and enjoy a solid 4X, go right ahead and buy it. (Edit: Holy crap it's $30! I take it back: wait for a sale - at least 1/3 off.) Otherwise, steer clear of Master of Orion. It's not like Wargaming needs your money. 

In fact, World of Tanks has become so rife with pay to win macrotransactions, they probably don't even deserve your money.

Catastrophic rendition of a classic game with an absolute clumsy delivery that is typical of a cash grab. I installed Master of Orion with all good intentions and hopes that it would fill the empty space that MOOII left when it became clear it could no longer survive on newer systems. Master of Orion III was another catastrophe with one of the clumsiest UI I've ever used. This game just does everything wrong in comparison.

The game is terrible. The AI is nothing more than a series of pre-planned events by seed. If you don't like a map, just quit, generate a new one increasing the seed. Doing this you'll soon realize that it makes no difference and that everything is just planned to hurt, including the UI. You can no longer see the stats of your ships from the main screen. I don't know why. You can't plan anything unless you take extra note on the missing information. The way ship names is managed is fugly and should probably be left alone. Those 2 things together is enough to piss off anyone.

You want a diplomatic report on another race, nope. Not anymore, they removed it. Oh they did manage to make some things better like splitting some tech in a more coherent tree, but you never know what gives what without having to scroll the entire thing looking for a particular entry by hovering on icons.

Everything in this game is unbearable, buggy or badly designed. The game frequently crashes. On linux it is impossible to set the resolution in full screen mode to anything you select. Game runs perfect natively  under Linux on PC with Nvidia  as well as on Laptop with intel HD 4000 (20 FPS on laptop which is OK).

In game  settings you can  switch to full  screen but also  use windowed mode (The latter displays in the  settings screen a resolution of 640 by 480 but  uses actually  the full  desktop except  for  he  taskbar).  No graphics issues noticeable, just perfect.

Using the UCP Mod.



About the Game

It produces the  one-more-turn feeling - I'm totally hooked,  I love it! Also it makes you really feeling like ruling a galaxy. All the mechanics of the  game which you  realize during learning  to play work  well with each  other. At  the moment  I'm only  using the  UCP mod  which changes mostly  convenience but  doesn't change  gameplay. Will  pick up  the 5X balance mod in the future.

The UI is done  really nice with soooo much love  for detail.  Watch the parallax scrolling of the stars  in the galaxy! The different characters you encounter on the diplomacy screen  are voiced nicely and are created with  a lot a devotion for detail.

Don't activate the timeline but instead save whenever you think a proper moment has come. Activating the timeline saves every turn of the history which leads to BIG save files.

Summary - if you love turn based strategy don't hesitate to pick up this one. The devs have put a lot of love in this one.

The UI is generally very slick and nice but the game has unforgiveable bugs: It doesn't show you some vital info (e.g upkeep costs of space constructions (bases), detailed info about ships (even yours) that is availiable during battles, etc); If you have multiple fleets in the same spot, you cannot select more than one of them (except via fleets menu); The AI is super bad, it doesn't take advantage of weak neighbours (me) and cannot assess it's strenght (like modern civ games, it refuses to talk to you for a long while after the start of war, even if surrender should a be obvious goal); The battle AI is broken: some ships just move to the starting point of enemy fleet and stay there, do not avoid super-slow torpedoes; And last but oh so very not least: game crashes consistently.

Also: mid-game empire can support a big fleet of... 3 ships!!! Impressive. Like not even a ship per planet...

   Pros:

           >Easy learning curve.
           >Immersive

  Cons:

          >You will contract the "just one more turn" disease. (Addictive game play)
          
Overall a very enjoyable experience.

Well I've finished two playthroughs now and it's still as bittersweet as I remember from when I first installed it. 

This is 4X for the casuals. And I don't mean a casual play through, I mean the game is dumbed down to the point where it's aimed at toddlers to play. Everything is basic and simplified. There are a few excellent mods that add some missing features and fix a few of the broken UI issues but the core game is still a dumbed down baby X4 game. 

Ground combat is two numbers and who has the bigger number wins. 
You can rename systems but not planets which is a pain when a system has more than one planet and you need to swiftly check a production queue. 
You get 8 blueprints for ships and that's it. Meaning you can't build different fleets for different tasks, you can't create cool tactical plans using fast missile boats or fleet carriers flanked by tanks. You can't have that cloaked assassin ship to flank an enemy. You get one type of frigate, destroyer, battleship and so on. You have a total of two extra slots you can make a custom build and that's it! All because the designer didn't like a tab button or scroll bars on his nice clean UI! Minimalism and 4X don't mix well! 

The vanilla game lacks any variety in biomes, events, plot, races, ships. 

The game is still glitchy in late turns with random issues like the menu not loading or battles getting stuck or the bombardment screen not showing the outcome. These can all be fixed by closing the game and reloading, but it's still a pain. 

There is a distinct lack of customization in games. You can't pick to play against 5 human races or select what events you want to enable. You can't disable certain victory conditions. 

It's a very restrictive game with a lack of depth. 

But it's not terrible. There is some nice things and well done aspects of the game. The graphics in battles are great, the UI for the most part is pretty clean and easy to navigate, if just lacking a lot of details that should be in a 4X game. 

Overall it's not a patch on past MOO games or other 4X games and it doesn't even come close to Stellaris which is the best 4X game going right now. If you're a 4X fan and you want a really really basic 4X game for you kids to learn the basics on, or for a quick evening game then this might be just what you want. If you really want a X4 game you can be engrossed in then go for Stellaris. 

To date there are few decent 4X games on the market and most games in this genre come from indy Devs with a very poor track record for support and continuous updates. Cough cough Stardrive… 

So the fact MOO works and does have continued support from the Devs is another plus. It's just such a shame it was so dumbed down.
Brings back all those good game feelings from my youth.  This is a great redo of the origional.
Fun game Simple 4x, nice and easy to get into.

Master of Orion 2 was one of the best multiplayer games of my youth. The 3rd edition was terrible and confusing but this is a worthy followup for the series. It is an updated and improved version the second game.
a revision of what made this game legendary, and it only improves the game.

I really wanted to like this game.  I played the original MOO forever (still play it sometimes). 
Masters of Orion (4?) Conquer The Stars is a remake of MOO2. It has some fairly decent basic Game Mechanics, and some pretty/amusing cut-scenes, but is difficult to enjoy, even though I really want to. Don't waste your time unless you're okay with all of the following. 
Key issues:
1) The game is incredibly slow. Not always a deal breaker, but you need maybe 40 turns before seeing if the randomly generated galaxy is worth playing 
2) The randomly generated galaxies spawn a lot of garbage planets but very few worth colonising - even with the settings amended to increase the number of planets
3) (edited) It took far too long to figure out how to upgrade ships. If the option appears at all, it says "This action is not currently available" instead of something useful like "this action can only be performed at a starbase".  Sadly, this is the sort of lazy unhelpful placeholder text that sunk MOO3
4) The diplomatic engine is outright lazy. Other races will only trade for your highest tech and won't settle for 2-3 lesser techs, even if it is technology they can't even use (e.g. Silicoids wanting Soil Enrichment and refusing all other options)
5) The game has been out for several years and is still buggy. I suddenly can't renegotiate research treaties as the AI says this will cost 135,473 BC (more than any race will earn the entire game)
6) As with the infamous MOO3 the information conveyed to the player is often nonsensical or non-existent. Leaders come with sparse nonsensical descriptions for their overpriced abilities. There really hasn't been  much effort put into conveying useful information to inform your decisions
7) Your peons start complaining the moment you hit 4 or 5 people on a new planet and then refuse to help build the stuff they need to survive. Unlike most 4X games, you can't adjust taxes for a specific colony. Either you bleed money from your entire galactic tax system or just carry some deadbeats on your new planets until you build the right buildings, thus slowing the game down even further
8) You can only carry 4 Blueprint designs. One for each  size of ship. There does not appear to be any way of seeing what specs your existing ships have, which again, seems like another pointless gap in the basic information you need and another basic fail in 4X game design
9) It's a lot harder to move populations around than it used to be. You need the right tech to build transports and they disappear and can't be reused for some reason. Because I guess the grateful peasants you ship use them to build a giant statue of you when they get where they are going?? This slows things down a lot.
10) The game takes forever. Largely because of pointless game limitations mentioned above. If you liked the largescale battles from the original, expect about 200 turns before that's going to happen.
11) The combat AI is comically bad. Usually the ships just walk in a straight line and then wait at the opposite of the map until the END OF TIME. If there's a starbase in the way, they won't even finish it off. Worse yet, if you exit the battle midway (e.g. because the enemy are nowhere near your station and have no intention of attacking it) the auto-resolve is based on the ships from the START of the battle. Which means that ships will magically pop back into existence even though you already blew them apart.  
12) Most of the game mechanics are simply ripped off from the Civ series. (the diplomacy engine, the respawning barbarian/pirate bases, the neutral races, the spacefactory/engineers, the population based happyness, etc, etc) That's not really a complaint, but Civilization did it a lot better. 
13) The alien AI are passive. So to spice things up, someone decided that the mongol hoardes should come rampaging across the map at turn 90. At that point in the game it will take about 10 turns to get your ships from one side of your territory to the other, so it will suck when the mongols (sorry Antaran) teleport in 3 turns away from a randomly selected world of yours. Expect to reload to muster your forces for a fair fight.
.
All that being said, the updated MOO2 graphics are cute, particularly the new msshran/psilon planets management mini-people.
 
If you do want to play this game, you'll save yourself 30 hours of trial-and-error by following a few basic game requirements that should have been a lot more obvious: 
1)  Send your ships back to a starbase often to update them to match your blueprint designs. 
2) It's not obvious, but you can also do this with your scouts and factories when you get better engines, so they can move around faster.  
3) When you start, immediately update your frigate blueprint design to include a nuke and then update your frigate at your homeworld - so you can take out pirate bases, otherwise they will eat your scouts. 
4)The game-mechanics do not permit your scouts to retreat from battle. They are required to drive themselves into a bezerker frenzy and then immediately kamikaze their way into Valhalla or something (only option is "auto"). However they are cheaper and faster than frigates so....... 
5) Stack your ship designs with missiles that will out-range the enemy ships that are sitting on the edge of the map updating their tinder profiles. You can win most battles using the genius art of sending your ships slightly to the left (or swipe right - your call).
6) Start with a big homeworld. Your homeworld is less affected by morale/loyalty than any other planet. Which is weird, because for most empires your stinking dickensian metropolis is the reason people want to relocate to the colonies in the first place... 

Lastly: The primary source of dramatic tension is something you can't easily anticipate. From turn 90, every 20 turns, the mongols hordes will attack a random base with a large fleet and only 3 turns warning. The target is decided 2 turns before they appear, so save often.

And be prepared for a game that takes hours to play, without much purpose or payoff.

I really really wanted to like this game.  Held off for awhile due to the mixed reviews on launch, thought I'd let them patch initial bugs etc.  Everything it has is good and solid and oh so pretty...
BUT...
There's just not enough of it, or it falls short.
Ship design is cool, but not all that in-depth.  Most modules just have straight up upgrades, no interesting trade-offs to consider.
Colonisation and expansion has some great ideas, but takes an age, micromanagement is a pain and falls short of what is offered by other games.
Real time combat, this game's prime selling point to me... There was basically nothing meaningfully tactical about it.  Aside from maybe moving a damaged ship out of the fight, there was no real benefit to me taking direct control.

In short, it's really pretty.  Has a lot of cool ideas, but there are frankly just other games that do everything it tries to do better.  Endless Space 2 and Stellaris would be my suggestions.

Basically, this is a high production value (for a strategy game) remake of Master of Orion 2.  There are really only a few slight changes from MoO2 - namely the combat is pauseable realtime instead of turn based, there is a pollution mechanic for planets, and an intergalactic stock market mechanic.  Other than that, it is basically a remake of MoO2.  That is NOT a bad thing at all since MoO2 is one of the best strategy games every made and it's really quite an old game.  It is very worth checking out if you like the 4x Genre.

I LOVE the newer Master of Orion. When I was a teen in the 90s, I spent lots of hours playing the original M.o.O. and then loved M.o.O. II even more (would still play that one a bit as an adult). I love the graphics, the design, lay out, and I really love still naming the star systems whatever I want. I especially was excited to hear voice-characters like Michael Dorn (Star Trek) and Mark Hammill (Star Wars) participate in the game. It helps sharpen management skills while having fun!
The base game is solid though it leaves a bit to be desired. With the 5X Ultimate balance mod it surpasses MoO 2 in my option and I played 2 for most of my youth (likely 2000 hours).

This game reminds me a lot like MoO2, mainly for the technology and races included in the game, although unfortunately some races must be bought....which is a real shame, people like myself bought it simply to relive the MoO2 days, Something feels wrong as well with the tech tree, in the old days you had up to three choices on what tech you wanted (unless your race had creative), but in this is kinda random, I've had moments where I got everything even though the game told me I might get one or the other throughout the tech tree beginning to end, kind of a happy accident I suppose, they also have warp points for each system to get in and out of to other connected warp points in other systems, which to me is kind of a mixed bag, a lot like space empires, but you can't close old ones and make new ones. 

All things said, I do rather enjoy it, it does give me that MoO2 feel with better graphics, and voice acting (which wasn't necessary, but graciously accepted), other things have been changed, like only being able to make one doom star, not being able to make mass amounts of spies per turn.
I don't mind change as long as it makes sense, if serves a purpose to make the game better, in fact I'm glad they managed to keep the successful formula of "Familiar but fresh" approach.

Oh one last thing also this game has a couple of weird bugs in it where sometimes it doesn't show the ship firing the stellar converter so a beam shoots out of nothing, or has a hard time quitting when you select quit game.
I hope this helps.

Great game. My favorite 4x. I had it on gog but bought on steam just to play friends. I feel they did the series justice, unlike some of the successors, or so I hear.

Awhile ago this game was low reviews because people didn't know what they were doing. I don't know how, its not that hard. Maybe they just didn't like how it wasn't an exact copy of past MoO games.

What differs for the most part is use of star lanes instead of traveling to anywhere. So systems have entrances you can put bases at, so you don't need to worry about ships crossing from nowhere to attack whatever they want. I like this change for the most part.

The voice acting is amazing, all star cast almost. Though some complain about annoying voices on some advisors, I feel thats whining just to whine. Mark Hamill is the alkari leader, I still don't believe it. The terran leader has the best personality imo, and is voice by the guy who was Freddy Kruegar!

The combat has a few options. Ranging from full control of units to cinematic fights. Other than some jerky movement I do cinematic fights (when I don't autocalculate). Unfortunately multiplayer has no battle options other than autocalculate, but I can understand why (games would be forever, and would take forever to do a turn unless it was 2 people fighting each other.

There are mods out there. I personally use UCP mod, it basically fixes some things with stuff the game had in it anyways (or so I think that's the purpose). People talk about how the game is better with a mod which I think is called 5x, but I really didn't like it. A mod to balance the meklar would be nice, but I didn't search for it.

Overall, the game is great. DLC I think makes game better (variety is good). I'm only saddened that you can tell the devs put effort into this, yet in the beginning they had subpar reviews. So stupid reviewers could have ended the series. I'm not sure though. For now I'm hoping thats not the case.

One boring 20-hour match down...

What's so unfortunate about this game is that it's "almost there," which is better than a lot of space 4X games.  It has all of the pieces and some aesthetic aspects are surprisingly well-done.

But my GOD the pacing!  It's such an important aspect of 4X, and even though it's obvious, I never would have understood *how* essential it is to the experience until slogging through this mindless purgatory.  I spent two days of my life on that stupid 20-hour match, and I can never have them back.  I went 3 hours at a time with nothing of interest happening.  Place a building, pick a tech, wait for 50 turns.  They even have the option to tweak the pacing, but the slog-fest is hardcoded and the tweaking is an illusion.  Sure, you can change the literal pacing of tech, building, and population growth, but this is a problem with the base gameplay cycle and tweaking the actual turns involved doesn't change the fundamentals.  Unfortunately, this feeling can't be well described and you will be *well* beyond the 2-hour refund period.

It's almost exactly like MOO2 - except that it's boring as hell!  I don't know exactly how you suck the fun out of a game while barely changing it, but they managed to.  MOO2 + good graphics - all fun-factor.  And I'm going to play it again, because it *is* still addictive.   I think it's just the 4X itch calling me, though...

Over the years, there have been many 4X strategy games.  All of them have had to live up to the standard that the Masters of Orion series set in 1993.

Starting in the late 80's going into the early 90's 4X games became one of the most successful genres in PC gaming, beginning with games like Armada and Spaceword Ho, followed by Sid Meyers Civilization.

Like many strategy games of its kind, MOO has a very straight forward approach to the user.  Settle on some planets, build, find more planets, build more ships, meet your neighbors and either make peace or conquer them.  Unlike most of the 4X Space games, MOO had some hallmark features including upgrading your ships after a research advance and diplomacy that impacted your overall gameplay.  2 sequels (the best of which is still MOO2), came out and while MOO3 was not considered a great game, it was still one of my favorite games.

Master of Orion takes the lessons learned from all the original games and updates the interface to be more user friendly, along with updated graphics.  I would suggest you look into this game as it is a great entry into the MOO universe.
