In short, I recommend the game if you get it on discount and you don't expect it to be better game than MOO2. For veterans, its a bit of a let down. Surely you get modern (although a bit dull) graphics, decent one time play through experience and nostalgia points but that's about it for the positive sides. Problems/lacking list is long but you can decide yourself how each of them matters to you, if at all.

First, the pacing of the game is very slow, especially at the beginning. Starlane system creates huge bottlenecks and stalls the game. The idea is probably more realistic than "fuel cells" but it kills game dynamics, exploration and element of surprise. Game also generates lots of dead end systems for the galaxy. It makes defending systems easier but attacks (rare occasion) become from predictable direction. Population growth of planets is snail pace even on terrain planets which adds to the slowness. AI is also quite passive and pacifist. After around 100-150 turns, something interesting, perhaps your first combat, might happen. 

Overall, there is far too few combat scenarios. Just micromanaging your colonies is not great fun. Passive AI doesn't bring much spark to the game: races pretty much keep to themselves and they have same boring tactics. Diplomatic event system is worse than MOO2. Races won't contact much and if they do, they mostly request attacking another race just to get your hands dirty since they don't fight much for themselves. I think even MOO1 had more realistic AI behavior in regards to diplomacy. AI mostly refuses to trade tech at all and always wants 100% better deals. At least audio-visually races in diplomacy screen are excellent with their animations and voice acting.

Next one is a biggie: space combats are gaming-wise boring. There is pretty much no means to strategize. What you do is pick your targets and press play and see how it goes. There is really nothing much you can do in that real time hassle besides sit back and watch. If you have stronger fleet, you win. As for visual aspects, combat looks okay but the arena is large, so your camera needs to be set far apart to can see everything. Thus, the ships will be tiny and visual treat (also audio) is not good. Battles are the salt of MOO and failure in that area is considerable. Also, designing ships is tedious process, one that used to be fun. Full screen modal makes it hard to compare selections total effect (pops up for choosing each slot), design view ui-elements waste screen estate and going through the whole process requires lots of clicks. Weapons and specials don't show proper damage stats but instead some abstract power number which makes different weapons generic. "Beam B makes 25% more damage than beam A, yay". Another miss there. And what about ground combat? Lets just say MOO1 had more thrilling ground combat. Next I'd consider music and sfx which are forgettable and quite lame. The only good track is the combat victory music, which should be in the place of actual battle music theme (theme is from MOO1). If you are doing a remake then at least copy the good parts. 

Spying system is improved from previous installment (comparing to MOO2 since third one is turd) and now you have "hero" like spies with experience stats. Only problem is that they cost too much to maintain and you can't have many of them. But you can do more with them, like assassinate leaders and halt research ("hack"), albeit slowly. Game only supports maximum of seven leaders (colony AND ship) which is not enough. I had six ship leaders and only one colony leader. Makes no sense. Leaders themselves are, yet again, generic, having only two different bonus powers and their icons are boring. MOO2 leaders had more "personality".

Clearly some corners have been cut to finish the game. Galaxy council with voting system is no more - if you are powerful enough after 500 turns, you win the game. And they even didn't bother to make ending cut scene and the game just jumps back to main menu after accepting the victory from the glorious modal popup window. The intro at the beginning is the only cut scene you'll get. Not even defeating Orion's Guardian gives you anything special. There is a voice over when you free planet held hostage by space pirates but that's all the extra you get. Lack of polish is apparent in technical level too: save games start taking 250MB per slot, GPU runs 100% even when nothing happens on main screen,...

Not everything is bad though. With all of its flaws, game is fine for one play trough but next time I'd rather pick MOO2 (or even the original) again if I need my dose of Orion. Cautiously recommend for noobs and nostalgics but this could have been a lot better.

This is a competent and in some points very well-done recreation of the original Master of Orion spirti. Master of Orion and its sequel Master of Orion 2: Battle at Antares were genre-defining titles. They stablished many things we now take for granted, and have a huge weight in many gamers' nostalgic memories — including myself: I have played steadily MOO2 (and, to a lesser degree, MOO1 and even Star Lords) for over two decades. MOO3 was something of a disappointment (although I liked the starlanes and the politics / diplomacy route it took).

Like me, many people have strong feelings for the series, and living up for those expectations is an impossible task. What do you do? Recreate faithfully the past or innovate and take risks exploring towards the future? The latter might turn out well, but it wouldn't be the MOO we grew up with. This is what happened, to a degree, with MOO3, and one of the reasons why it had a poor reception.

I think the developers here took the right choice. They have recreated a blend of MOO and MOO2 with a few newer elements (the aforementioned starlanes, for example) which have been tested in other games and even the third installment and work well and don't disturbe the basics. 

About 99% of the game you will see is a present-day recreation of the original spirit, down to the cheesy Galactic News Network take on events. The original MOO games wer never *too* hard-line science-fiction. They had an adequate rooting on the tropes of the genre and incorporated pulp fiction elements as necessary, and that works well as part of the mix. In this rendition the races are more humanoid than in other variants (silicoid used to be less like stone golems, for example), which is a bit of a turn down but at the same time allows them to have recognizable expressions like becoming happy or sad when they win a vote in the galactic council or diplomacy screens.

As said, the original content is there, and then some. We have the basic races, we have the space monsters, the antarans and the Orion guardian. We have the galactic council and the micromanagement of planets. We have the classic technology trees with phasors and structural analyzers and battle pods and titan construction. We have diplomatic treaties with peace and non agression pacts and war and trade options which actually work, and research investments expensive but which turn out well. We have new, interesting non-spacefaring civilizations with which you can interact too. 

I genuinely feel happy for this version of MOO. It basically brings back to life mostly the better parts of very dear pieces from my gaming past.

If I have a criticism, it is perhaps that the interface could be better designed. Not only by modern standards, but by the original games' too. For example, the «planets» screen in MOO2 allowed you to browse known empty planets and send colony ships to them directly from that screen, whereas I can't find a way to do that in this new interace. Likewise, navigating fleets can sometimes be confusing — it was never easy, mind you, because it is frequent that you will have to tend to lots of different fronts at the same time, but I feel it could be improved somehow. Perhaps allowing to create  fixed fleets with assigned names or symbols to locate them easily?

It is also... not too fast. Both hardware-wise (the graphics are cool and I understand that takes up CPU and GPU cycles, but I feel this is a bit unoptimized) and gamepace-wise. In this latter aspect I think MOO2 or MOO played a bit faster, with «empty» turns being skipped more easily, enemy actions happening quicker, and getting you to the meat of the action and decision-making faster. I have found that playing this MOO version is not something for a quick break: you'll play for a few hours at a time. This is fine with me, but I think it should be noted. The turn-based nature already means you can control pace, so having the game add a degree of slowness to it can turn off some people.

The ship design screen could also be improved. I liked the way it worked in MOO2 — the main screen was focused on which weapons you loaded, which systems, the statistics of them all, and this allowed to create truly specific designs. I used to create ships based around the gyro destabilizer, for example, to damage the structural integrity of opponents, or ships solely for bombing or boarding. Often I had very specific fleets with one-of-a-kind ships in them for very specific purposes, like defeating the Orion Guardian or boarding and adding to my fleet ships from other races. I haven't been able to do this yet with this version of MOO, and it is a bit of a disappointment, but I am still exploring the larger aspects of the game before I delve too deep into that kind of micromanagement.

I could go on, but this is long enough as it is. Just let me stress it again: I can understand why people find it slow-paced for nowadays standards, and I can see why some people find it not original. I don't think it is trying to be imaginative either. It is what it is: a faithful as possible recreation of the original titles with a few actualisations and variations. For that, it works quite well, and I'm really glad to have it.

This would have been a great game if it were released 2006 - 2009. Don't get me wrong, it is not a bad game; it's just not that great. The graphics are solid, and the interface is smooth, intuitive and easy to use. The game is well balanced, easy to understand, and it does a good job at showing the player what the impacts of actions and decisions will be when presented with them. It contains all the essentials that make a good Space 4X game. 

However, the gameplay is blatantly dated, lacking complexity, depth, growth potential, replay value, variety, etc... of its contemporaries. It is a remake of MoO 2, with some rebalancing and a tech tree from the Civ franchise. For a truly excellent 4X, you're better off playing Stellaris.

After seeing the previews for Master of Orion, I decided to grab it even though it was still in early access.  Having put in over 300 hours I think I can provide my honest opinion on the game.  I have been a fan since I played the first Master of Orion back in the dos days, and can say I'm fairly happy with the direction this game took.

First, the cons:

I know this is a personal preference kind of thing, but I dislike the starlanes.  It does change the strategic nature of empire building, by allowing you to create a secure place with defensible choke points, but a major part of the MOO1 and 2 (We don't talk about 3....) was having to take into consideration the fact that any colony could be attacked, and to have to juggle fleet positioning accordingly.  I know it's kind of a nitpick, but it does play a role when I'm trying to decide if I want to play this or Galactic Civilizations.

Camera controls during combat.  They're a bit difficult to get into the right position and zoom rapidly.  While you have full freedom to pause combat, it's primarily real time and fighting with the camera to see what you need can be frustrating.

Turn based combat. I know this was kind of an afterthought put in after fan response, and it feels like it.  It's really nothing more than the game auto-pausing ever few seconds.  An option to have it instead pause whenever one of your ships had an action ready, or just when a weapon was ready to fire, I think, would have made it feel at least a little more turn-based and control-able.

Ship design.  While the visual design of the ships are creative, and each race having a design aesthetic is also cool, having more options in the visual department would have been nice, or at the very least, providing mod support for new ship visual designs I feel would have improved things considerably.  Also, limiting ship slots for smaller ships seems unnecessary, as there is already a limitation with the space available, it feels like an unneeded constraint.  This one however can be addressed by mods, so it's not a huge complaint.

Racial characteristics.  Some of the racial bonuses and weaknesses felt like they didn't effect gameplay as much as they should have.  For the most part, it felt like you could basically follow the same formula to build your empire no matter which race you played, while in 1 and 2, you really had to focus on your strengths, because your weaknesses would cripple you otherwise.

Now the Pros:

Visual design.  This looks like a proper upgrade from Master of Orion 1 and 2.  While I felt there could be more ship designs available, those that are there look great, and tie in nicely with the philosophy of the races they represent.

Empire management I feel is a step forward.  I feel it's a good balance between the simplified abstraction of MOO1 and the sometimes overwhelming micromanagement of MOO2.  You still have to construct buildings for specific purposes, like in 2, but the autobuild AI is greatly improved, so you don't necessarily have to focus on what each planet is doing.  I found, especially in late game, just setting a plan and turning on autobuild was more than sufficient to keep a large empire manageable, allowing me to focus on building fleets.

Voice acting.  The cast is great, and give some fun life to the races and advisors, you definitely feel the personality of each race more than ever.

Mod support.  This is probably the biggest pro in my book, and supporting modders and allowing them into most aspects of the game is what keeps me coming back to this one more than MOO1 or 2.  There are mods that address nearly every part of the game, allowing you to tailor it more into what you want.   My only gripe here is the lack of support for a very few aspects of the game: starlanes, which I can understand as that may be an essential part of the code that might break the game if changed, and ship visuals, which I mentioned before I feel mod support would have greatly improved the game by allowing more visual options.


All said, I can say I was not disappointed with Master of Orion.  It did a fairly good job of taking the best parts of the previous games and crafting an enjoyable experience that really did feel like a Master of Orion sequel.  Admittedly, it doesn't break any new ground, and some gameplay choices do have me dividing my time between it and Galactic Civilizations 3 for my space conquest fix, but it does feel like the sequel Master of Orion 3 should have been, and hopefully now that they've got the franchise back in production, maybe we'll see some new stuff if they go forward with a sequel.

Overall, if you're a fan of the series, I recommend giving this reboot a try.

While MOO is a good game I can recomend, it does come with its own reservations on it.

The game itself is a really streamlined masterpiece, however it also means its a really simplified version of the genre.

As 4x goes, MOO is simple, although it does hit all the basics. Economic control with planet buildings, Espionage with spies, basic exploration and combat expectations. You have some modular freedom with ship design, however it remains restricted enough that you can't really get that creative with it. It works, but it has its faults - graphics hits me allot with how the animation of the ships are all basically copy-paste for the models and the weapons just emit from the center of it making it almost all look the same.

Where it falls short in my opinion is where you'd expect more complexities, it really is simplified down. The AI support is helpful to the point where you almost run on autopilot short of ship designs - and those can almost be ignored thanks to the larger numbers game. Ship design itself is limited to being modular, while it said it as a good point, it only makes it so far as a good idea for newer players - you have very limited options on the ship design and weapon loadouts thanks to limitations with its real time combat style. You have some freedom with weapon arcs, but the mixture of AI function with real-time speed on combat you loose out on some turn-based control you could have had. It does make the fights look nice however.

The largest drawback in my opinion is in the race customization. It feels extremely limited, and unless I missed it somewhere, you can't save the custom race creations.

In general, the streamlined nature and relatively simple feel lends itself to be a good version of 4x, however veterans of the genre will be left wanting more somewhere in it.

If you're looking for a wall of text -- I don't do reviews that way.

With that said, overall, I'd recommend this game.  It's already a lot of fun at this early point.  However, as someone that played the original MoO and MoO 2 (mostly the latter), it doesn't feel quite right just yet.

I think the game is off to a good start, and if the developers keep moving in a positive direction, this will be a B+ game easily when it's officially released.

The game is definitely not ready for an official release just yet though, so don't buy this unless you're a fan of the series and don't mind playing something that's not quite finished yet.

I've seen other 4X strategy games before, but never got into them. This, however, was one game that had my interest, especially with the excellent voice cast like Mark Hamill and John De Lancie! 

Gameplay wise, I enjoy the unique and varied races with their different traits which, despite having the same structures and ship classes, make their race standout. The ship designs are cool and the ship builder is cool, allowing you to make your own loadouts for each ship. Unfortunately, unlike Galactic Civilizations 3, you can't design ships piece by piece to make some unique designs. You just have 2 base models and a few themes (paint patterns). Also, you only have 8 blueprint slots once you unlock the doom star. you unlock a new slot each time you unlock a new ship, however this leaves you with only enough room for 2 unique blueprints to design from scratch. HOWEVER I grew to not mind this as much because this does force you to give each ship a ROLL, besides just varying amounts of damage dealing. There is more then enough tech in the game to equip each ship type with different builds. I've go a battleship that focuses on energy damage and also releases repair drones to help my fleet stay in the fight longer, You could also make a ship an evasive cloaked craft with a short range teleport to escape from harm during emergencies. You can do alot, but you have to pick and choose. I would like the OPTION to change the number of blueprints a player is allowed as custom rules, but I don't hate this limitation as much as I thought I would. It allows you to make a fleet that feels distinct, instead of just having anything and everything available at any given time, making your fleets "identity" become faded.

The map is very "customizable" during a match. When you unlock terraforming it allows you to turn low quality planets into valuable, hospitable planets. One of the end-game weapons allows you to blow up planets and turn them into asteroids, which then can be transformed into a large or huge barren planet! this could be great for getting rid of small planets with extremely hostile conditions like toxic and radiated! Just make a new planet, that'll solve it! (haven't tried it yet.) 
One minor complaint though is how there is a player limit of 9. I'd like a map just big enough to include one of every race so you can experience dealing with ALL of them. Not a deal breaker, and more then 9 could make this game a chaotic and crowded.

Diplomacy is cool, forming alliances with other races, signing treaties which grant mutual benefits, getting tech early, etc. Also spies and espionage is cool. You can steal starcharts, slow their research progress, and more! Allies are surprisingly valuable in this game. The fact that you can't unlock ALL the tech in the game by research alone,  makes it so you are seeking out other races to acquire the tech that you didn't pick during research.  

Compared to what I've seen of other 4X strategy games, this is probably the most user-friendly and accesable I've seen. Others were obnoxiously complicated and felt like the dragged on during gameplay. 

Combat features include real time combat which can be sped up or slowed down, however it feels a tad inconsistant. start of a battle may be paused, so you take the time to issue orders individually (because ordering a cluster sends the movement lines freak out sime times.) and they move where you tell them to, but sometimes they go somewhere else. Also, the "hold position button" doesn't seem to work while time is paused. The response time and more may need to be addressed.

Overall, this was a fun game and I enjoy listening to the cast react when you are in diplomatic talks with at least one, the tech variety is great, though the option of more blueprints would be nice. 

I do recommend this game, it has a great sound track, cool ships, customizable map, and an awesome cast!

TL:DR - This game plays like an all time favorite, and I would certainly recommend it to anyone into 4X style games.

PROS: This game is a great trip into the land of nostalgia for those of us who have played the originals! Much more like Master of Orion 2 than M.O.O. 3, containing the familiar races and traditional MOO gameplay, but obviously with updated graphics and a few tweaked game mechanics. The cinematic style battles are fairly nice to watch and command too, if you aren't the type to just auto-resolve every encounter. The game didn't feel as dry and clunky as M.O.O. 3, and all victory styles are plausible.

CONS: No new ground broken here, just a rehash of MOO2 with a new skin and cinematics, with some updated mechanics. The game's auto-update feature for ship technology is basically useless, and provides some fairly wasteful and unstrategic ship builds in my opinion. I also find Normal difficulty to be too easy, and hard to be bit too difficult, but that's probably just me. Some of the achievements are super hard, but then again, I claimed to enjoy the game, not be that I was any good at it. ;)

Two of my favorite games of all time are X-Com and Master of Orion (from the 1990's).  Each had sequels that gradually got worse until they sort of disappeared.  Thankfully complete remake/re-imaginings have come out that did what most fans wanted. Keep the races and basic mechanics but using the graphics that are so beautiful today.

This new Master of Orion really is beautiful. Playing it made me feel like it did back then and that's what I wanted. I'm not going to go deep into differences, improvements, non-improvements, etc.  There are professional reviews that fixate on these things.  The highest compliment I can give and the strongest recommendation I can offer is that if you loved the feel of the first game then you will probably love this version as much as I do.

Basically this is a graphics upgrade of the classic Master of Orion 2 with one major game play difference, space battles are in real time.  While this major change in gameplay mechanic from the classic initially infuriating to those who wanted a pure update to the classic, it's not that bad once you figure out dodging torpedoes and continually issuing targeting orders to your ships to ensure they are targeting officially (nothing like watching your entire fleet decide to lobby their entire load of torpedoes at one frigate).  Diplomacy and trade is pretty much broken with the AI.  You end up having to build your economy strong enough to be able to afford to give the AI enough BC to sign trade agreements with you.

Even with the questionable choice of switching to real time combat, and the diplomacy let down, it's still worth playing if you really liked the classic or never played it and would like to try this modernized proxy.  I see this game heavily discounted on the store page quite frequently, and is worth it at those prices.

 It certainly has flaws and shortcomings that trouble a bunch of players, the first example being star lanes which a lot of people seem to dislike.

Despite these things that don't stay "true" to the originals, the Aesthetics of the whole game are just gorgeous:
[list]
[*]The voice actors for each race are absolutely fantastic for each of the races and their respective advisors
[*]Race visual and cultural design, whether it is completely made of sci-fi or inspired by existing ones, is mindblowing.
[*]The planets, the backgrounds, and the stars are just nice and the interface is not bad.
[/list]
While I'm not sure how better the game could have been in gameplay and balance, I can absolutely say that as a universe with great visuals, aesthetics, characters and whoknowswhatelse, this is absolutely perfect.

And even with all of that, there's modders who gladly keep bringing life to this game to make it even more betterer, with more balance, features, more visuals or even wacky things.

MoO2 is one of the greatest games ever made, and I've played it since release.  There was a lot of negativity surrounding this Orion game for a long while and that kept me from trying it out.  I finally gave into my curiosity.  

It's not MoO2, but nothing is.  It is, in actuality, a very serviceable, approachable, streamlined game that is deserving of 4X players attention.  Simplified but not necessarily dumbed down, it may not have the complexity of some others but it's kind of relaxing.  

Graphics are a bit goofy, UI is clean, encountered no bugs (I am using the two most heavily recommended mods that seem to address most issues however), never felt the AI was cheating nor asleep at the wheel.

Give it a shot.

By means of complexity and variety Master of Orion is one of the less ambitious 4X space strategy games out there today. This is not necessarily a flaw however. It comes down to what kind of experience you want personally from your strategy game as a player. Master of Orion reminds me heavily of Civilization. You build colony ships like settler units and colonize parts of the map, you manage your population in your planets (cities) to produce either production, food or science. You produce science every turn to advance technology in a vast tech tree. You can upgrade your ships and units constantly, and make your own designs. Although the cosmetic portion of the ship designer is quite limited. You seek to unite the galaxy either by conquest or diplomacy. This all is very familiar stuff, but it has it's fans.

What the game design of Master of Orion lacks in originality, it gains in quirky personality. There is something undeniably cute in every race. This is due to cartoonish visuals and design with decent voice acting to boot. Every race has their unique personality and character. The races are familiar from the classic Master of Orion games, so the fans of the originals will find their home here.

So far I have not encountered many bugs. Due to simplistic presentation, the performance is excellent too. Unlike the processor power gulping Civilization games, in Master of Orion the turns are processed quite fast in the largest maps up to the late game, in both single and multiplayer games. Multiplayer works superbly well too. The game is at it's best at 5 am with your friend anyway. Rather than the usual "one more turn" -formula, Master of Orion has become more like "one more war" for me and my friends.

So, if you're looking for a simplistic, yet charming 4X space opera strategy game with superb multiplayer capabilities and great performance, look no further. Orion is waiting for your colony ship.

This is a remastered Master of Orion, and it's FANTASTIC. There is a lot of love put into this game, and one of the few games not plagued by bugs.

Like the original franchise, you have all the original races, except they have beautiful 3D models whose reactions change based on your actions. Just a couple examples - I was playing Terran as a warmongering star empire, whenever I engaged in relations with the other races they had a look of hopelessness about them, you could really feel what they were thinking. "Are we next in line for destruction?" - I ran a peaceful diplomatic human empire, and the ai were eager to speak to me in interest of mutual technology or alliance. They are very realistic responses. It remains faithful to the turn-based 4x spirit, and it feels very clean and polished. To top it all off, we have famous voice actors like Alan Tudyk (Firefly, Knight's Tale, Zootopia), John Delancy (Q, Star Trek: TNG, Star Trek: DS9, etc.) and Mark Hamill (Star Citizen, Luke Skywalker in the original trilogy, Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope [1977], Etc.) voicing the characters, and if you thought that was badass, MICHAEL DORN (Worf, Star Trek: TNG / Star Trek: DS9) narrarates what is happening as the events unfold, he also reads off the races' biographies to you.

This is more than just a callback to the first master of orion games, this is a callback to the golden age of sci-fi. The love, dedication, and effort put into this game is obvious, and I for one choose to be excited and embrace the fact that here are game developers working hard to give us that same feeling of awe and wonder we felt the first time we saw Picard as captain of the Enterprise, or Luke Skywalker as he traveled to Dagobah to learn the mysteriums of the force, rather than complaining like a spoiled child because daddy didn't get him THAT toy.

If you don't like it, fine, but complaining that it's not your perfect game is not a valid review, sorry kiddo. Unfortunately, like very much of today's society, most reviewers just want to bitch about the surface of the game - none of them consider the difficulties that comes with coding a game, the tedious hours spent fixing a bug whose cause you have zero insight on, and the difficulties in working around the busy schedules of famous actors.

In fact, 90% of steam reviews come from people who have never coded before or worked a day in their life - games despite actual quality are subject to even the slightest inconvenience if a freshman in high school would much rather complain about a black-screen (which only they seem to have) instead of figuring out how to fix their own system.

Overall, this is a beautiful labor of love - the quality, polish and dedication is obvious. Despite the competition from Stellaris and Civilization, as well as the bloated expectations of ye olde MOO players - this is a blue diamond that shines brightly even in the darkest regions of abyssal caverns.

Feel free to get angry at me kiddos, this won't affect how I feel for this great game.

MoO2 was all about micromanage and tried to correct the massive stacks of ships in mid/late game of the original- it failed IMO, it became a borefest and made for long drawn out games that should have ended/restarted long before
MoO3 tried to stay with the original concept while trying to reinvent the wheel with combat, the only fail part was the combat was to constrained.
now we come to this remake of the game, it's been abandoned and there are a lot of mods out there for it trying to make it like each persons favorite version of the game series. MODS are nice when they enhance game play or add a few new things to a game. When you use mods to make one game look and play like another just go play the other game.
This version of MoO is a good game, it has some slowdown issues with late game between turns as it processes a lot of information, it could have been optimized in that area better, but people are jaded and used to MMO style games that run on what amounts to supercomputers and distributed servers, there is no noticeable time lag for their computation and they also employ people to keep that system working and optimized, you don't get that on a single player game especially when the game was basically 90% finished then abandoned.
this game has a lot going for it, but those who are rabid fanboi's of MoO2 will always scream and yell unless it is a remake with modern GFX of that. Ignore those reviews that compare it to or call it a poor remake of 2.

Master of Orion is a remake of MoO2 with some upgrades. This game is not nearly as flawed as people claim. 

This game is in a tough spot, pitted against the warm fuzzies people have for its predecessor. I love MoO2 with all my heart but let's not pretend it didn't have flaws too.

Master of Orion is enjoyable in the early game, fantastic even. I really enjoy the warp point system, the AI seems less random, and the UI is pretty intuitive. I also appreciate that it's a lighter and more accessible 4X game.

Later on things get sluggish, and the AI seems to kinda slow down and stop expanding at a certain point. I typically play small maps because huge ones really bog down. Mega battles are prone to freezing. I don't personally love the switch to RTS combat but that may just be me.

I definitely recommend the unofficial patch and 5x mods, they offer balance and bug fixes.

If this goes on sale, and you use the Universal Code Patch and 5X mods, then it's not a bad game as far as the gameplay goes. However, lategame on any decent size map will cause the game to freeze up between turns for so long that windows thinks it's unresponsive. It's a masterpiece of un-optimized crap. (And I'm using a freshly built PC with a Ryzen 2700x and Vega64 so not-brand-new PCs will run it even worse.)

I seriously haven't seen lag between turns this bad since I was running Civ 1 on a 286 with greyscale EGA graphics. How do they even manage that shit? It's not like the logic behind the game or AI is particularly advanced. MOO2 seems like it had more going on in that department than this new MOO.

If you must have some MOO, I'd suggest going back to MOO2. If any decent modern 4x in space will do, Stellaris is probably a better option, if more expensive after all the DLCs. If you want any 4x in general, well, Master of Magic is still my favorite 25 years later, and it can run on anything via the magic of dosbox.

Basically, a less polished Master of Orion 2 remaster would of done a lot better and been received better.

You can see the Devs really loved Master of Orion and wanted to make a Modern version of the game. The problem is there are better modern 4X games (compared to this) and they dumbed down a lot of what made MoO good.

Which means is become a decent game, not as good as the Classics but it's the best MoO with modern graphics.

Is it worth buying? Yes... if you like MoO enough and it has Mod Support so likely the game will be made a lot better over time and get closer to MoO2.

There are several games that I will return to again and again, MoO2 is one of them. That being said, this edition does well to capture the feeling of that classic. The updated graphics and sound are also a welcome addition. My only major gripe is that the addition of auto build features and a much easier AI make it feel like it on training wheels. I liked the first and the second game. The third game did not happen. What third game? What are we talking about?

Oh yeah, this is the real third game. It has a lot in common with the second game, so if you liked moo2, this will look familiar.

What's different?

UI is streamlined, you don't have to micromanage so much any more.

There are lines connecting systems and you can build guard stations to defend choke points. You can thus wall yourself off.

The ship-to-ship combat is real time with pause. Yes, I miss the second game's turn-based approach, it was good times. This is different, but it's tricky different, not dumbed-down different. A lot of abilities and ship design work together to allow the player to create interesting units - like broad side battleships that focus on strafing enemies, smaller craft perhaps that can kite the enemy and teleport behind them, and then run away with backward-facing guns pummeling the whole time. 

You can ignore all that and just focus on building the bigger fleet with more guns and auto-resolve fights with brute force approach, but there's depth and nuance if you care to explore it.

Also, the spy system here is really interesting, and far more involved than in moo2. You can trade captured spies for ransom. The stealth suit tech is OP, even if your species aren't the Darloks.

Also I should compare this to Stellaris. Stellaris is a more modern game, it has quest text and events and a ton of stars and planets and ships: there's a lot going on and there is a lot of real estate for it to go on. This is a smaller scale game, where there's less stuff to conquer, but also every ship matters, because you have a lot fewer of them. Likewise, fewer enemies, and thus diplomacy is more intimate and thus more dangerous. Stellaris doesn't allow you to micromanage a ship battle, it's just a game of numbers and a big ol' retreat button. Here, the fights can be won on a technicality of a better ship design and clever positioning.

Late game doesn't suffer from micromanagement nightmare thanks to the new shiny UI, but it can get stale once you realize you're winning but still go through the motions of conquering everything. There are no world-shattering events the way Stellaris throws them at you.

In Stellaris, warfare has rules, meant to prevent wholesale slaughter and early steamroll positive feedback effect. Wars get forcibly shut down if they drag on too long (your people are tired, have a forced truce). No such hand-holding in this game. You can try diplomacy but your mileage may vary.

In conclusion, both games are worth playing and offer distinctly different experiences.

II don’t understand why this game has such mixed reviews, this was the first real RTS game I was actually able to understand and it’s kept my attention for a LONG time now. There are so many ways to play and win, and so many species to play as. Sure, some species are locked behind DLC, but its a miniscule amount compared to all of the ones available to you. The diplomacy-centric Humans, the masterful pilots of the Alkari, the hardy Bulrathi colonizers, the stealthy infiltrators of the Darlok, the fierce ground forces of the Mrrshan, the planet-eating Silicoid rock people, the fast-reproducing Sakkra, the highly advanced and intelligent Psilons, the hive-minded Klackon infestation, and lastly, the cybernetic industrials of the Meklar. Veteran RTS gamers will find it a refreshingly consistent reboot of a game from the time they began playing, and gamers new to the whole RTS scene will find it easy to learn without needing to adapt as extremely as some other RTS games.

In my opinion, this game is underrated. It is not the best, but fairly decent at least.

Main problem of "Master of Orion" is... its name. "Master of Orion" has a huge community of so-called oldschool gamers, and this game got caught into inevitable trap... developers tried to mimic successful previous parts so fans claimed that game is boring and brings nothing new. Still, if developers tried to actually create something new, same fans would claim that game does not continues traditions and so it is bad. Well, I still remember "Master of Orion 3", where developers tried to invent something different... and I still remember how it ended.

So. "Master of Orion" tries to be similar to old classic games. Almost all gaming mechanics are copied from "Master of Orion 2", and developers did it quite carefully. You may play as one of pre-generated races or create your own specie with its own strengths and weaknesses. You will colonise and develop planets, design ships, contact with other space powers and - almost inevitably - fight with them. In my opinion, "Master of Orion" is designed as a game about war. Maps are fairly small and borders are tight so neighbours are quickly turn into rivals. There is a diplomatic way to victory, but diplomacy is very simple and not too effective, so eliminating all opposition seems much easier for me.

And there comes main issue that prevented me from finishing this game. Wars are very easy, when you created a good fleet able to defeat neighbours - you won. Final part of game turns into tedious and boring process of cleaning map from rival factions and they just can not stop you. Even on high difficulty. While first part of game seems interesting and early wars may be even challenging, final part of game is... just boring. 

For example, in late game you do not need to wory abot economic, just set all new planets on optimal path and forget about them. You do not need to worry about fleet battles either, just launch auto-combat and forget. You may try to command your ships manually but results will be same anyway. And ground combat is just auto-calculation anyway, just bring some dropships with troops to the orbit of enemy planet and... that is it. Thanks to "classic gameplay", for more or less experienced player game quickly becomes very predictable. So... I dropped it.

I do not want to say that "Master of Orion" is a bad game. It is a good game, developers did a very good job. Unfortunately, it just can not compete with other representatives of genre, such as "Galactic Civilizations", "Space Empires" or "Distant Worlds".

I may recommend you to purchase "Master of Orion" if you are not very experienced with 4X strategic genre. This game can be an excellent introduction into genre, it offers classic gameplay, provides good introduction into basic conceptions of 4X and looks quite pretty. For your first 4X strategic game - "Master of Orion" is an excellent choice. By other side, if you are familiar with genre, "Master of Orion" is not the best choice as it is fairly simple; so, I guess, experienced player will find this game not very entertaining.

Finally, I must bring some compliments to visual part of game. "Master of Orion" looks great, it is a beautiful game, especially when it comes to diplomatic screen - every faction is animated and voiced, it looks really good. Still... visuals are not the most important part of any strategic game.
Very cool game. You should try mods aswell

This game seems to take after MOO3 more than MOO2, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. Star lanes are here to stay, and they make the game more positional/allow chokepoints, which people seem to love or hate. They also have specific star lanes that can only be crossed after research. Combat is real time again. The extreme accuracy drop off of beam weapons makes it a bit screwy and takes some getting used to. On the other hand, that means missiles and torpedoes are actually a thing.

Graphics look nice, ships are in 3d and look way better than MOO3, Races are better animated and feel just a little more alive. Custom races are still a thing. Preset races get more in terms of trait points than you can get with custom, but custom is still better, of course. And, as always, they aren't exactly balanced. Think of them as a difficulty adjustment. The Galactic News robots that periodically comment on the state of things are either fun or annoying, depending on your personality, and they can be disabled. Pirates and pirate bases are a thing, but you quickly become so much more powerful, they might as well not exist.

One more thing, the Antarians/Orions/whatever they are are back, and meaner than ever. They are intentionally scaled to be more powerful than all your ships combined and attack the most powerful player periodically. They destroy a planet and then leave, but usually keep attacking the same planet. Just think of it as you're going to sacrifice that planet into being forever near barren unless you have the foresight to disable the gimmick.

Overall, the game is a satisfying MOO experience. If you're something of a MOO2 purist, you might hate it, but otherwise, it should be fun to conquer the galaxy a couple of times.

I really don't understand all the hate on this game.
Sure, some features are poorly implemented, there isn't any tactical combat in multiplayer, nobody ever really plays multiplayer at all, and the stock races are severely unbalanced (looking at you Meklars), but that doesn't really matter.

The 5X mod and UCP fix most of the game's flaws (fixing the bugs and balancing the game, as well as giving it more depth than ever before), and I personally don't care about the lack of multiplayer options. For me, it's about the single-player experience. The graphics are great, the real-time combat is an interesting twist on the systems of past titles, and it's so good to see that people still care about this series. The devs have abandoned the game, but the community has revived it.

In short: This game is good value for money (you should still wait for a sale though) and anyone telling you it's utterly  broken is just ignorant.

Master of Orion: Conquer the Stars is a turn-based 4x space strategy game that is essentially a 3D remake of the classic Master of Orion II (1996). As a fan of MoOII, I have some bias here, and many comparisons will be made. While MoO:CTS offers some improvements to the series, it also comes with questionable design decisions. 

Gameplay is your usual randomly generated galaxy map where you issue commands to expand your empire and research technologies. What differentiates MoO from most strategy titles is that combat is handled in a separate tactical screen, allowing greater control of how battles play out. Combat is this game is in real time, and in many cases, is handled on autopilot. While I appreciate that is resolved quickly, it's unfortunate that it's far less engaging and simplified. Ground combat is a severe downgrade as well, and there's no ship boarding at all. While MoOII offered a myriad of options to win a battle, here it's greatly stripped down.

Somewhat unusual is the implementation of star lanes. Ships may only travel between star systems using these star lanes without special tech, and thus it becomes possible to create choke points and see when enemy fleets approach several turns in advance. I don't hate the star lanes, but I also think the game would have been better off without them.

Race creation makes a return, and as with all games that allow it, I spent hours playing with it. Most picks are the same as MoOII, but there are noteworthy changes, mostly for the sake of balance. There's a few bizarre picks though, most notable being the biome options which despite costing points, may actually be harmful to pick.

The game offers several win conditions, which allows for varied gameplay styles... sort of. Typically, rushing through opponents seems to be the best way to win, but I found it more fun to go for other victory types such as defeating the Antarans. The ending cinematics could stand to be more grand though. Every time I beat the game it just felt like "meh."

For the most part the graphics and aesthetics are great. I love the ships, the planets, cinematic combat, and... some of the races. The user interface felt like a downgrade though, going for a rather simplistic scheme. I feel like there's a lot of wasted assets. For example, all advisor tips are voiced and unique to each race, but I can't imagine wanting to hear everything multiple times when they could have just gone with one. GNN also has a lot of animations, but I shut that off fairly early. The music is all right - not quite as melodic or immserive as MoOII, but never grating. Does any one else feel that the title music sounds oddly similar to Galactic Civilization II's title theme? 

Performance is an issue with this game, and for me the biggest thing holding it back. Anything larger than a medium galaxy takes ages. If I had a computer that could calculate turns in mere seconds, I'd probably be playing this game a bunch more. The game is generally bugless as far as I can tell, which is good.

Overall I rate Master of Orion a B. I had fun with it, enough to replay quite a few times. But at the same time, I occasionally felt I would rather be playing MoOII. The game supports Steam Workshop, and there are some excellent mods that add some of what is missing in the core game.

I almost forgave the misteps because of the mods for this game, but I can't recommend this for two reasons. First of all, despite having options to tweak the speed of production, research, and pop growth and having 5x to fill out the game content, you can't get around the abysmal turn performance later in the game. It makes you sit around and waste play time waiting for the game to finish processing and just saps the fun. 

[i]The second reason I can't recommend the game is that even if you run a smaller game to improve the turn processing speed, travel time just kills things. It's not fun to wait 40 turns as reinforcements are built or do nothing for 10 turns while you're ships traverse a jump gate. The net result is you wait most of the game to fight a battle that takes five minutes and requires another 50 turns to rebuild. Maybe if jumpgates or another late game tech allowed for wormhole like travel it would be fine, but as is it just doesn't give you an incentive to continue.[/i] (this section is no longer valid as it can be fixed via mods.)

While the game isn't complicated, broken, or unfun as it was in previous versions of this game, the game overall is rather disappointing. Master of Orion II was a more serious game, where alien races and dialogue showed more the realpolitik that you would expect from space civilizations. Additionally, the pollution mechanic continues to be a frustrating and delaying mechanic. In prior versions, there was a way to basically over-produce your planet and accidentally stagnate yourself. This has been moderated, but the game just makes pollution brutal still.

Exploration is no longer macro-level but now micro-level and the over-complication of space structures one can build (while not properly explaining why I can or cannot build the structure) leaves exploration boring, and leaving you with an overall feeling that you cannot exploit your exploration. In fact, it feels like in an attempt to modernize Master of Orion, it has lost its 4X nature (Explore, Exploit, Expand, Exterminate). Explore feels overly complicated "to add content" when it doesn't, and exploitation feels very limited. Expansion is penalized visciously, and extermination is something the AI constantly chooses.

Diplomacy, Military, Economics, all are inferior to predecessor games and equivalent games such as Endless Space or Stellaris. I had hoped the legacy would continue for Master of Orion, but it's clear that the developers simply bought the name to get buy-in from fans, not to actually meet expectations.
