Few things are more satisfying than to tinker together your ship-build, lead it into a battle and rip apart an enemy precisly with the weapons and tactics you build your vessels for.
Stars in Shadows is able to do this.
Maybe because they didn't wasted so much money for actors like Mark Hamill vor their fucking voiceacting (which is good, but often so repetitive and pungent that you turn it off anyway).

This game looks pretty, it is an mediocre 4x game (modded), but i won't recommend a wasted chance to revive the best space 4X game of all times caused by the ignorance of the developers and/or publishers.

And this is only one aspect.
Hyperlines, freigthers, a bollocks research system (this is fixed by mods), etc, etc.
They didn't wanted to make a modern MOO, they used the MOO licence and name too melk the francise with a half-butt made Spacegame.
They seem to tried to "balance" the gameplay to dead for fucking multiplayer, they failed, and now you got a half-butt made single player space game with the MOO name on it.

This game is exactly like Endless Space 2 except for two major differences: it doesn't punish you for doing what you're supposed to do, and it doesn't magically freeze everytime the a.i. can't figure out how to win.

I finally got a Steam account because I stumbled across this game. I used to play all 3 previous entries . As far as I know this is the game that launched the 4x style ( Civ being the biggest now) . I have a lot of nostalgia , but I think it's a 3.5 to 4 star game if I take that into consideration. It skips many of the negative aspects of MoO 3 , and is very much an updated version of MoO 2 . It's a simple turn based game , but so very enthralling. The last Civ game I played was Revolution , and I wasn't near as enraptured as I am with this installment of MoO . I have yet to dabble in mods , but I am pleasantly surprised to see many available to address whatever issues you may see , and an active player count today of over 600 people. Not bad for a genre that is not overwhelmingly popular and a seemingly lesser known name. 

TL:DR 3.75 of 5 for turn based strategy.

The ship to ship combat window is fun for the first few hours of play and then it loses the new feature lusture.  The strategical play afforded in Masters of Orion 2 (the 1990s title) has been limited by the base race traits which are skewed in implementation in this version.  For example: 
   1. Electing -25% population growth results in a significantly larger penalty, the calculation for population growth is skewed.
   2. Electing -25% food production results in a signficantly larger penalty, the calculation for population growth is skewed.
   3. Electing positive growth does not extend the full benefit either.
And those are just a few of the racial traits which are ignored or skewed by the game.  

The game does not count torpedos in the offensive capability of the ships, excessively values missiles, and electing a negative firing solution results in missed targets most of the time.  Upgrading your ships with new computers and the battle scanner does not overcome the racial negative until very late in the game.  

The game is heavily balanced towards the first 60% of the research tree, and last 40% of the research tree is achieved so rapidly by comparison that something like a Doomstar is a pointless build unless you choose to drag the game out just for that.  Your active front line ships will always be 2 versions behind the new models, because technology gains for the last 40% of the tech chart are too fast.  

I'm annoyed that they changed the Telepathic (conquer planets with mind control) from the original cruiser to a battleship, and then made it difficult to get a battleship until late in the mid-game.  The only good reason to be telepathic is to avoid making a nearly endless supply of troop transports.  

Also.. The game extends itself to static fleets with a one shot battle finale, ie. you lose 1 battle and you lose the game because it is impossible to replace the fleet if its lost. If you play with the advanced settings it is possible to push the engine to very fast production, which still isn't enough of a push to make disposable fleets although you can lose one if you have a couple of ship building planets and not immediately lose the game on extreme. The game should be better balanced, the 1990s version MOO II was.

And finally, the game is buggy, the new updates to windows 10 cause some of the wording to fail to load the correct windows fonts.  It would be nice if they issued a patch for this.  

I only play extreme, win often, and find the game fun.. with a few exceptions noted above.  If there is one feature I would like to have fixed, perhaps more than any other it would be the telepathic cruiser and the initial starting configuration for the first frigate (theirs is the worst design ever... can't bomb a pirate base without a bomb).

I have LOVED MOO since MOO2. original moo was fine but didn't grab me like 2 did. I waited eagerly for 3 and bought it in store as soon as it was released... ugh. That was a horrible, angry mess, broken game on release that I paid AAA price for and they abandoned it after only a couple minor patches that still didn't make it playable. So sad for me, I kept looking for good space 4x games, hard to find good ones. There was nothing to match MOO2... until Stellaris. oops, this is a review for MOO. So disappointed in this game, and no it's not just expectations. It's basically just a mash up of MOO2 and 3 with nearly zero improvements for the decades that have passed since each. Stellaris is the game that MOO SHOULD have been. I was so nervous to buy Stellaris after the reviews, and my experience with MOO. Even before the latest game update, I uninstalled this waste of space. I'd ask for a refund but it's too late for that.

TLDR: MOO is sad, get Stellaris instead.

I prefer this game to ES/ES2 and Stellaris.

It may not be as polished/pretty as ES2 or customizable as Stellaris but it's faster and more focused on the core 4X mechanics. It has the best ship design mechanics and the best population management mechanics (cells / diminishing returns).

The races at first seems cheesy but they are quite good to recreate other SiFi universes (Mass Effect, Enders Game, Wing Commander).

I used to play the original game many years ago and not until now, at the end of 2018 did i finally pick this "reboot" up on sale. The quick verdict: It's worth every penny.  

I'm not going to make this a very long read, but here's my reasoning.
I've ran 4 games to the finish line so far using standard settings. I tried different races and strategies every time. I haven't won a single game yet and i'm about to start my fifth. Why? Because i'm having fun. I find it challenging and entertaining and I don't bother using the poor battle-AI(use Auto-resolve) because I don't need to. For me, this type of game isn't about stressful Micro management like in an RTS. It's basically CIV without the tiles. Easy to get into, a lot harder to quit. Enjoy!

It was a fun game but not for how much they priced it. I bought it a $7.49 and though that it was really fun. I was not worth 
$30 though.

Very poor game, worse that the original by quite a distance. Gameplay is excessively slow and new introductions haven't been well balanced. 

Loved the original but have one recommendation - don't buy this game.

A true to its origin of the old classic turn based 4X game, MoO is the updated graphics and playability we all wanted in the original, while avoiding all of the harsh lessons of MoO3 and similar titles. Overall its a great game, good replayability, soliod online reliability and devoid of bugs. Its what a game should be, and fills the 4X niche perfectly.

Fully recommended.

A fun game and a good throw-back to the classic that is Masters of Orion 2. Challanging, good depth, and amazing voice acting. Only issues I have is some minor bugs here and there, how much resources it chews up, and how it has some content held back, but other then that its definately fun and enjoyable.

I played lots of MoO2 so tried this one .. its similar but feels half baked and is abandoned by devs. Its kinda fun, but its not enough in modern days and hard to recommend given the other 4X games. Its missing a main/race related story, global events, repeatable tech, race unique tech, usable and efficient automation,ship crew experience, hero skill trees.
 6/10.. only worth grabing on a sale maybe mods will improve this, didnt check yet.

Has some severe performance issues that make fleet combat unbearable in the mid- to late-game.  Overall the game's performance is pretty poor even at the best of times, which is strange given its tiny universes (compared to e.g. Endless Space or Stellaris) and rudimentary graphics.

Tends to freeze or crash occasionally (though by default it autosaves after every turn, so the impact of it crashing usually isn't a huge amount of lost time).

Ultimately it's just not fun.  There's a very large random component to whether you ultimately win or lose a game.  Furthermore, it's typical to hit a pivotal point after a few hours into a game, at which point you either lose basically instantly, or you are basically guaranteed to win (but it can take many many hours to grind through to that formal victory, which is dull and challenge-less).
It isn't as mind blowing as MoO and MoO2 were, but still a good game. If you are new to this series, then buy it without a doubt!

The GUI is not very intuitive. Haven't played much of the game, all it does is remind me how Stellaris is better and that I should play that game instead. If it is actualy a Masters of Orion, I seem to have been misguided by memory. This feels like Stellaris light to me. I can not recomanded for that fact.

LINUX USERS - BEWARE

Don't buy this game if you're a linux only user.  As of 2018 Dec. 25th the texture and graphics bugs make the game unplayable, unfortunately.

I have a hard time getting into this game.  There's lots of clicking the end turn button as your things take 50 turns to build, very few interesting anomalies to spice up exploration, the hyped voice acting is minimal, diplomacy consists of paying the AI for an embassy and then trading with them until they like you, which doesn't do much, moving soldiers or civilians is tedious, but it has all the basics covered so there is a game, I just haven't had much fun playing it so far.

Very well done, Space 4X game.

I've been playing with and without 5X mod and both are pretty good. If you are worried about the negative comments you are seeing, they are usually due to difference to older Master of Orion games. I believe this is currently one of the best modern Space 4X games in market!
pretty good, they should develope this more. I'd say make it free to play for more players. It could come with one race for free, and sell the rest.

As a fan of space 4X games, I love and hate this game. It is a watered down, over-simplified hackjob of Endless Space. That is what I hate about it. Now what I love about it is that is is an easy to play, 4X that anyone especially someone new to the genre. I mean would you stick a novice driver in a Ferrari (Stellaris)? No, you give them a Mini Cooper, you give them Masters of Orion.

Oh yeah, and the voice acting is full of A-List actors and actresses, if that makes a difference. Parents, get this for your kids and get them off COD.

I played MOO2 for ages and loved it and it is still one of my all time faves. I still play it now and then and even though it is pretty dated it is still a great game. I had high hopes for this new one and have clocked up about 80 hours playing it. Sadly I am finding it just doesn't have the same attraction as the original. The research tree is still very linear which is a huge disappointment as really you have to research almost everything. The planetary management is much the same as in the original so nothing new there either. They have tweaked the galaxy maps a bit, altered some names in the research tree and maybe added and removed some things. The real time space battles are a bit odd in a turn based game and not sure I like them very much either.
I notice there is no difficultly level choice so far and apart from my first game I have won every game I played by simply following an early game of devoting everything to colonising new planets. It doesn't seem to matter much which race you play if you use this tactic.
To be honest I think MOO2 was way more captivating than this new version so the developers need to do a lot more work to make it one of my all time faves. It isn't even close yet.
My all time faves have been about half the Civilization series, MOO2, Privateer and Alpha Centauri. Noow it is time to go play one of those instead.
As a MOO2 fan this is great. Teaming up with a friend in multiplayer to conquer the stars.
For those that know the franchise......Ehh, it's O K. Fun to play when you got nothing else to do.

Honestly, Master Of Orion II: Battle at Antares was the best.
I love that they tried to make a new one, one that's much better than the third...
Yet it doesn't really work as well as it should.
Awesome trailers for it though.

Spent hours playing the original Master of Orion titles. 
Nice pace to the game. A polished title that earns it's name.

Pretty but Dull.
Because of the fixed and predictable tech tree each game tends to unfolds the same way.
Your opponets don't have any unique and destinctive tech, they have what you have, or will have or use to have. Hardly makes it woth spying on them.

Combat is dull:
You start over here, they start over there and you charge one another. As there is very little input from the player you end up being a spectator in your own game. yay
You don't decide what to shoot or who to shoot at, the AI does that for you. 
You select a squad and the AI makes the fire decisions, usually badly.
eg A cruiser shooting at a group of frigates, it will shoot up one, take a bit off it shields then switch targets to an undamaged frigate. Nothing ever gets killed, meanwhile the frigates eventually wear you down. You will find yourself muttering "Just pick one and KILL IT" 
eg Battleship with multiple weapon batteries vs frigates. Each battery can easily vaporise a single frigate but the AI will shoot ALL batteries at one frigate vapourizing it multiple times over while the other frigates keep comming. (That when it isnt shooting up asteroids) (and I thought these gunners were supose to be professional.

Missiles no longer have ammo restaints so become just another damage X weapon.

Weapons are dull:
In Moo2 you had shield piercing weapons, armour piercing weapons, weapons which did extra crew damage and other which did extra structural damage. Different capabilities made things interesting. Thats mostly all gone
Every weapon tend to be like every other weapon, just different damage levels 
Laser Dmg 5, Rng 50
Neutron Blaster Dmg 9, Rng 50
Gravaton Cannons Dmg 25, Rng 50
same special effect, same ranges, dull

Ground combat:
Not even sure if its implemented. You can have Neutronium armour, barrier shields and plasma guns and the cave men with spears and animal skins will kill you dead. 
Invading planets is such a pain 4 men at a time.

Multiplayer
All comkbat is simulated, you  dont even get a chance to watch.
You have no idea of your opponents ship designs or weapon choices, say goodbye to intelligent ship design


Planetary governors are idiots. 
You tell them to focus on research. Yep they will do that to such an extent everyone will starve to death. When a planet maxes out population they wont scale back food production. The excess just gets dumped, Its not like you can even send it to other worlds to help them grow as every polanet is essentially independant. Your not an empire, you just a bunch of independant worlds sharing the same flag.
Even moving people between planets is such a pain as it now requires you to build one man non-reusable ship to move a single person.

Planetary growth 
Planetary growth depends on food production and not on population.
Does this mean that your people are canabels? How else to you explain why population growth depends on surpluss food.

Fleet overview: 
You will have ships and you will have no idea what there armed with as the only time it lets you inspect your ships is when you're in combat. 
The Fleet Screen is somewhat useless. Need to find out where your lost ship is, you have to go through every ship one at a time, they use unique symbols which don't mean a lot and even when you find your ship you don't know what there armed with. 
You can't even find out what the ship your currently building is armed with.

Diplomacy:
Remember when you could always rely on the Psilons accepting research treaties or Gnomorions  accepting trade treaties, not any more. Each race now has the same diplomatic personality and that personality is 'jerk' 
The AI offers you 62 credits for your star maps and gets progressivly hostile if you refuse them.
You offer them 1000 credits for their maps and they feel insulted.
Trade and research treaties now require cash and lots of it but since all the AI's tend to be broke you can never entice one into a treaty. 
Your ally will progressivly become less happy with you each time you refuse to accept a tech exchange with them.
Ally: Give us Stellar Converters we will give you Atmospheric Renewers.
You: No thanks we already have Core Waste Dumps and don't need your backward tech.
Ally: Your a meanie, -1 to approval rating. 
Ally: Give us Stellar Converters we will give you Atmospheric Renewers.
You: No thanks we already have Core Waste Dumps and don't need your backward tech.
Ally: Your a meanie, -1 to approval rating. 
You: Shut up and go away I will give you Core Waste Dumps if you give me your #$%^ Atmospherics Renewers.
Ally: Don't insult us with your pathetic trade offers.
You: Argh, please let me demonstrate the fully functional Stellar Converter on your homeworld.

Exploration:
There are worlds out there with different biomes, desert, volcanic, swamp, toxic, radioactive, etc
So what, you can settle them all, you don't need any special tech to cope with hostile conditions
they just give you less food. 

Espionage; 
I actually think the new espionage system is quite good.
You can choose different types of missions you wish to undertake.
The only downside if so can the AI. One moment your world is happy, next moment their rioting in the streets and have left the empire. No warning, no build up, pow it just is.

Game play:
I start on my own little subsector with one AI opponent and dont get to interact with the rest of the universe untill I develop a special tech which lets me travel unstable starlanes .
It's awefully contrived. 
What about starlanes that can only accomodate small ships, that way I can explore and meet new races but my ability to wage war on them is limited untill some future tech advance.
Or what about giving me the option to have unstable starelanes at all.
The AI has no clue how strategically valuable  the Multyistate Insulator or Jump gates are and often get left behind to die slowly.

Empire screen
When your sort the not so compact spreadsheet it would be nice if it remembered your sort and actually moved your scroll bar to the top of the new list.
As for sorting via production I have no idea what there actually sorting, its not alphbetical, its not production time remaining, its not buyout cost, its not planet name, I have no idea but just trying to findout when the next battle ship is due to roll off the production line and save you in your hour of need takes Sherlock Holmes to work out.

Planet screen:
Need to be able to set a Range limit when seaching for new planets to colonize. ie sort by Biomes all planets within 10 turns of travel.
It would also be nice to know that a prospective planet is actually reachable or if another faction already has claims to the solar system by colonizing another planet in that system.

Fuel:
There is none. Another piece of strategic play taken from me.

Crew XP:
Doesnt exist. It may be on its way but not yet.

Reverse engineering capture ships:
Not implemented 
Hell, you can't even capture ships anymore.

Finding tech on captured worlds 
Not implemented 

Research:
When picking between technologies it would be nice to be able to review the tech tree to see when a similar tech is available in the future.

Production
When I finish building something it would be nice to know what I was building before asking me what new item I want to build, especially when terraforming. 

Upgrades:
It would be nice to know what the AI has in mind before I select upgrade.

Bases:
It would be nice to be allowed to design your own bases.
Do I get to play this game or just observe?

Upgrading Ships is too easy, you can do it literally anywhere, build a listening post and you can magically reconfigure your ships instantly just prior to a battle with no down time. Customisen your ship at the last momement.
Why plan when you can instantly turn a defeat into victory?

It just feels so dumbed down as so many options and choices have been taken away from me.

I sincerly hope the developers reflect on what there doing.
I am just so glad that there activly trying to improve the game.

VEry Nice Game, the Ai does leave a little to be desired. There always seems to be one race who races ahead, I like how the antarans stump them... nice touch.

HOWEVER, the Development Teams Leaders have made a gross Error. Just go online and see, no one is playing. The reason, simple, very very simple. Since 2016 people have been begging to be able to play with their friends and have a nice healthy tacticcal space battle. a huge part of the fun is tweaking our ships and if we cannot see how they perform, how will we make them better or improve. SO, once again, is anyone playing online, no. Will they, no.

The worst thing about never listening to anyone, sooner or later they'll not care.

Make the multiplayer Tactical combat available. you can set limits ie 30 seconds per turn or 60,90 wtv. But most of us play which voip connected. so, make it happen. I would still invest in this game but not now. Rather go back to MOO II

Its a nice game, I recommend if on sale, but while the replayability is there, not multiplayer, very frustrating for no reason.

Exactly like the Master of Orion 2 from 1996 or 99
Nothing has changed
space battles were nerfed
there is an unnerving new feature:pirates and mines over asteroids and gas giants
and you can block your system
now you are restricted in movement
no longer warp drive but human made jump drive
and the game is not recommended
I played 21 hours in a row

Awesome sci-fi game. It's a turn based strategy game.Easy game to learn, but gets interesting when you start interacting with the other races and then the power struggles start, either its colonys or tech or even just fleet size, it all matters when dealing with your neighbors. Late game turns can take alittle while.





11/30/18 Update: Still enjoying this.

I have played, on and off, a LOT of this game. It is fantastic, great example of 4x space strategy, as well as a fun sci-fi game. I would reccomend this to anyone who enjoys 4x strategy games as well as those who enjoy space strategy games like Star Wars: Empire at war. (the galatic conquest gameplay is very much like this)
The ships are well done, graphics are solid, and it is quite well optimized.

Plus, you can get games where Worf narrates it while Luke Skywalker wants to fight you at the same time 'Q' wants to make an alliance all while Wash advises you what to research.....

10/10 would fight Luke SKywalker for control of the galaxy again.
As a fan of MoO and MoO2, this is the game that MoO3 should have been.

Single player, 10 hours or so review, Dec 1st 2018:

Bring backs most of the magic of MOO2, with especially fun diplomatic ambassadors and GNN Robot News. Even though it's a bit simple, I'm getting my butt kicked by AI fairly regularly still at this point in my learning. I can see myself playing this a ton when I want some 4x fun that reminds me of the good old days, but doesn't paralyze me with a million layers of depth and management. I'll update this review if something comes along to reduce my enjoyment, but so far, so good!

I seldom write reviews but this game was so disappointing I had to do one.
The bad:
- Nothing innovative about it.  Just stick with with Gal Civ III, Stellaris or Polaris Sector and you'll be better off
- Graphics are ok but not outstanding.  They have a few good videos and animations but overall UI is poorish
- Unabalanced, your success depends highly on starting planets and how lucky you get
- Short.  You have interesting technologies like terraforming but they take so long to execute they're not useful in the game
- Bad combat system and although you can customize ships it's almost not worth it
The good:
- Interesting technology tree although fixed
The game wasn't really quite ready when it launced, but since then they have refined it. It plays mostly like the classic MoO2, but with a bit more depth.

This MoO isn't a bad game at all, but it's just not good enough to stand out or be worth your time.

After having some time to play around with the mechanics and try to enjoy the game... I can't. It's just not a very good game, and not a competitive 4X experience. It is not a bad game - but there are far better at the same or lesser price. Get Stellaris if you want a very intense long-form strategic experience, or Endless Space if you want a great modern version of a classic 4X. Even go and get the old Master of Orion 2 before trying this one.

The Good: The game has good basic mechanics, excellent aesthetics, and a lot of heart and character.

The Bad: Much of the game is spent tediously waiting for things to complete. Battles look good but have numerous weird bugs and quirks, and are largely non-interactive. Colonization rapidly becomes an agonizing slog of micromanagement - a serious issue because your biggest advantage is making numerous small optimizations. The AI is more annoying to deal with.

The Ugly: The game mechanics actually regressed compared to a 20-year old DOS game. Star Lanes are not an inherently bad idea, but they work against the relatively small galaxy sizes. After multiple test games, Numerous small features were either cut or locked behind cash DLC.

So there are some differences from the old MOO games. First, no turn based battles. Kind of disappointing. 2nd, instead of exploring based on distances from your star systems, you get star lanes you have to follow between systems. Yeah, I don't know why they did that, but the game is still fun. It's still MOO at heart. Simplified? Sure, but so was MOO2 from the original. Remember needing to build specific colony ships depending on the planet's climate?

A little wish. The planets are stationary in their orbits. I think they're pretty, but would look so much better if they actually moved a bit turn to turn. Oh well, fun game anyway. Go ahead and buy it. It won't be exactly a modern MoO 2, but you should still be able to enjoy it for what it is.
Thie game is fun

This is a great reboot of the original game, I wish more people played online. I can understand why some people are not playing it online because one game can take hours and hours and hours. with all the depth and hugeness running a Galatic Take over the Galaxy can be.  I do recommend this game if you like 4x Games.

Fantastic game!   I bought it while it was on sale for close to $8 and found myself playing it straight for 10 hours.  Its definitely one of those games where you keep saying, " just one more turn."   I was an old school MOO player and found this edition to be just as exciting and memorable.   I cannot wait until tomorrow so I can play some more!
crashes at some point early in every run ...
Great time spender loved the series since the first one !.
One of the first 4X. It has inspired all of them. But somehow, now it lacks something to be able to rival to endless space 2.

I've been playing them all...Stellaris, Galactic Civ 3, Endless Space 2, and this lil gem - Master Of Orion. I'm pleasantly surprised, and it's straight-forward manner was refreshing vs. the learning curve some of the other titles present. The artistry, voice acting, and worlds/galaxy come to LIFE in beautiful colors and graphics that are truly beautiful to just stare at - especially on a 4k TV (I'm playing on a LG C8 55-inch) ..it's just breath-taking to behold. As with ALL games, there are some areas that could use some improvement, but atm I would only classify it as nit-picking at best. 

I would really like to see them release more content...expansions! And, of course, don't abandon this product developer - you got a gem here, so keep showing it love!
Nice graphics.  A great game on its own, but as long as it is compared it to the old games it will not measure up.

I don't think there is any strategy game fan who does not know or has played at least one of Master of Orion games. While this game captures all good stuff from original 2 games, just as all strategy game, can easily become very repetitive and burn you with some dull tasks if you are trying to get all achivements. (like delete 600 blueprints)
On positive side, some boring tasks are automated and well integrated with rest of the game.
If you like strategy game - this game is for you, if not, you can give it a try - it is not bad game.
Very good game, close to the all time clasic MOO2, too bad that you have not good control during battle.
Awesome

I played the original MOO and was adicted to MOO2, this is a worthy successor to those legacies and I love playing this game for hours at a time.  I do, however,  wish we could still capture enemy ships, that was such fun in MOO2!

Overall score: Good 4 out of 5 stars. 
Pros:
--Choke points on systems.
--Modern graphics.
--Better Diplomacy.
--More like MOO2 the good one, not like MOO3.
--Updated colony management screen. I like how the more workers you put in the less effective each one is.
--New ship design screen that is easier to use.

Cons:
--Real Time Combat.  I thought I was playing a Turn Based Game!  I feel like it is more of a cinema.  Also I miss not being able to board or capture ships.
--Large maps, even the small one is a very long game.  I wish they had a tiny or duel size.
--Built in races are better than custom ones.  I enjoy playing custom races but I feel like I am being robbed.
--Not as innovative as I hoped, more of a update to MOO2 as opposed to a new game.

Final thoughts: I am a huge MOO fan, so this game was made for me.  Nice to see the game updated with modern graphics. I like the art with all the races.  I kind of wish they used the MOO2 combat system and just added an initiative system so each side took turns instead of one side getting to shoot first.  That would of made this a 5 star game.

Decided to try this during the Autumn Sale event. Let me say, this was the best money that I've spent on a game in a long while. There's more to this game then meets the eye and the in depth and preogression the further you get into the game is quite astonishing. The GNN brings a little comedy into the game while also giving great information about what's happening during the game. Definitely would have bought at full price, the game is a gem!

This game has proven itself through the test of time. Although it is basically improved graphics on an old platform that playability has never diminished. A true turn based wonder.

very nice

Nice game

I loved MOO 2, and really hoped for a good successor here, but this game disappointed me. Here's my breakdown:

The good:
- Turn-Based civ management, allowing micromanagement, but not requiring it.
- Custom race creation
- Interesting spy system
- Military outposts blocking space lanes (if you prepare, those not at war with you can't colonize your claimed region)
- Ship design
- Worf

The bad:
- Not turn-based combat
- Slow ships, even with jump gates and highest drive tech. It takes so long to get anywhere, if the Antarrans attack, better hope you had a fleet in the area.
- Painfully slow turns in late game. When I click next turn, I stand up and go walk around. I have a nice computer, though it's a couple of years old. Far beyond recommended specs.
- No victory movie. You just get a crummy text popup. Even MOO2 had a fun victory movie.

The ugly:
- 64 GB save file. This was the easiest uninstall I've ever done.

3/6
It is already a good game.  With the addition of harder AI, spies, and custom races (and the 4 missing ones), this game will be 10/10.

Update 4/25
They made the AI harder, added spies, and added custom races.  They also improved random events and improved the news reports.  It really is a good game at this point.  They are rapidly improving it.  This should be a buy for any fan of 4x.

Update 7/4
The latest update inproved the AI further but they removed food and science production from startup colonies so they mostly start in a starving state.  This slows down the game tremendously and will need to be reversed.

Update 8/13 EA7
I do not understand why they made some very poor decisions on changes.  Planets now grow very slowly and the AI (on normal difficulty) has 20 planets and a 2000 point fleet when I have 10 planets and a 58 point fleet.  You read that right, 58 to 2000 on normal difficulty.  I have over 130 hours played now and over 1000 hours in moo2.  I am not a neophite.  The game has taken a major step backward in fun.   I'm hoping they reverse course and are still balancing the game.

Update 8/31 Retail release
Well they fixed the colony growth problems, rebalanced the AI so it is a fair fight, added several animations and an intro and a ton of other fixes.  It isn't perfect yet but it is a good game and a definite buy at this point if you want a 4x.  They have promised to add independent colonies and other upgrades for free.  Antarians will probably be a DLC.

Update 11/21/18
They added everything they promised to and it's still a reccomend if you like 4x games.

I even bought into the negativity myself, thinking the game riddled with bugs, like the "save bug", which turns out is not a bug just people not understanding their own software installed. If you have a cloud service or other service on your documents drive, then exlude the MMO directory or it will write-lock the save file as it is constantly syncing.

Well, onto the game, as an MOO fan since MOO1 and loving MOO2, I find this a competent upgrade with hours and hours of entertainment. [h1] Just one more Turn [/h1]
I was very skeptical at first, especially seeing all the negative reviews. 171 hours of game time later, here is my review.
Up front: This is a review for the [b] Linux version [/b].
I bought the game on sale with all the DLC. The concept of splitting the original content into DLCs...well, let's say I would not have bought the game full price AND payed for the DLC. But I did not have to, so moving on.
[b] Performance [/b]: I'm playing on a 2.6GHz, 8GB RAM, HDD machine with an old intel graphics card since the NVIDIA burned out. This game runs rather smooth most of the time, just large fleet action seems to bring the system to it's limits. 
[b] Look&Feel [/b]: This game does feel like Master of Orion. I'll get to space battle later, but story, looks etc. work very well.
[b] Game Elements [/b]: The game is more diverse than MOO2 and adding workshop content really blows this to the extreme. They added a lot of cool stuff that makes the game more fun, like Space Pirates wit ships and bases or anomalies which hide treasure.
[b] Space Battle [/b]: I don't really get the nostalgia for moving ships from left to right. The new system is cool. Really, it is.
You now have asteroids, floating banks of nebula and they have an impact the battle. You can hide behind asteroids!
Also things like maneuverability suddenly have a huge impact. A small, out-gunned ship might outmaneuver a larger vessel by keeping behind it and things like that. From a tactical viewpoint this game offers way more than the old games. 
Though, this works best with small numbers of ships. Large-scale battles I usually auto-solve or use the cinematic mode. It's just not fun.
However, I remember how boring moving 25 ships in MOO2 was, so no improvement for me, but also not worse. 
[b] Sounds and Music [/b]: I'm a sucker for a good soundtrack and this game does not disappoint. 
Music is swell and the voice actors for the Leaders and assistants are great.
All in all the Galaxies feel way more special and individual in this game than in MOO2 (especially with the right workshop content) and at least for me I found workshop conent to change everything I did not like. 
[b] Bugs [/b]? Sure, there are some. Like the strange thing where you have to scroll the spy list just right to be allowed to click a spy. Annoying, but no game breaker. 
[b] Replay value [/b]: The different people groups (Humans, Alkari etc. I'm German, I don't use the r-word) are very different and I've played almost all by now and found you need a completely different approach to the game depending on who you play. Which is what I want.
171 hours in and I have unlocked 38% of all achievements. There still is a lot to explore in this game and I am still finding new, better ways to do things.
[b] 10/10 [/b]

I'm quite fond of this new iteration and, quite sincerely, don't understand why the poor reviews. Sure, some things may have been better (ground combat screen is a joke, and you cannot assault enemy ships as you did in MOO2 all those years ago, and some of the races are locked behind DLC paywalls), but others are really nice, such as the overall presentation and ship-to-ship combat. Also, the AI is up to the task, and I find the gameplay fine and relaxing.

Master of Orion is not nearly as bad as some are making it out to be. For what is has tried to be it is at least a limited success.

People seem to fault the game for being both too similar to too dissimilar from Master of Orion II, as a veteran of that game and 4X games in general I feel qualifed to speak at length about its strengths and weaknesses.

PRESENTATION
Master of Orion knocks it out of the park here. The in game animations, the models of the different races, the short CGI movies, voice acting, the pleasant empire interface, menus, — all of it — is extremely well polished. I had no glitches, crashes, slow downs, it was a beautiful seemless experience. The real-time battles look terrific, with laser beams and missiles hurtling towards other ships. It's on a 2D plane which while less strategic is a lot simpler to navigate. This is the prettiest 4X Space Game I have ever played.

GAMEPLAY
This is where some crticism is going to show up. Master of Orion is very similar to civilization here. You have 3 main resources - Production (hammers), Food, and Science. Gold/Money/Credits are also present. Functional this behaves very similar to Master of Orion 2 and Civilization. Each population unit can be moved to focus on either of the 3 resources, and each population unit generates income passively. It's a little too simplistic and is LESS interesting in many ways than MoO2.

DIFFERENCES MOO2 and Master of Orion
1. Growth is determined by how much food y ou are producing. In MoO2 growth was fixed once you fed enough people and extra food was either sold/exported.
2. No importing/exporting of food. Well, you can do this later but in MoO2 you could build Freighters to ship your extra food. This let some planets specialize into bread baskets and letting barren but mineral rich planets focus on indutry - but this no long works here. 
3. Without a Freighter system moving population units around is a bit more cumbersome as you have to build Civil Transports which are single use ships, similar to colony ships.
4. No more Colony Bases, only Colony Ships
5. In game Combat is real time BUT you can pause and fast forward. This IS a better system regardless of what many detractors think. Functionally an RTS where you can pause slow things down is very similar to a turn base game (think Baldur's Gate). It makes more for a more cinematic fight as well. 
6. More routes to victory - outside of Conquest, Diplomatic, & Antarans, there is now Economic, Science, and Score (after a set time).
7. More granular customization of game speed. You can adjust research, growth, and production speeds. I highly recommend slowing down research speed on bigger galaxies or you'll never have time to do much else.
8. Pollution instead of being a penalty to production, now will start hampering food growth and eventually deterraforming your planet. It is a lot harder to combat now even requiring your planet to simply stop producing for a time
9. Spying is both better and worse. You now build individual spies than level up independently and are sent on specific missions, each taking time. Unfortunately there doesn't seem to be much point. Stealing tech is always nice but because you research 'baskets' of individual techs, you still need to research a broad category even if you've stolen some of the individual techs in that basket, so it doesn't save you beakers. You can still sabotage buildings, or cause revolts, but these tend to fail, and being unable to target key things like Star Bases/Missile Bases makes it fairly pointless.
10. Diplomacy is as uncomplicated as it was in MoO2 - except the AI frequently doesn't have enough money to even enter a trade agreement. Exchange Technology is worthwhile however.
11. Autobuild still exists and it's... just as terrible. The Auto-build governor loves building pollution lowering buildings - even when you have no pollution! It's infuriating this can either be better controlled or customized.
12. There's now a 'worker' unit that improves the star system you are in, but other than building some sensors and improving some asteroids it's kind of a throw away.
13. System and Ship Leaders/Captains make a return, but they are far worse than in MoO2. Their effects are just very mild for their cost.
14. Star Lanes now exist. Highly controversial these do limit player freedom but do enable you to create choke points.
15. All the original races are here including the new "Terran" race (not Human).
16. Government is gone. No reason to leave this out as it was one of the key ways races were different. As it stands there isn't enough distinguishing the individual races. Really key attributes like Repulsive, Creative, and Subterranean have been neutered to be less impactful than they were.
17. Antarans still attack but are much weaker. Before they would zip in and obliterate any colony they attacked. Now while still difficult to beat in ship-to-ship combat, they hardly damage a planet once they reach, then promptly leave. 
18. Combat mechanics are exactly the same, including nebulous terms like "+50 to Beam attack" (+50% to hit? +50 Damage? +50 Accuracy?)

Overall this is better than what Master of Orion could have been (see MoO3!). There have been some improvements but some poor choices and things that could have been improved that weren't. With better Macro control, more differentiated races, better food management options, it would be just about perfect. It's still good, but the developer has stopped patching the game, and we'll have to accept it as is.

It's what Endless space couldn't be - fun.
It plays very much like Endless Space, but it actually has a soul to it. I, personally, found ES to be completely lifeless and bland. MoO is an extremely similar game yet they manage to flesh it out in a way that makes it engaging, like you can't wait to play one more turn.
It's very easy to learn, there's really good UI and tooltips that tells you everything you need to know. Combat is a little weird but I just auto-resolve in most cases anyway. It's reasonably challenging (on normal so far).

In a nutshell, this is a whimsical 4x grand strategy game.  

Coming from a guy who has played a few different 4x games like Stellaris and Civilization, Master or Orion is a needed relaxing game compared to most 4x games.  Full voice acting and fleshed out characters make it a welcome change from the little animation and graphics produced in most grand strategy games.  

This game is more simplistic than games like Crusader Kings 2, but I think that is a good thing.  I've never passed turns so quickly and I think I like the fast turns.  There's also no endless mountain of expansion packs needed for this game.  

One last note, I'm new the to Master of Orion franchise, so it seems like a good game to me.  I think the negative reviews stem from nostalgia filled gamers.  If you are new to the franchise you will probably like it as I did.

Still new to the game, but will comment on what I see so far.

I loved Moo3 as the best strategy game of all time.  Massive depth, maps, battles, tech... and modable.  No other tsrategy game has ever come close.  Turn based game with real time combat.

Master of Orion is pretty good.  I've run games on colossal & huge maps into 600+ turns.  Tech devleopment is interetsing & deep, plus real diplomacy, spies, ship customization.  It isn't as in depth as Moo3 (which many will actually like that it is not that way) yet has a lot of depth and replayability.  More in depth and yet fluid than most space strategy games. And modable.

This is a simple mix of Endless space plus the characters of Stellaris. 

What this game does better is the charm put forth by the narration and although sometimes annoying and simplistic, the repetition of the advisor adlibs (there's an option to disable it).

Although the intro seems full of charm, soon after the game starts, in about 100 turns you will find out there isn't much to it that this game does outside of the box when compared to titles that plays the same way, ie Endless Space, Stellaris.

What this game does well is the turn speed, its pretty fast. And direct combat where weapons are designated to regions of the ship in front/side/all sides and it's used when you aid in its direct control (useful in boss battles against space monsters).  

All in all, I feel like this is a very simple rendition of a 4X space game. Approximately 10 bucks will be worth your effort to play it.

I have been an avid MoO fan since the original but so much negetivity kept me away from this one.  Finally bought in with the -75% sale and for that price absolutely worth it for the voice acting and cinematics.  For single player this game is for all intents and purposes Civ in space .. works almost identicle and is usually worth a bit of fun.

For multiplayer forget it.  Only auto resolve for combat, limited space and players even on biggest maps, frequent game hang ups usually on a CPUs turn, if a player disconnects you have to remake lobby no hot joins, and the most popular mods are for countering bugs and optimizing game balance.

TLDR:  Good to grab on a 75% off or better sale to play SP, full price or multiplayer forget about it Stellaris or even Sins of a Solar Empire do MP SO incredibly better.

I played thousands of hours of MOO and MOO2 and this game looked like a great reboot.  Unfortunately, it appears that the game was coded by 1st year CS majors.  Its bugs and poor performance make larger games almost unplayable.  I’ve read a dozen posts where people claim that poor performance is due to poor hardware.  But my PC can handle Skyrim, so why would a simple turn based space game lag so bad during space battles?  And why would it take up to three minutes (yes 3 minutes!) for a turn to process?  And why would Stellaris perform so much better?  It just comes down to poor coding.  I could almost deal with it if gameplay was significanly better than MOO2, but it isn't.  So I'm going to keep playing MOO2 and wait for this game, and its developers, to mature.
Complete waste of time and money.

After a lot of thinking I decided to recommend this game. After all it is fun game with a lot of content and things to explore. 

If you did not played MOO2 it is a good chance that you will like this game a lot. Unfortunately I played it and have bunch of things that I miss. Most of all Antarans, dreaded ancient race, are a complete joke. Their fleets will cause such minor damage to your colonies that it's not worth mentioning. Even worse your fleets will have no problems dispatching their raid parties. Second issue is the AI. Again, complete joke on any difficulty level. I only played vanilla game so probably some mods can help with this. Also upgrading ships (entire fleet) for credits in single turn is pure blasphemy! That really kills fun for me. Diplomacy? Really, who needs diplomacy when you have all those wonderfull Battleships? Spying? Again, you can completely ignore it and still win game on hardest difficulty.

On the good side I really liked Space factories and their abilities to build useful space objects. Game pace is much better than MOO2. Now a fleet of destroyers with nuclear missiles can wage a war! This means you can have real action after 10 mins of playing! Well done! Animations are wonderful. There is many heroes that will join your faction but their abilities are sometimes not that helpful. Battles are easy to fight and interesting. Some of the MOO2 spirit is still present in them. 

Overall game is OK. It has solid fun factor. Main gameplay problem is that after you crush first oposing race you already know you will win this game because you have enough resources to push all others. I tried to start war with all other races at once and won. That really should not be possible even on normal difficulty. Also, Game went too far with simplification of all actions. Sometimes it went OK but in the end it caused to be a bit boring. 

Even with all these problems I think players should try it and buy it when on some fat discount. I guarantee they will have at least couple of hours of fun.
Still unplayable multiplayer after many years, full of bugs. Last game worked 53 turns.

Ack! I think the complex chart-styled map and real-time combat system are just fine, and the races' new designs and abilities are quite well done (though it does piss me off that the Terrans and the MoO2 races are sold separately).

It is the classic Master of Orion recipee, on a new -brand new- modern era package with nice graphics, and wonderfull soundtrack.
 Its addictive, turn after turn, its fun its everything that made older Master of Orions great.
 In the cons i would add the battle system, it seems worse than the classic older turn by turn systems, but altought the game has this flaw it is still a great game and highly recommended if you look for a classic 4x Strategy.
 I have played also endless Space 2, stellaris, and a few others and although this is not the deeper of games it is maybe the simpler, with the more clear interface as to get you started. 
 I highly recommend it, no matter if you are an old Master of Orion player or a new one.

 PS. My real hours spend on this game are way more...
Good game but if you have an old computer it’s a bit glitchy

I played Masters of Orion and Masters of Orion 2 to death.  I'm talking thousands of hours.

I couldn't get through a single game of this abomination.  Needlessly graphically heavy, horribly designed/balanced, horrible interface, and not even remotely fun to play.  

Devs should be ashamed for destroying such a great series

I grew up playing the MOO series and loved it (NOT 3 mind), I bought this cheaply during sale just to have a look, as I was pretty sure beforehand it wouldn't provide anything new and that is exactly how it turned out.

It's basically streamlined version of MOO2 with better production values.

I have to criticise the developer for forcing a starlane galaxy map in a turn based space 4x based on MOO.  I'd be more forgiving if it was not MOO or if it were an RTS (albeit still disappointed) because the idea of a naturally occuring transit system in the galaxy that is the ONLY way to get around is stupid.  It makes it feel like your exploring a weird space dungeon, complete with corridors and doors, instead of a the frickin galaxy. Also war now becomes all about bottlenecks. Very disappointing.

I don't hate the real time combat, but would have preffered the turn-based one from previous titles.

It's a difficult situation, and I do sympathise a little with the developers as they were walkng a tight rope from the beginning and it is very much a case of 'damned if you do, damned if you don't'.  Without doubt it is well polished with high production values and despite my previous criticism is a pretty solid game.
Nevertheless, it is regretabble that I find it impossible to recommend it to anyone because if you've never played MOO/MOO2, then i'd advise you to play them instead, and if you have you probably won't be very interested in this remake, so there isn't really anyone left after that to recommend it to.  Shame that.

It's a cool concept but holy hell the computer gets to cheat lke crazy.  They will have these enormous fleets with no money and somehow maintain it.  You'll struggle having 5 ships.  Cheat your ass off otherwise the AI is frustrating to deal with.

First off, I loved Master of Orion 1 and 2.  I hated MOO3.  I had high hopes for this, but I can't say I like it.  It is pretty to look at (when it works), and the music/voice acting are excellent.  However, all that goes out the window when the game won't run!  No Man's Sky was attacked for being buggy, well it was a lot more stable than this train wreck!  It locked up my computer during my initial attempt to start it.  Then, after re-loading and starting the tutorial successfully, I quit out to start a new game, and it locked up again.  Then, after re-starting the game and trying to start again, it locks up!  25% success rate on a computer game's stability is unacceptable!  Apparently they no longer update it, having given up, seeing as how it has been about a year since the last update.  I need a refund so that I can reinvest in a game I can ACTUALLY PLAY!!!

After playing several games across several years, I cannot reccomend this game. I found the gameplay itself rather dull and felt far too similar than the Civilization franchise. The gameplay felt tedious, but this can be attriubted to the turn-based concept as a whole (a personal problem, of course). Great game in itself because of the nostalgic air it has with the previous version.

There are however quite a lot of downsides to this game which would not make me recommend getting the title:
- Game "recycles" the buildings from MoO2, uses the almost same tootltip but the bonusses from the buildings / tech is new (usually less then MoO2 buildings).
- Diplomacy is shit. Options the opponent has with you cannot be initialised back.
- Planetary UI gets slow beyond turn 60 / 70. A restart of the game fixes this for almost 3 turns.
- Game gets serously slow beyond point 170. Hitting "end turn" gives you the Win10 flickering cursor wheel. When lucky it will resolve itself. If unlucky, your game gets terminated instantly.

If you want something to kill time, get MoO2 from gog.com. It lives in a dosbox but it is way better opmised then this game!

This game so fell short of being the success it should of been, the best game of the masters of orion series are 2 and 3, 2 is a simple game that was quite well planned out and didnt constantly put your empires treasury in the red, number 3 had way better strategy elements and a much more extensive technology tree to research, so my recommendation is to go play one of them two.
Fantastic.

This game is based on the game Master of Orion 1-3, aka the greatest games that I never played.  So with that said, I did get all 3 when I bought the deluxe edition however, I haven't played them much yet, therefore I have little to no biases for how this game compares to the originals.  

With all that in mind, I like this game a lot.  I still come back to it, despite owning Civilization 3, 4, 5, & Beyond Earth.  It is very similar but seems a bit simplier than the Civilization games that I've played.  

When you play single player, you can opt to fight the space battles manually, or you can watch them unfold in cinamatic mode.  However in multiplayer, as far as I know, there is no cinamatic mode or manual control mode, so it's purely a game of percentages and chance at that point, which is probably its biggest downside for me, the lack of control and spectacle in multiplayer mode.   
My other problem is that it seems a bit pricey, especially since the DLC doesn't come in the deluxe.  $30 isn't the worst price, but I got it on sale, so I can't really complain too much.

All in all though, I really enjoy this game, despite its faults.

This game is good fun. Period.

This game has really improved over time, since we last played it.  Beautiful graphics, music,aesthetics, and atmosphere. Game is relatively easy to learn, very rewarding to play. We appreciate the large, easy to read UI and fonts. The infrequent but refreshing humor and occasional sarcasm lends to appreciating the various races. AI has greatly improved from the earliest versions. The addition of modding capability is a plus. There are some very detailed mods, tweaking and polishing the game, while removing some bugs. We recommend turning off the Antarian victory, as we have found the Antarians to be nothing but a pain to deal with.
The only other recommendation would be to play without the pirates and monsters, and increase the turn limit to 1,000.
All in all, this game is now highly recommended, rewarding, and enjoyable, yet challenging.
There are a wide range of difficulty levels, so beginners will not get a migraine trying to learn it from the inception.
basically the original but with a lot of stuff fixed. Not perfect, but it's good.

I think the negative reviews are mostly unwarranted.  A large portion consist of "they did not include X which I liked in MoOX".  The real time combat is a positive in my opinion.  Seeing your ships battle it out in real time is exciting, especially in the later phases of the game when they are truly massive.  From top to bottom it is a really well constructed game and a worthy successor to the MoO franchise.

I'm glad I did not let the haters prevent me from buying this one :)

Edit: This review is updated and reflects playing the game using the Spud Dastardly 5x Balance Mod which improves the original game no end.

In short: Looks like a 9 and plays like an 7. It doesn't set out to innovate in the genre but to pay homage to the original. Sadly the game was abandonned by the developers so only buy on special if you're a MOO fan (thus the recommendation) and use the 5x mod. It's a 4x lite game to play over a weekend, so if you're after massive depth then check out other titles like Stellaris.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]The graphics are gorgeous and a shining example of what a 4x game should look like.
[*]I keep playing it (over 330 hours so far), so "just one more turn" has become a thing with it.
[*]The UI is an absolute treat to use. Other 4x devs take note, this is how it's done. No diving into sub-pages and menus to find what you want. Everything is a click and one screen away and clearly presented.
[*]Enough options to set up gameplay to your liking.
[*]The ship designer is fun to play with, though not particularly necesssary.
[*]Crushing your enemy and hearing the lamentations of their... wait, they're all dead.
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]As of March 2017 the devs went quiet and there have been no official patches since then so read the reviews carefully before purchasing.
[*]The AI isn't terribly challenging at normal level.
[*]Tactical combat isn't all that interesting, then again, I just use the auto battle result the vast majority of the time unless the odds are against me.
[*]There's been a lack of bug fixes for the really blindingly obvious bugs in the vanilla version, but they've been fixed with the 5x mod.
[*]I suspect large numbers of the development team have been abducted by the Antarans and gone missing.
[*]Graphically, too many races have spacehips that look like flying bricks when more sleek, sexy SR71 type ships are needed as well as completely bizarre looking ones.
[*]The tech tree is linear and the same for all races, bar some options not being available. I'd much prefer differing research trees and also having the meta game of being able to allocate research between shield tech, missile tech, beam tech, ecology etc.
[*]Lack of a ship battle simulator so you can test various designs.
[*]It was released from early access 6 months too soon, though the DLC and 5x mod has matured the game nicely.
[*]This is not a game for in-depth micromanagers.
[/list]

[b]Meh[/b]
[list]
[*]The sound is average. It's not bad but it's not Mass Effect either.
[*]Mid game is slow with lots of pressing of the end turn button.
[*]The manual. It covers the basics but doesn't really explain the mechanics behind some of the game systems.
[/list]

If you're a fan of micromanaging massive empires with extreme depth and games that last many days, then look elswhere. This game is a 4/10 in terms of complexity compared to others in the genre. But if you like being able to jump into a game with an easy learning curve and knocking a game out over a couples of days, then take a look at MOO:CTS.

---

Summary: this is another 4x space game that aimed for the stars but hit the moon. It's still better than the vast majority that exploded on the launch pad though and fun enough to play to warrant a look on sale. Consult your Magic 8 Ball before buying and check out the other 4x space games out there first.

Pros:

Cons:

- Colony auto-management is stupid: it was building recycling buildings when there is no pollution.
- As is not so complex like Stellaris, during mid/late game there is no much things to do.
- All starships (Frigate to Titan) looks all same size, only during the battle you see them in real scale.

I recommend it, but not full price, maybe with 60% or more off.

The game is cool, a good rework. More faithfull to number two than the origional or number three.

It's a shame steam doesn't allow neutral reviews, as i like the game, unfortunately wargaming seem to have cut a few corners when making it. So overall the review has to be negative, despit the game being good.

Unfortunately i have multiple graphics cards in my machine and the game seems unable to identify one from the other so no longer works. This is a wargiaming issue not simply restricted to Master of Orion. My world of Tanks now also no longer works. It's been about two months since i reported the issue and they've now stopped sending me mails to clarify the situation. The last message was over a month ago saying they need more time.

Personally i'm torn as to if i should get my money back or if i should stick with it... I think wargaming is more mobile focused. A Simple, Clean, and Elegant Space 4X game. Its well designed to make your decisions matter, but the ship movement is too slow for my tastes. They feel more like moving pieces around a board than wielding mighty starships. 

It doesn't over take Stellaris for my favorite game in the genre, but it did more or less eat 2 straight days of my time, so its not all bad.

In a way it's CIV meets Total War, I don't understand why this has so many mixed reviews. It takes a little bit to get used to but I enjoy it anyway, and there's very few bugs that I've ran into which is forgiveable. Good to pick up in a sale.

The 'mixed' rating on here seems unfair to me, for a game that does exactly what I expected: an old-school 4X game /without/ the huge complexity of the newer genre entries.

I've played the original MoO I and II, and even dabbled in the rather disappointing MoO III. Of these, MoO II still reigns supreme, but after a bunch of updates and balance patches, the Master of Orion reboot (i.e. the game I'm reviewing right now) is nearly identical to MoO II in terms of gameplay, with two exceptions:

Ships battles are real-time (vs. the old turn-based battles), but pausable. Very little difference in reality, and not a solid reason to rate this game much worse than the original MoO II.

Balancing in the latest version of this game actually tends to be /better/ than the old MoO II. There's still plenty of cheese tactics possible, but less so.

I personally think the main reason for the negative reviews here is that current 4X games (e.g. Stellaris, Endless Space, Endless Legend) are vastly more complex than the original MoO games. While I understand that this is desirable to some, maybe even most hardcore players, I was hoping for something between "casual" and "mind-bogglingly complex". The MoO reboot hits that sweet spot.

The closest analog of modern games I can think of is Endless Space (part 1, I mean). Comparably simple planet management, comparably simple battle decisions, some complexity in how you design/fit your ships -- and that's it.

Exactly what I was hoping for, so for me at least, the game is an unconditional recommendation (if you're not into the deep complexity of games like Stellaris of Endless Space II).

So, long story short, this is what Master of Orion 3 should have been, if it had come out back then, it would have been lauded as much as master of orion 2, it could have been a game of the year contender. The problem with this game is that it did not come out as master of orion 3, instead coming out much later. This is a good game, it's worthy of the franchise and improves on moo2, really there's nothing much to say other than that, if you enjoy the franchise it's decent, if you're new to the franchise and love rts than it's a good addition to any collection.

If you loved and played the original MOO and MOO2 as I did, you probably will end up feeling hollow disappointment.

Races available in previous Master of Orion games sold as DLC.

"Oh, don't worry.  We know what made MOO2 great and MOO3 poorly reviewed!"
*star lanes and real time combat in a Civilization clone*

Aaaand the hype train crashes.

Pretty good game by itself. Slide on the 5X Overhaul and Split Tech Trees from the Workshop and you practically have an updated version of MOO2. The ability to mod truely is a wonderful thing, something that is lacking in many modern games. 

Easy on the eyes, good for just chilling, doing chores, working from home, and killing a bit of time all the while.

Don't let the mixed reviews fool you. I'll bet most of them are from people who expected a MOO2 remake. Reading through a fair few of them, that seems to be the case. I guess they didn't do their research before buying?

If you expect an "uber hardcore" experience, turn away. At-least for now, there aren't any mods that would make this game that, unless you want to make one for yourself.

If you expect a fairly light 4x game that can be enhanced to reach MOO2's potential with a couple mods from the workshop, pick this up. I'd pick it up on sale, but at its full price is fine if you are working a decent job.

7/10 Without Mods, 9/10 With Mods.

This is a great game if you like MOO 2. The most significant change for me is the introduction of star lanes. I did not like it at first, but after some play I found it added new strategic gameplay challenges. All in all I recommend this game, especially at its current price point.

Played the original, wasn't a big fan. This one isn't...horrible. It seems like they really were trying for the "cinematic experience" niche, with the large amount of voice acting, the little cinematic things when you start a campaign, etc. I'll praise the ship blueprint auto-updater for actually appearing to work, because such things usually don't work very well in other games like this.

The problem with this game is basically that everything it even attempts to be good at is done better by other things. For spaceship customization, you have...okay this one isn't even attempting to compete there, the ship design part of the game doesn't seem to have any depth at all. For touchy feely stuff like aesthetics, which definitely seems like it's what they were trying to make the selling point, it's just...an inferior offering. The aesthetics of the ships and the planets and all of the art bits you can find are just blown out of the water by Endless Space 2, there's just no competition at all. The music is just elevator music, I could recommend Endless Space 2 again or I could go to Stellaris, which also has a very good soundtrack, or I could even cite Galactic Civlizations 2, which is free or something these days, apparently, and has at least one good, memorable song.  The tactical combat is not worth bothering with at all. I don't understand how it's possible to make a bad RTS interface nearly ten years after Brood War was released, but they did it. The actual strategic gameplay is really, really dull. The majority of turns I just push the next turn button without doing anything at all, at least for the first three hours I've tried to play the game. It finally starts to pick up around turn 120, but the early game is pretty painful. It's really, really dull and empty. If the game made me say "Eh, I'd rather play Endless Space 2," it would be forgivable, because Endless Space 2 is an incredibly good game. This game makes me say, "I'd rather be playing Stellaris," and I -hated- Stellaris.

I wanted to like this, it is a tough call, for one I really like the way the map is laid out.  Hyperspace lanes..  I hate them in a 4x strategy game, the use of them is lazy and for AI purposes it is purely a genre problem at this point so I can't fault them for using them.  Stellaris did it right, until they didn't.  still salty about that. so maybe I will blame them.   Back to Moo..  this was a nice blend of Moo1 and Moo2 elements, as an IP I think this is the right look and feel, graphics and story wise.    I liked that it was made in unity, but given what was accomplished and the price point, it is a pure money grab.   Unity is more powerful than this..  shame on the developer.
The Bad: 
[olist]
[*] You took old school races and put them behind an additional paywall to your already obnoxiously overpriced game.    
[*] Hyperlanes, lazy designers/programmers solution to robust A.I.
[*] Ship design was drastically paired back, there was so many things that could have been improved upon.  Just lazy design
[*] Ship Combat, again lazy.  If you'd simply followed Moo2s design you would have had a much better ship to ship system..  Instead you basically lifted StarDrive2s combat..  but without the robust ship design capability.
[*] Planet management tools....  get some.. even in Moo2 you could select more than one colonist at a time..   painful.
[*] I can't mix up the ship sets or colors..  I can't play a Klackon race with Human ship set and Alkari color.. Boo!!!!
[*] Hyperlanes..  because they just need to die.
[/olist]
The Good:
[olist]
[*] Diplomacy, it was one of the more enjoyable aspects of the game.  Nothing really special here, about what I'd expect of a 4x
[*] Planet View, exploration.  It looks good, the start systems feel good and are pleasing to the eye..  but the scale is a bit off, and star system counts are abysmal.  you could have done better here.
[*] Espionage system was probably the best one I've seen in a Moo Game..  I don't consider Moo3 a real Moo game.. Quicksilver made something and slapped Moo on it..  
[*] Voice acting, it was nice to hear all those actors I am so familiar with.  It gave credibility where none of the rest of game carried it..  
[/olist]

Bottom Line:
This game at full price is an insult, go buy StarDrive2..  It's buggy and the developer abandond it for a real job, but its' just straight up better than this.   If you see this game up for under ten bucks, then no harm no foul..  As for the voice actors that put their name on this..  my apologies, you have my sympathies.  Micheal, if I hear you say GNN one more time....
Not a bad game, but painfully unstable on Linux. Crashes and freezes on a regular basis Once your galaxy gets a bit large.

Basically, it's like a cheaper, less complicated version of Stellaris.  Whether or not that's a good thing entirely depends on your preferences.  For what it's wortth, I enjoyed my time with Master of Orion quite a bit.  It's a solid game with decent replay value and a gorgeous presentation that's only slightly marred by it's lack of depth relative to similar games.  If nothing else, it serves as a great introduction to the space 4X genre, while still managing to be a fun experience in it's own right.  Your playthroughs are going to eventually feel a bit samey, but the game's charm gives it some staying power.  Give it a shot if you're curious.

Pretty Nice, I miss some stuff from Moo2 but overal nice and decently ballanced. Realy good adaptation of antares and some of the races. The feal is there. Only thing I dislike is what I always dislike, the breakup of the game into dlcs.

Essentially this is Master of Orion 2 with better graphics. I wish there was the possibliliy to play as the Antarans and invade the Universe, but maybe it's the little power crazed dictator im me dreaming ...
