Surprisingly easy to get into, I play Endless Space 2,  Space Tyrant, Stars in Shadow, and whatever... this was probably more digestable than any of those games aside from Space Tyrant. I'm fan of the whole GNN thing they have, just some dumb humor while playing instead of being super serious all the time. While I still enjoy ES_2 the most out of all Space for-exes, I can see this being my favorite once I get into it more... great first impressions and glad I picked it up.

As an huge fan of MoO2 I, like so many others, were thrilled when they decided to update the game to a more modern version. The reviews of this game when it first came out were a mixed bag of disappointment. I was particularly disheartened to see the use of starlanes, a concept so hotly debated there are essays on the subject. Not to wade into the debate here (there is no debate, they're completely stupid - restricting the very concept of space travel by constricting the physical world into a two-dimensional construct for babies), but the failure to keep MoO2's empicable spirit alive was not only wasted, but murdered with drunken madness. Since playing this game I'm overwhelmed with sorrow, as the developers make clumsy mistakes one after the other. Whether it's re-organizing the tech tree, irrational use of spacelanes, allowing races to destroy one another's fleets without it being considered a hostile act, or a combat platform that's confusing and pointless, the only conclusion one can make is that this game just-plain-sucks. 

There aren't enough words in the world to describe how developers have screwed this golden opportunity up. Someone, or perhaps everyone, should be fired - immediately and post-haste. 

You're welcome.

TL;DR - This is a solid remake for fans of either MoO 1 or 2, but more importantly, this is a great "My First Space 4X" game for beginners to the genre with excellent craftsmanship in the visuals and audio departments.

(SIDENOTE: From what I can tell, most of the negative reviews here on steam are either related to old problems now patched, or are people complaining that combat in this game isn't turn-based, but real-time. While I can understand that complaint to a degree, since the OG MoO games are turn-based in their combat systems and if you prefer that, you prefer that, the actual combat system present in the new MoO (remake? reboot?) is actually completely decent on its own, if a bit no frills. Moreover, it's real-time ***with pause*** (as well as speed options when un-paused) much like a lot of classic CRPGs, which is . . . . well, it's almost turn based in a lot of ways. You just have to set your own turns. I get it, as I like TBS tactics games too, but it's really a personal taste thing in my opinion, not a mark against this game's battle system.)

Anyway, that out of the way, this is a great Space-based 4X. The gameplay is very much Master of Orion in terms of its roots and does things in several slightly different ways compared to others in the genre out there. You have starlanes instead of a big open grid or hexagon tile map for example, which makes map movement and traversal much more restrictive, but more strategic (as you now have natural chokepoints to defend, or that you have to take). You have (now better balanced) pollution systems that limit development on planets you colonize to make settlement management a little more interesting. You have the invading Antarans, who act as raiders that are everyone's enemies and are a constant threat, but which make pure peace runs a lot harder. 

It does things just a bit differently enough from most in the genre that it's definitely carved out a nice unique place in the the space 4X genre. It's all fairly simple to understand, but there's also enough depth to the systems that they remain fairly interesting over the course of a game.

The main thing that makes this game easy to recommend is its presentation. This is probably the highest fidelity 4X game on the market at the moment, with incredibly well animated and polished visuals (especially the leader screens, which are somewhere between Civilzation 5 and 6 in quality) and great voice over work by a pretty amazing cast of recognizable sci-fi actors from a bunch of shows and movies including Star Wars, Star Trek and Firefly. The music is really grand and well executed as well, and I'm a big fan of the cheeky news reporter robots that are used to notify the player of major events in the galaxy.

All of this combines into a package that might not be what you're looking for if you're a big fan of the space 4X genre and already have your favorites in it, but which makes it a very approachable game for people who might not have ever played a game in the genre before. Every individual system in the game I think has been done better or with more depth by another game out there, but all of them present in this reboot of MoO are done well enough and are simple enough to grasp that I think they'd be great starting points to build off of for new players (GalCiv 3 for example, has a far more robust, but also far more obtuse ship builder). 

There are still some flaws though. The "tutorial" is an absolute piece of trash. You're better off just starting a game at a normal difficulty or easier. As a result, there are several features that are not very well explained to the player (like that you can use CTRL + left click to move multiple workers around on a planet's production menu), but for the most part things are intuitive enough (and there are enough tooltips) that you can figure out how to use them. The Trilarians (the fish guys) are also a bit underwhelming compared to other races - they should probably get the ability to build warp gates early and in neutral territory or something. The diplomacy system works but it's pretty basic and has little depth (and the whole ability for other leaders to ignore you for long periods without any way of even knowing how long you're on a time-out with them for is just a bad idea). There's not nearly enough event variety with anomalies and pirate base destruction (which makes pirates fairly farmable for free population). If you use an alternate hulll design for custom ship, it shows the base hull as an icon . . . but these are getting into nitpick territory.

Overall, this is a really, really solid space 4X that's easy enough to pick up and play (even with the crap tutorial) and it with enough meat on its bones that you can get One-More-Turnitis pretty quickly, and should be great for newbies. I'd recommend getting the extra races DLC though, as they add a lot more variety.

I don't normally write reviews, but i feel like i need to after all the reviews i've seen.  Many of which made me not want to buy this game.  Since it was on sale and it came with MoO2, i figured 10 bucks for MoO2 is worth it if nothing else.

This game is pretty good.  Its not perfect but it is a good successor to MoO2.   I feel like most of the hate comes from the non-turned based combat.  Though i would really like to see something like that, what they did was still neat.  My bet is that most of the people don't understand how the combat and weapon directions/range works.  They did it a few times and gave up in disgust.   The rest of the game is a sort of combined copy of the better parts of Endless Space, Civ 4, Stelaris, and maybe others i haven't played.  Which in turn probably copied alot of their stuff from MoO2 to begin with.  I don't really care much about graphics, as i am excited to play MoO2 still, but these are Really good.

LIked:
[list]
[*]  The tech tree was solid, though as always i'd like so see a bit more options
[*]  Combat is fairly fun
[*]  The races are great, ship design top notch
[*]  The base game and mechanics are taken straight from MoO2
[*]  Graphics
[/list]

Want changed:
[list]
[*]  Would still like a turn based combat option, but unless they stack all like ships like in MoO2 it would be tedious.
[*]  A few more options in tech and the revival of the Megabolt Cannon.
[*]  More ship designs so i can tell ships apart of same size but different design.
[*]  The extra Perks on planets quite literally make no impact.
[*]  Can't board and take over ships to steal tech and get cash, sad panda.
[*]  No sorting options while making ships.
[*]  Biggest complaint is the star lanes.  I like the idea, just not how it was implemented.
[/list]

Starlanes are a good addition to the game imo.  They make choke points you can defend and build battle bases at.  The bad part of them is they stop normal flow of movement.  Each time you enter a star system, you have to stop.  Then you have to fly to the edge of the star system and stop, then you can move on.  FYI the whole map is COVERED in star systems.  Unless there is something there preventing movement like a battle base, there is no reason that it should impede the normal travel speed of a ship.  Want to travel to somewhere around 7 turns away with 3 planets in between?  13 turns. 
 If anything is gonna make me hate this game, its that.  

Though i would like to see the game continued to be worked on, its still a great game well worth the sale price.
Super fun. I wake up and go to the computer. "I'll play a quick game. Okay I should get off now, Wait when did it get dark out?"
Liking it so far. Not overly complicated and it has that just one more turn effect on me heh. Will report back when I have had more hours.

What I love is the diplomacy, I love seeing the other leaders from other races and their reactions.
The fear of you as you become the most powerful empire in the galaxy is a very nice touch.
Do I recommend this game? To a point, I would hope the devs keep working on this.

I changed my opinion and now recommend this game.  I was rather unhappy in my first game on very easy difficulty to have the Antarans wipe out my entire fleet and while I still think it's stupid that the Antarans attack on the easier difficulties, the best strategy seems to be to move your fleet out of the way and let them have their way with whatever planet they attack.  They will bomb it once and then withdraw.  You'll have to rebuild your orbital defenses but that's better than losing your fleet in a futile defense.  I'm enjoying the rest of the game.  The presentation and mechanics of the game are good.  Diplomacy feels fairly realistic.  The warp lanes movement means defense is possible unlike in Stellaris and Stardrive 2.
this game is really nice, its simple and fun game you can just jump into. if you want something overly complicated then go get stellaris, you have to spend 100hrs on it just to understand it.

Master of Orion is a great, relatively easy to learn and play game.

I loved Master of Orion II, and can see the original work at least as an inspiration for much of the new game.  The tactical management and automated fleet design makes the game much easier to play, though I really really enjoyed this element in the original and find it unsatisfying in the new game due to the changes in tactical control.

Graphics are light years ahead, the 3d elements are fantastic, and while the city scenes are flat, they are still gorgeously done.  The ships are relatively uninspiring aesthetically.

The game is much more balanced, making technology less of a tool for crushing victory.  This gives the game more of a buffer in case you get behind or ahead.  That said I genuinely loved the sense of progression that version 2 had.  Planets and Fleets increased by orders of magnitude in power from beginning to end, and it created a much clearer and dramatic sense of progress.  In this they definately improve and increase, but it's nothing like version 2.

Do not buy this game. The space combat just sucks. The dev had the opportunity to go back to the roots of the game and make a turn based combat system that was one of the features of the original gamres, but decided that a real time combat system, a feature that MOO 3 went to (which was also terrible) was a winning strategy. It isn't. Homeworld does it much bettter. 

I am not looking for real time combat games. I miss the original turn based game.
Not really worth playing but the voice acting that they so prided themselves on was indeed really great.

Game is really simplistic, with tactical part still being a joke. Also there are surpirsingly bad technical issues. Like if you have any mods those are to available through in-game menu and have to be enabled there. Sometimes game will have neverending End of turn events, which you can save/ bounce the game and reload. Overall, not worth the trouble, which is a  shame for such a great series.

A massive disservice to the Master of Orion series. Races are horridly unbalanced, combat has been gutted into watching two blobs smash together, research feels less meaningful, and overall boring, cartoonish, and rushed.

Master of Orion is a fun 4X for those wanting to have a galactic empire at their fingertips without delving into spreadsheats. Game mechanics are well streamlined and the races have a ton of personality creating a smooth and enjoyable experience.

I personally have not experienced noticeable bugs, so I can safely recommend this title.

At first I would have highly recommended this game.  It was on early access and many new features were added both before and after release.  I was a hardcore player of MOO and MOO2.  MOO2 had a very serious tone and was great.  This re-write has a more silly and goofy aspect.  I'm sad to say it looks like the game has now been abandoned without being completed.  The load time is unusually long and there's no tactical battles in multiplayer.  The game is also still full of bugs.

I loved the old game (only player master of orion 1) and this game is indeed a nice re-take on that, just with modern graphics, etc. 

However, it gets bogged down in micro-management. You need to explicitly build specific buildings on your planets, and that just becomes a hassle when you have many. You got to click like 50 times for trivial stuff that doesn't matter. 

Each ship you want to build, you need to click 4 times. There is no "keep building ship X and relocate to Y". And then zoom and scroll, and slow-populating menus.

The time a round takes really goes up by the number of turns too.

Tech tree reminds of the first game, but also here it's been made worse. Much harder to understand, less options and you can also get most tech (miss out on less).

Graphics and audio are great. Really love the dialogues and artwork.

Unfortunately the game is unplayable if you have more than 1-2 stars due to micro-management.
The game gets you excited for a few days then it becomes boring to play.
Its nothing like the first game that came out

If you loved these old games you will really like this newer one.  It stays true to the races and in my opinion makes them even better.  I have done several playthroughs and honestly if you aren't careful, you can get your tail kicked on harder difficulties.  It does feel like the story treats 3 as though it never happened, which is not so bad honestly.  It feels like a newer verision of the 2nd one, which frankly was my favorite.

This game lets you modify ships to suit your play style, you can even customize existing races.  My only complaint is when you customize you seem to have fewer points to purchase abilities with, but honestly it is more fun sometimes to play at a disadvantage.  So this part evens out for me.  It is turn based and the diplomacy system is worth learning how to utilize.  I have saved my empire more than a few times, but you will get boned if you have tons of tech they don't have and you want an alliance.  

There is one of my top 10 favorite games of all time.  We even have some well known actors of sci fi shows that we all love, and they do the voices for the characters, this only adds to the greatness of this game.  I highly recommend it.  It has a very good steam workshop community with some very interesting mods.  It would probably be even more fun if you had people you enjoyed playing with who were turn based enthusiasts.  As a fan of the Master of Orion trilogy, someone who has frequently said, "I wish to God they would make another one of these," I am not disappointed in the least.  

Now to the stuff that I didn't like:  
1.  I loved that certain technological devices could give you a decisive victory over overwhelming odds if you knew how to use them right in MoO two.  The fleet battles in this game are mostly you overpowering the other fleet, most of the strategy comes in the form of how you build your ship and picking the right weapon to overpower the enemy.  In the old MoO2 game, the blackhole generator w/ a time distortion type device along w/ phase cloaking could help you stave off attacks with a subtantially smaller force while being invaded from exponentially larger forces if your gameplay style was not warlike.  It was more satisfying to play like that sometimes.  Just overpowering your enemies in this game is fun but I feel like it limits game play.  In 2 you could even utilize onboard marines to board enemy ships for tech and victory.  This is just "pew pew pew I hope you die before I do".  An expansion could improve this but most games like this don't do expansions.  
 2.  If you want to play certain alien empires like the Trilarians, Gnolams or Elerians, you will have to pay for them.  I bought them, I really do like them, they make nice additions to the gameplay, but it seemed somewhat random to pick these 3.  The trilarians are not particularly special perse, but the other 2 are pretty powerful although require a specific gameplay style to make use of their abilities.  Also if you want the Terrans (alternate human empire), you get them in the collector's edition.  This isn't a complaint, just noting it.  There are 4 races you will have to pay extra for.  I didn't mind overly much, but it was weird.  I felt like if I was going to have to pay for a race, they should have at least gave us the Ithkul from MoO3 and the Nommo, even the Gas Giant inhabiting races as well.  These were strange races and altered gameplay style a bit.  Those were my favorite of the entire franchise and I don't forsee an official release for these.  :(  

Oh well, I am just happy they released this one.  It is still a ton of fun

Mixed is the right description. a worthy iteration of the Master of Orion series that I've spent weeks playing but I honestly can't recommend this game . it's just too damn buggy !

I was a huge fan of the original, and enjoed to some lesser degree most of the sequels.  I somehow missed this release, and just bought it.  (March 2018)  I play any Space strategy sim.  Love Stellaris, and Endless space, Planetbase, etc.  They all have their shining strengths.  I was a bit put off by the reviews on this, but I have to say after giving it  15 hours, it is charming, simpler take on the 4X space genre.  I really like the COmbat system, and of course customizing the ships to experiment with tactical roles in battle.  The quality of the voice acting makes me actually want to keep the volume on, (WIth the exception of the robot news anchors, but it's obviouos why they did that, it is so they can have audio descriptions of a WIDE variety of possible news stories, they can mix and match copy that way.)
It is not as grand as Stellaris, It is not as Elegant as Endless space 2, but it is fun.
It feels more like I'm playing a board game than any other 4x but I find that a refreshing take.
If you like space genre, and 4X in particular it's definitely worth the purchase, and the cost of the DLC.  Plenty of well reviewed mods, too, that I installed right off also, to fine tune the gameplay experience.
Quite happy with this game.

Two years too late (for the game, it's abandoned sadly) I'm changing my review to positive.

I'll leave my initial review at the end, but I just finished a game.
I had decided to try the current gen of 4x games again after awhile, in my my mind the top contenders are this, Stars in Shadow, Galciv 3, and Stellaris.  Some of the things I liked of this, were because they contrasted Stellaris.

In short, I liked the diplomacy (the races felt concrete and acted rationally) and that you could strategize and defend planets.  I still don't like that they went with an RTS combat design.... except for one move (my Advanced Transports were fighting and getting killed stupidly) I watched the AI lead my fleets and didn't think I could do better.  I felt the same way about ship design, the AI could do a better job than me.  These are things I miss from Moo2 -- still the oldest game I am able to install and play.  I did appreciate the elegance of the design, they kept it elegantly simple -- and that the production values were so good -- the best for a 4x game.  Sure, there were minor gripes still -- no end custscene or score page, no big reward really for being the MoO.... but I enjoyed the game and I may play it again.  The designers did fix some of my initial gripes with quality of life patches (for awhile, apparently), including not being able to rename planets and not having leaders (though you can't rename leaders, annoying).  And Elerians and Moo2 races....

Anyway, it wasn't awesome.... but if I have to pick between postive and negative it NOW gets a positive.  There isn't any perfect 4x game out that I've seen.  Steam workshop is a nice touch.  I reckon the series is dead again, but I wish they'd keep it going -- with a turn based combat model next time.

Not liking it. 
I bought it at full price, rare for me, but Moo2 is one of my favorite games of all time.  
Way back when I sold Moo2 as soon as Moo3 came out -- clearly a mistake in hindsight.
I was more cautious with this one, but somewhat hopeful.  I played a game up until someone got to Orion, I'm uninstalling for now.  I may try it again later 'cause I'm stupidly hopeful.  

Dealbreakers for me: 

1) Real-time combat.  They gave some lame explanation of you cant do fun turn based in space.  I only had small battles, but they were completely on autopilot.  Galciv 3 space battles are more interesting.  
Moo2 was one of the best TBS games of all time, this design point I knew would probably ruin it.  It did.  

2) You can't rename planets.  A feature the series always had, and helped me remember which system was specialized in what.  Now it's the battle of Ceti Alpha 6 or whatever every time.  Kills the immersion.

3) There are no heroes, like Moo2 had.  That added alot of flavor (though stupidly in Moo2 you couldn't rename the heroes, either).  They are missing.

I mention these 3, because otherwise it is a revamped version of Moo2.  The overall production values are really nice... so close to breathing fresh life into the series.  I was hoping they would pull off what a revival like happened with Xcom.

In me like in many people this name rings a bell and makes me remember the good times I had with Master of Orion 2. Then my mood darkens due to the complete break MoO3 did with the series. The question now is: Is this a worthy sucessor to MoO2? The answer isn't as easy as it seems.

Do you want a game with the races from the first two MoO games, the techs, the "feeling" and the micromanagement of the colonies? Then yes, this is your game. Those aspects are very well done and feel like the old games.

Did you hate the real-time combat of MoO3 and want the great deepth of MoO2s Tactical combat back? Then you'll be disappointed. While the combat isn't all bad and you can pause it at any time, it has a rather simple real-time combat system with not even roughly comparable deepth to MoO2.

So depending on what you want from am MoO game, this might or might not be for you.

While I really do miss the tactical combat, this is still a good game and mods make it even better.
It's not what I hoped for with the name "Master of Orion", but MoO3 wasn't either.

Like many people, I was a bit disappointed when the game came out. It was bland and small, in spite of the top-notch graphics and voice acting. Well, I re-installed a few weeks ago with 5x and the UCP mods and I have to say it's a very nice reprieve from GalCiv III and Stellaris' huge complexity. These mods add a huge amount of depth and scope to the game, yet the game mechanics remain fairly straightforward. It's a simpler game than these two other colossi, but it's still a lot of fun when you want to conquer a galaxy but don't want to have to open a spreadsheet to keep track of a thousand moving parts and how they affect each other. The game is colorful and has a lot of personality, and once you get an empire going, the combination of star lanes and warp gates makes war quite strategic. Ship customization is a quite deep and can make a huge difference in battles. I've found diplomacy to be competent -- have yet to see an AI do something utterly stupid or out of character. Finally, 400 turns into my current game, I've yet to experience any crashes or even significant bugs. 

Pro tip: For those who own an Oculus Rift (or perhaps a Vive, although I'm not completely sure about this), do yourself a favor and buy Tridef VR to play this one. Play it with the default profile (Stereo) and you'll swear it's native 3D on a HUGE screen. It's fantastic, especially the battles and the diplomacy. It's all in perfect, giant-sized 3D and the immersion is something else.

A good game hidden under many bugs even long after launch. Not to mention most games end at 250 turns due to it becoming stuck "Processing Turn". Your better off getting the original Master of Orion 2.

And...Nothing still not working. Has not had an update in over a year and now I cannot play the game at all.  So finally giving it a review and it has to be thumbs down since the game is not playable and does not look like NGD Studios is going to fix the problem.

Master of Orion 2 was a mark in gaming history, and probably the best game I've played. I didn't expect much of this one, but it manages to disappoint and to put a bad taste in my mouth... so, here we go:

- Missiles and beam weapons don't actually miss you, they hit your ship, show a shield block effect, and have a "miss" text effect. That's the strangest and most lazy development logic, which also breaks the game. Having a +50 missile evasion shows 100 missiles hit your ship, with a big "miss" text, but when facing more advanced missiles, they do an area damage and always damage your ship by exploding at point blank range. That's not how a missile works. 

- Ships can't hit the broadside of a titan class barn, no matter which weapon or what computer they are using. A +150 computer ship with 6 disruptor cannons missed the 12 first shots onto a space station, from a medium range. The whole combat is confusing, showing a "miss" effect on a target that you'd hit with a rock. That leads to you installing torpedoes in all of your ships and destroying fleets 10 times bigger than you. In fact, I manage to beat the game twice and I still don't know how ship combat works...


- The whole combat control is flawed. while attacking a specific ship, your ship will auto fire on any other ship that is in range. Most often, the "dreadful" Frigate class AI will hover around your ship, and no matter what you do your ship will target that frigate with heavy weapons and miss, while your actual target will casually fire at you.

- Most systems are either bugged or not balanced, with or without modding. The pulsar is automatic and only works on the first missile, the cloaking/phase cloak is non-intuitive, the displacement device doesn't work if you exceded the range, under attack or in a nebula but you have to guess if it will work or not. Spent tons of hours saving, placing a system, attacking something, then trying to figure out how to create the "best of the best" ship design. turns out none of these systems work, and all you need is defense and lots of torpedoes.

- Speaking of saves, today I found each game save is 450Mb (??!!) large. I actually started this review a moment after finding out that this game clogged my drive with 150GB

- Most buildings are "System Unique" but they don't give any bonuses to the other planets in that system. I know, it's confusing, but the simple analogy would be that if Texas has built a university, no other state in can build a university in the entire USA. BTW most buildings in the game are not balanced, and it takes literrally 150 years to build a proper economy. 

- Building a colony ship on a captured silicoid by me the Psylon, actually creates a Psylon colony ship. sending a civic transport does send Silicoid, unless you have a mixed colony, at which point you can't send control who you send. the whole civic management, and having to drag citizens one at a time, is both counters productive and full of design flaws

- And yes, they managed to ruin the Silicoids. you can't play them as their population doesn't grow. You literally can't invest in the growth of Lithvore or cybernetic races, while you can in any other race that relies on food. That's practically punishing you for investing 12 points on a race ability without doing internet research. Did I mention the word design flaw yet?

- tech tree doesn't make any sense. there are 5 major technologies that will give you tons of bonus, while the rest are just a "you can now spend 20 turns to build something that gives you 10% bonus in something" techs.

- Espionage is broken. I'm not sure if it was tested. I gradually sent multiple spies to an inferior race to steal that specific tech. they all stole a technology that I already owned, and they did that turn after turn. I wasn't surprised, by now it was the 20th or so time that I spent resources and time on a master plan, just to find that it's broken by the game's design

- space travel is broken. you need to go sector to sector jump-game style, but it takes you an extra turn to go to the other side of the sector. A ship with a mega-hyper-drive can actually reach the same time as one with the basic jump drive. I could think up of a half-dozen better ways to reward you when you get a better drive, one of which is the original fuel and warp dissipator based design from the original game

Wow, I can keep going and going with this. To sum it up, the devs did not play the original game, or they misinterpreted the gameplay, or just didn't have a budget to fully develop its predecessor. These things happen, but Master of Orion is considered one of the best 4X turn-based game, and its name is now ruined by a new version with better graphics and much worse gameplay, and I'm not even mentioning the bugs and crashes I experienced

I mean, it's a game from the 90's. How hard is it to copy and improve it it ? Devs could have just used the original design and tweak it, instead of creating a worse game.

Not a bad 4X game at all.  I would recommend it to anyone that is new to the genre or new to Masters of Orion.  It isn't better than the MOO1 or MOO2, but definitely better than MOO3.  I mean, almost every game out there is better than MOO3.

For those familiar with the genre, I would say that you probably won't like the combat.  Also, the star map has lanes and choke points for each star system.  This can be a good thing and a bad thing.  It does seem to be more restrictive, but from a strategic standpoint it can be an interesting feature.

Anywho, I played this during Beta quite a bit and also around launch.  I put about 8~9ish hours in it recently.  It runs a lot better than it used to.  

As I said, it is a decent 4X game.  If you just love all kinds of 4X games then I would say give this one a try.  If you are a 4X veteran and are looking for something different, complex, or new, then you should probably pass on this.

I wrote this originally in reply to a thread about "Why doesn't this game have more players?"  Here's my answer in the form of a brief review.  TL;dr at the bottom.

Master of Orion has the same problem that a taco product called "Big Mac II" has. In that it hoped to sell copies and maintain a playerbase using a particular brandname while doing fairly little to honor the substance of what its named after.

It's not that it's a buggy mess--though there are things that could be improved. It's not that the game is too short (I'm in a 500 turn game right now...I am still only 3/4 of the way through the tech tree and realistically, I couldn't have ended the game before now either...there's still content for me to explore even after that many turns in just one game).

The one thing the game is absolutely missing for me, and its a real shame, is that Real-Time battles are absent in multiplayer...you can still play a full multiplayer game and use the game's autoresolve function, but it really sucks the fun out of it for me, personally. So I play SP and just like any SP strategy game...once you figure out the AI's tricks, you can't really lose unless you are going to mod it or enable cheats for it or something.

Anyway, about purchasing the game:

If you are someone who has never played a Master of Orion game before, you are going to have a great time. Especially if you like or are interested in Stellaris and Sins of a Solar Empire. However, if you played Master of Orion (the original from the early days of computer gaming) or its actual sequel Master of Orion II, then you will probably hate this game. It's not turn-based like the originals, its combat, for better or worse is real-time and certain decisions about how to place your ships, for example, aren't as important as they used to be. The decisions you make in battle are really about which ship should fire at what enemy ship. 

You still have enough influence to say, take a battle you were "supposed" to lose according to the little victory probability bar, and then through good management, win that battle. BUT it's not as significant as in previous Master of Orion titles. There are just some engagements you cannot win, and from what I remember about the originals that was rarely the case--you could win as an underdog, and even against the AI a technological advantage didn't guarantee victory. This made battles exciting, even against less developed AI empires. To a certain degree that's missing here in this title. Yes, you have influence over battles that you're commanding...no, you aren't going to defeat the Antarans with anything less than the end tier weapon and defense tech...there's just no way mathematically for your ships to do it.

Some people saw that as a major regression and not a real advantage of Real-Time battles and abandoned the title.

TL;DR:

So in summary: Good game if you come from it with a clean slate. It has AAA graphics and voice acting, and despite a few examples is bug free and performs well on a technical level. The real time battles suffer from the same issues as Total War: you have influence over the outcome if you command them BUT there are just some units you can create (or face off against) that WILL beat you no matter what because of their stats. Even so, it's definitely a good game for 2016/2017 and has no major drawbacks that aren't drawbacks in any of the other Turn-Based/Real Time hybrid strategy games.

That said, it's a bad Master of Orion game, much like a taco is a bad hamburger. If you are buying it for nostalgic purposes, you are going to be disappointed. There are probably other games that are better spiritual successors, ironically enough.

Review disclaimer : I've never played the first three games, so this game is my first experience of the series (although i have just recently added MoO1 and 2 in my steam libraray) so my review is coming from a neutral position, with no positive or negative pre-conceptions if i was a long term fan and/or hater of the series.

Review disclaimer 2 : Have only played the Humans, Psilons, Alkari and Darloks so far.

Pros :
Interesting races with different characteristics making them feel unqiue and different to the other races.
Clean and crisp graphics
Warp Lanes (some people might have this in a 'Con' colume) - can be strategically and tactically used in various ways, especially used in conjuction with warp gateways (tech you can research)
Ability to design and custom fit your layouts / blueprints for your ships - always fun doing this :)
Civilisation type feel to the game with multiple ways to win, with the game being turned based generally (excluding rts combat).
GNN can be funny at times (some ppls might find them annoying - but thankfully there's a option to turn off GNN) and provides some niffy updates / random events
Ability to customise games, with different galaxy sizes, galaxy age, galaxy types, number of AI / human opponents, change game speeds and difficulty levels.

Cons :
Tutorial is not fleshed out enough and doesnt do enough to explain all the key concepts needed to play the game succesfully
At the time of writing this review, the rts combat is simple and lacking a bit of depth. Currently i dont believe its available for MP (simulation only) though this could change or be patched in.
Pirates were under used. No diplomatic, mercenary or bounty hunting options with them. Pirates dont really level / tech up to much as far as im aware so far (though i haven't played the harder difficulty levels so i could be wrong!)
Occasional bugs / glitches with AI for some races and they might act "OOC" in their dealings with the player(s).
Lack of a proper story / campaign mode.

Overall i've enjoyed this game so far, and hope to play the other races soon to find out how they play / what they are capable of. Some of the races that i've played are fun to play, but honestly i belive they might need some tweaking in terms of balancing. The Psilons are probably just a bit o.p. when it comes to technology, where as the Darloks are weak in comparison and their spying (while strong) isn't that strong to make up the difference. Haven't played the rest of the other races yet so please bear that in mind. Very little ground combat, all of it being simulated so if you're looking for a game where you can fight space and ground battles (ala Star Wars : Empire At War / Forces of Corruption) you will be disappointed.

Not too bad a game and has the potential to be great, but definately will need some work in terms of balancing and content patched in, alongside a full tutorial to help us MoO newbies learn the game better. At the risk of annoying long term fans of the series, i currently rate this game :

6.8 / 10
Above Average, with alot of potential :) 

UPDATE : Have played the Mrrshan Pride. This race seems best geared for an early conquest victory, with the race starting with destroyers and better marines. They do have an advanage in terms of other races accepting deals, though this is useful later in game, not at the start.

Their tech seems inefficient however, so if a game drags on, then the Mrrshan Pride could find themselves at a serious disadvantage tech wise, especially if they're up against the Psilons. Theres very little ground combat so far in game, so the"advantage" of better marines isnt that useful. Best bet is to build an early fleet and "Zerg Rush" opponents before they can build / tech up to much.

UPDATE 2 : Have now played a little bit of the Klackon hive. This race seems to be the Zerg / Tyranids of this game (whatever your preference is lol). They are an insect race, controlled by a hive mind, led by a queen (sounding familar yet? ROFL).

They have an insane production rate for ships and buildings, and grow and insane amount of food, which in turn increases their numbers to acheive higher production values. If their tech and research wasn't so poor / slow i would say they're o.p but i'm assuming this is the game's natural balance to their overall high production / population advantages. Note : they also have a beginning disadvantage diplomatically as well, but no where near as pronounced as the tech disadvantage.

UPDATE 3 : Have played the Sakkara race. This race is kind of a reptilian / dinosaur race and has been in previous versions of MoO (not that i have played them!). They are an aggressive and highly reproductive race (holy hell does this race have a big advantage over others in terms of population growth rate!).

Because of their high reproductive rate, this race is an expansionist race, especially since they get the biology tech straight off the bat! They do suffer a disadvantage in terms of diplomacy, and their technology/research is uncreative, which might hurt their cause late game. A race it seems best suited to be aggressive early before the other races can catch up in numbers or tech.

UPDATE 4 : The terrans is the dlc race unlocked intially when i bought the collectors edition. This may have changed in the following months so i will review the race and how they play, rather than get into the 'politics' of BS dlc, mircotransactions etc :p

The Terrans are considered to be an 'evil' faction, mainly being an aggressive, militant race. They get extra command points, start with destroyers and have a bonus to moral which make them an ideal race to be an aggressive player early on. Properly played, the terran race can be quite a handful, especially with their moral bonus you can set their tax rate to maximum without having to worry too much about moral drops and striking workers. From what i've played so far, they are best at attacking early though they can be decent late game with their tax rate / moral advantages.
Dont' seem to have too many weaknesses, so the Terrans might seem OP at first.

UPDATE 5 : Have played the Meklars now and they seem to be one of the most powerful races in the game. This race is the 'borg' race of Master of Orion. Have ships that are powerful, bonus to both food consumption, production from population and their ships have the nasty habit of self repairing! All this race needs to do in game is to say "Resistance is futile" and boom instant law suit lol just kidding XD

I am a fanatical fan of MOO1 and 2 (we won't talk about 3), so I approached this new version with much skepticism.  The early bad (terrible) reviews also scared me away. Lets be clear, MOO2 will always be the best game in this genre, nestalgia combined with some truely awesome features makes that almost a certainty.  That said, MOO2 gets harder and harder to play as the interface ages, and, lets be honest, a lack of new content even with mods.  MOO?4? (this game) does the best job to date of trying to keep up with MOO2 and i've enjoyed all of my time playing it.  You have to look past some minor things (i'll leave the details to other reviews), but overall I was very pleased to spend quite a few hours playing this game.  I paid $30 for this game and I would say it is well priced at that point.

This is a remake of the classic 4x genre, personally I didn't dislike this game, but I didn't get super excited about it either. Let's break it down quickly:

1. Need DLC to have more the races, without DLC, there's very few races in the game, that's feels like I've been had.

2. The tech advancement is good and well-planned and there's a logical development path.

3. The planet development is good and well-thought out.

4. The UI is easy to use, a plus for sure. 

5. Several paths to victory is good.

6. Using stellar converters to completely destroy the planets of your rival is fun, wish there was multiple cutscenes to show the destruction though, as after seeing it for the 100th time, it does finally get old. 

7. The space battles are great, with a movie mode or tactical command, watching the movie mode is simply cool with fighter or missile views as they're inbound to their target. Tatical decisions in the battle make a difference between winning and losing, usually the auto-resolve will cause you to lose when you would otherwise wipe them out when commanding yourself, making you having to nearly command every battle yourself. 

8. Galaxy can feel small unless again you buy the DLC and have more races in the game, as the game will eventually be 3-4 civilizations vying for control and slugging it out with stellar converters.

Graphics: 7  (+1 Mini-cutscenes are a huge plus) : 8
Sound(Effects and Music): 8
AI: logical and makes sense; however, not easy to make allies even if you just declared war on their enemy and give them lots of tech to try to make friends : 7

Bottomline: Buy if it's on sale 50% or more off and the DLC's are too, otherwise wait.

I played the famed Master of Orion 2 years ago, and was tempted to pick up 3 and never did. From what I can tell, 3 had many features that were poorly implemented, and a UI that battled the player in bloody conflict in whatever you wished to do.

I say this implying that I am familiar with the franchise and it's gameplay, even though it was many years ago. Interestingly I turn 20 in just a few days, it has been 20 years since the release of Master of Orion 2: Battle at Antares.

But with all that aside, I shall turn to what you desire to know. The game is overall decent, although a bit different from the franchise' 1997 entry. But that is to be expected and it is not necessarily entirely a bad thing. The gameplay works well although some features need a bit of ironing out as is unfortunately the norm for games today. The new developers took cues from Master of Orion 3 and have designed a UI so clean it could be comparitive to a Windex commercial. Everything I need to know is displayed in front of me, and anything else is a click away. There are a few things that should be clarified, i.e. espionage missions. "Hacking" does not stop all research as it tells you, it halves the output of a faction. Or "Destablize", it does not actually reduce relations with all other factions, only with one, and by small amounts.

I am in my third playthrough on "Very Hard" after finding "Hard" to be a cakewalk. I remember struggling with great challenge even on "Average" in Master of Orion 2. I have yet to experiment with commanding the battles, I leave them to an AI commander. But I have read from other players that they are dissapointing and poorly implemented overall. They are real-time instead of the traditional turn-based of the franchise, and were so buggy that they disallowed them in multiplayer altogether. That action is pretty sad considering I would think a large aspect of versus gameplay would be pitting your fleets against eachother to see who is the better commander. 

Regarding the AI, I find it pathetic and hopeless. It is not hard for me to amass military strength so intimidating that all races feel "Threatened" by me, and bow down at my feet in worship. Also they handle finances without any intelligence at all. They are bad at making investments in the financial victory, just handing it to you every time. I always have to pay their part of the trade treaty, and I get the impression that they spend their money on things that are not very beneficial, wasting it.

The game is relatively enjoyable but needs some serious work here and there. I do find their move to add three of the classic races in 2 as DLC quite distasteful.

Cons:
- Information sometimes incorrect ingame
- Some bugs
- Three of the original factions from Master of Orion 2 have been chopped into a DLC
- Not challenging whatsoever
- Inactive servers.

Sure enough, as with every other game nowadays, no game launches without bugs, i have come to accept that as a given truth with every designer, and developer, so for people to expect the perfect game is like people to expect to be given three wishes on their 21st birthday to make things their way, not realistic, and not going to happen. As a casual, though avid, fan of the 4X genra, I appreciate the enormous user-friendliness of the title. From automatic auto-saving to the streamlined Empire management screen, playing MO is an absolute breeze. Having said that, the game brings little innovation to the series, beyond improved graphics. Not to say there's nothing new, just that it all feels a little shallow. The diplomacy system is good, compared to civ titles. The AI seems hopelessly outmatched as a match goes on, but maybe that's just the cave-dwelling gamer in me talking. The difference between races is noticeable, but feels largely cosmetic. Every match basically boils down to frantic expansion, cutting off the AI's attempts at expanding and a mad rush to bigger and better ships. This is true regardless of race and, maybe, regardless of game.

Anyway, it's alright, but I wouldn't pay full price for it.

P.S. Oh, how could I forget! Also, this game suffers from the epidemic of terrible endings. Since the devs (rightfully) assume few people will make it to the actual end of a match, since it's so frigging boring, there was exactly zero humor or CGI invested into the ending cutscenes. Excuse me, did I say cutscenes? I meant text pop-ups. As someone who grew up with Red Alert's amazing stories, being rewarded for dozens of hours of gameplay with a "you win, congrats" is just short of insulting. Seriously, splurging on five million trailers and zero ending cinematics isn't capitalism, it's alienating your hardcore customer base. Screw that. I'd much rather pay extra for more story and cinematics, than for another, barely different, race.

Update 10/7/2017 : The game is now dead and abandoned. Devs stole our money and only updated the game for about a year. No major updates ever came out. Most major bugs remain. AI is still terrible. They still have the nerve to sell this game and its DLC at its original full price. Stay away from this and any other titles by this company! I originally didn't recommend this game because of issues I stated in my original review below. At this rate, I'd tell you it's not worth playing unless the company PAYS YOU to play it. The perfect example of a cash grab using a famous series. Not sure if Master of Orion series will ever recover from this one, sadly. 

Original Review 3/1/2017 :

I'm going to have to go ahead and say I don't recommend the game at its current price. While it is an honorable start to being a glorious 4x space stategy game, and it does feel a lot more like MOO to me than MOO 3 did.... overall the experience just kind of peeters out after an unsatisfactory amount of time.

Pros :
- Most of the UI functions smoothly
- A good deal of MOO lore is included
- FPS is good and stable on a mid-range machine, even with all graphics options turned up
- The graphics are acceptable, but nothing special
- MUCH less buggy than 1 year ago, but still very buggy

Cons :
- I think "terrible" is actually a poor word to use to describe the AI. The right word is "ridiculous." Nothing they do makes sense
- AI uses cheats instead of tactics at higher difficulty levels to become harder
- The opening video seems to lag for me, not sure what that's all about
- Turn length increases far too quickly
- Workshop community, as always, is trying its best... but the game has design limitations currently which are severely limiting the depth, functionability, and compatibility of the mods.
- Community agrees that game is only about 1/2 done, at most, but updates have screeched to a halt in the last few months. Furthermore the devs have been in much less communication with the community than they had been.
- The pirates function way too shallow fo my taste. They essentially just attack as soon as their ships are spawned. They do not at all feel like their own hybrid civilization. No way to form diplomacy with them either. I know this is uncommon in 4x games anyway, but it really is a feature that would add depth... if you could have a back-door way of getting on the good side of pirates, but bad side of everyone else in doing so.
- Random pauses between screens at time, especially when entering a battle.
- Tech tree is too short, too shallow, too streamlined, too everything that makes a tech tree unexciting
- Very limited customization options for galaxies. Even with mods.
- The largest galaxy type that comes with the game would be considered medium in most 4x games.
- Can't rename planets/star systems
- Quite possibly some of the most underwhelming paid DLC I've ever seen for this genre of game
- They made all the leaders/species look way too cartoony in most instances. I think using these graphics but sticking to MOO 1 and 2 lore (it seemed like a rather rustic, raw, and Babylon 5-ish universe did it not? Now it feels like Shrek in Space)

The game felt like it was progressing quickly until the fall so perhaps the devs are just working on something big, let's hope so. But until then, thumbs down.

Also, I have quite a bit more experience than the 8.5 hours recorded on steam.

I give Master of Orion a CONDITIONAL recommendation:
It's a good ENTRY POINT for people just getting into the 4x genre.

It seems that we can all forget about Master of Orion 3 now, right? But the question is: should we? The game didn't turn out well, but the things it tried to do were important to the 4x genre. It tried to eliminate micro-management and allow players to control a truly massive empire. It tried to focus most of the challenge and intrigue on the second half of the game, rather than it all being front-loaded into the early stages. These are valiant goals for a 4x to strive for. It's a shame that they didn't work out.

This rebooted Master of Orion is forgetting all of that and simply hitting the reset button. Though I had some fun, I don't see myself coming back to Master of Orion once I'm done with it.

Master of Orion: Conquer the Stars doesn't have any fatal flaws. It looks slick and has a lot of nice bells and whistles. It just doesn't do anything particularly well, and some of the systems and mechanics have annoying nagging flaws and feel a bit shallow. If anything, Master of Orion works well as a fairly gentle introduction to 4x strategy. It's easy to jump into, and games play pretty quickly. I actually completed an entire game in a single afternoon -- something that's nigh impossible in a game of Civilization VI. If you're new to the genre, then this is a great introduction. It has enough going for it to be interesting, but isn't going to overwhelm you in the way that a bigger 4x game like Endless Space or Europa Universalis or Stellaris might.

This is a solid successor to the classic Master of Orion games, and it's a great entry-point if you're interested in the genre. For experienced 4x players, there's bigger, better games on the market right now.

I invite you to please check out my full review on my personal blog:
http://www.megabearsfan.net/post/2017/08/07/Master-of-Orion-(2016)-game-review.aspx

Master of Orion CTS is a strange beast. 

On the one side, hey, it's not MOO3! THe game is certainly enjoyable, and you can have a lot of hours of fun with it. The campiness is back, all the races are there, fleshed out for everyone to see, graphics look good and there are no obvious setbacks.

On the other hand, IT seems like a missed oportunity at many junctures. While it's great to have MOO for our generation, it fails to be as memorable as the first two, because it's just not innovative. Everything you do here you probably already did in moo1 and moo2. 

Also, some of the design choices are just odd. I mean, you can say yeah to starlanes or nay to starlantes, but once you decide to go with them, you have to own them, and i think they really missed the spot on this one. 

Antarans are fun, but they fail to be a "Galactic scale" threat and just turn into the new pirates V2.0, And If starlanes and choke points are going to be that important, then why not make the star-system scale as engaging as the galaxy map fleet movement ? Having moving from one planet to the next be as time consuming as moving from one star to the next just doesn't feel all that right. I don't presume to know how to fix it, but i can certainly spot there's some parts of the magic that are not as shinny as they should. 

I do enjoy the game a lot, and plan to get back to it tough. Hope you like the review!

MOO CTS plays it safe by rehashing MOO2 with modern technology.  It's hard to fail at that but then it won't be anything revolutionary.   The most significant difference is that the map is a bit more like MOO3 with choke points - requiring more strategic selection of systems.  That's an upgrade.  

The style and artwork of the game is great.  

The game is much better balanced than MOO2 - but still stays true to the nature of each race (making some very OP - *cough* Elerian *cough*).  It's for the better IMO.  Where balance fails is with the fast pace of science (then you're greeted with science points contributing to nothing but score once completing the tree) and the slow pace of population growth.  Fortunately these can be tweeked in settings.  Set growth to fast and tech to very slow.

The biggest and most significant negative is how brain dead the AI is.  It is by far the most predictable and utterly ineffective AI I have come across.   It's at least better than the impossibly brutal AI of MOO3.. 

In the end it's good enough to be the MOO game to play for the modern gamer.  MOO2 is still amazing and you should play it but MOO CTS will probably get much more play time.   Definitely worth a buy if you like turn based strategery.

WELL this would be a great remake! If you wouldn't need to buy the DLC to make it a good remake This is alos the biggest problem of the game. It quite obviously was split in two parts, one whole product served as an inferior product with an expensive fix. I don't like this practice!

BUT with the Antares DLC it is the complete Master of Orion 2 remake. Those who liked MoO2 will at once feel at home. For everyone else, MoO is a 4X strategy game on the light side of the genre, a good point to start roundbased 4X strategy. AI is mildly acceptable and you have enough choice in difficulty. Races are plenty and well fleshed out, and play really differently. GNN-News get old quite fast, but you can disable them. All in all I love it. But I am a huge fan of the old MoO2 so 33% of my excitement originate in nostalgia.

This is not a Master of Orion game.
They ditched all of the core mechanics of what I & II great games.

For a new generation of MOM, this is a competent adoption, with some glaring issues. They aren't unplayable issues, but they do take some enjoyment out of the game.

The bright spots: The voice actors do a bueatiful job and were worth every penny. You may get tired of them after a while, but they are enjoyable, and it's worth the price of admission to experience them all. 

The game hybrids between MOO 1 and 2 Economic model. You got population you can specialize in development and it has planetary surface development, but it does feel a lot like the Moo1 Sliders. None of this is a bad thing, and it feels nice wihtout having to micromanage too heavily.

Visuals are wonderful, and I tend to enjoy the colonization sequences. This might be a downside for others, but for me it doesn't get boring. At least not yet.

If you want to finish a game in a day or two, it is possible. Not a lot of strategy games lately can say this.

Downsides

Space Combat. OMG, you just have no control, it's almost worse than Moo3. It just is not servicable. I recommend skipping it. It's pretty, but not enjoyable at all.

Tech Tree : They get rid of the older system trees, and replace it with a singular development Civilization Style Tree. It's... okay. It has a few obvious paths through it. It's not as fun as Moo2's tree, but it serves welll.

Diplomacy - Yeah... it's... Well, it's not like they go to war at a drop of a hat, and the computer will work against itself, but if there is tech to trade, they'll trade it between itself before they'll trade it with you. 

Overall, if you are new to the genre, and if you are an old fan, or if you just like space opera, this is a servicabe 4X game that honors it's sources well. If you are already a master of the genre and more complex space sims, you probably want to give this a pass. However, the voice performances are at least worth looking at.

Played this on Early Access and I was ... strongly ambivalent. Thought this was an exercise in futility back then.

Returned to the game since and -- it's GREAT.

It's not the most elaborate 4X game out there, but this game really manages to capture a perfect compromise between the original three Master of Orion games and comes up with a great niche spot in the current state of the genre.

Basically it has the simple elegence of MOO1 (and I mean this as a massive compliment), the colony building of MOO2 and the starlanes of MOO3.

I feel the starlanes are the most controversial feature of this game. I personally love them. To me they're a great way of keeping fleets sane, meaningful, and manageable. I like that you have fronts limited to a selection of systems. They make bases more meaningful too.

Overall simplicity -- I love games like Stellaris, but they're "big". I like that Master of Orion has everything on a boardgame-like board and I can understand what's going on in the big picture with generally understanded mechanics.

I still play Galactic Civilizations III and Stellaris regularly (and Civ 6), but Master of Orion definitely has a place in that echelon and I appreciate I can have a good solid campaign in 5-10 hours as opposed to 2-5x that...

Why do I like this game?

The most common argument against the new Master of Orion is the simplicity of the gameplay, but actually I see it as a huge advantage compared to other 4x games. I play sci-fi programs to experience the joy of mere exploration, to meet unique alien races, to participate in galactic parley or to conquer and crush "lesser" beings - withouth the burden of endless micromanagement. I like sci-fi games for the athmosphere, but too much detail can kill the fun, at least for me.

And this is why MoO caught my attention, as it does not want to burden me with details in every corner, instead it offers a smooth ride across the galaxy every time I play it. Do I want to oversee and control each of my colonies, or do I want just to gather a fleet and wage war against others? It is totally up to me, as the game can offer pretty much support in every aspect, including colony management, ship design, research etc. Even if we wish to go without the help of the game, the mechanics are still easy to understand and master, and for me this is a pro and not a con.

So if you seek a 4x game with serious micromanagement and weeks-long gameplay for every single run, in which you can put the pants on every single colonist by yourself, than you will probably find MoO a bit simple for your taste. However MoO can and will give you unique races, fancy-looking fleets, detailed galaxies and huge space battles, not to mention the athmosphere I really like in this game - this is where MoO truly excels.

Of course this game also has some drawbacks: the rather basic spy system, sometimes inbalanced racial traits and the simplicity of the AI, but if we look the big picture, the final verdict is definitely positive.

But enough talk, I must get back to my Sakkra fleet to crush the weasel Darlok scum once and for all...

I've bought this game on the first day of it's EA release on GOG and have played more than 170 hours of it. As most of the discussion about the game takes place on steam, i have been present in the forums here. As the game was on sale on steam this summer (2017) i decided to get it here as well.

I've been a huge fan of the original MOO since 1993 and have got every sequel. While they said that they wanted to make a reboot of the original game, this is actually a full reboot of MOO2. The main difference is the presence of starlanes. While i would have very much preferred not to have starlanes (as i don't think it belongs to the core mechanics of the first two games), i find the implementation ok. It does however slow the gameplay a lot and, while, it doesn't had anything valuable imho, it does make the game a more relaxed experience as you can take your time to build up an empire and defend it. The changes made to the original games make it closer to the Civilization games. Actually, it could very well have been done by the same team who made Civilization 5. 

This game has been my main game for 2016 and i really recommend it. It's been a great experience to play this with my kids...i enjoy to play by myself but i think it's a good game for the family.

MOO2 stands out for it's art, sense of humour, tactical combat and (re-)playability.

Conquer the Stars (CTS) redelivers the formula with some great innovations that eliminate or contextualise some of the more annoying aspects of MOO2 (speaking as someone who has sunk... *ahem*... some time into MOO).

The default game is great but the "[b]5X - The Ultimate Balance Mod[/b]" is better - definitely a lot better than MOO2.

[h1]The Feels[/h1]

This game has good assets, if ya know what I mean  ;)

I enjoyed the music a lot when I started playing as it has a great drifting-above-it-all-in-space sort of vibe.

The game art and UI are iconic rather than detailed. Personally I think this is a great move if the game is going to be your re-playable 4X go-to.

Useability is king in 4X and many good titles have been subtly aggravating due to an overabundance of detail in a UI already laden with icons and numbers to interpret. The simple lines, contrast and typography of CTS make it accessible enough for new 4Xers and fast enough for veterans.

That being said, the leaders, planets, backdrops and cut-scenes are all great and deal up the atmosphere at the right time in contexts where it rewards an achievement or adds a dose of flavour to what would otherwise be a workflow diagram (ah 4X, we love you).

[h1]The Strats[/h1]

Well I've lost my last two games and I wasn't even on the highest difficulty or trying to challenge myself so there must be something there  :)

MOO2 and CTS both have an unusual talent for making the mid-game of a 4X playable. In almost all 4Xes, the winning strategy is to gear up for the AI's first assault, win it on favourable ground and then conquer them while they're rebuilding their armies. Then you have 2 players worth of resources and the game is more or less won.
For extreme difficulties, this is usually achieved by exploiting particular glitches of the AI (for example, stealing workers in Civ).

In MOO, the glitches are part of the gameplay and evolve as the game progresses. In the early game diplomatic relations take time to worsen so wars (usually) don't kick off immediately and a bit of compromise can help you eke out a small empire with a weak early game race. And mid game allows ship designs that can use the player's RTS skills to out-manouver opponents and gain marginal advantages against a superior foe, allowing your strat to play out.

Where this differs from MOO2 is that espionage sucks ass and is completely pointless. Where once a game with Darlocks in it would mean a bunch of unexpected wars as they framed you for their misdeads, they're a free conquest in CTS. I haven't played the balance mod enough yet to see if they've fixed it but there are some obvious improvements so maybe.

[h1]Tactical Combat[/h1]

Before I start, I think I need to mention that I play twitch games like MOBAs and FPS so I don't have a mechanical challenge to overcome with realtime combat.

I like the tactical combat and the sense of needing to micro properly with some kinds of ship designs is really welcome, as is the faster pace for larger battles.

That being said, I probably like Endless Space's approach of more cinematic battles with a surprisingly deep poker-ish card game over the top of it more. Star Drive 1 & 2 definitely get the prize for having the most intelligent system but also having computational complexity issues that really hurt the quality of the game a lot. Stellaris's combat is just boring and the ships look awful.

My criticism is in the lack of numbers. Why can't there be numbers and rule text flying everywhere!??! IMHO, that's what people are actually missing from the original experience - there's no feedback that your design is actually working.

[h1]OMG, is this still going[/h1]

I have no idea why I'm writing a review for a Steam game. I think I'm procrastinating... I definitely have better things to be doing.  :)

I, and others, were very disappointed with a lot of what Wargaming initially released and it was hard to understand where they were coming from (seriously, some of it was pretty dumb). However, it's in a really good place now and the 5X balance mod is the best thing since candy and cocaine. Happy gaming.

It is an improved version of MOO3. Interface and planet management is polished, fast and really fun to play. Saves and loads are really quick. AI seems OK so far, it is easier than previous versions to do treaties or agreements (at least on normal difficulty). The battle interface could be done better, especially the cinematic representation when choosing automatic result.

In essence, especially for MOO3 players this is a really good upgrade game. There is a room for improvement but with mod community on the works and frequent upgrades, I think this game is worth your time, especially if you are a Master of Orion series fun.
The game has a groovy old school feel but nostalgia can only carry a torch so far before it fizzles. My biggest gripe was compared to other 4x games the uninspired tech tree was lacking.
new graphics....old game.  loved the old, the new lacked a bit for me...

Pros: It feels like MOO, and the voice acting is on par... ship customization is easy, however...
Cons: (and this is it for me...) The stupid command points. Maintenance on fleets on realistic, however, command points? I could have sworn I have fleets and fleets of ships in MOO2, in thsi game? I was lucky to have 4... each with maybe between 3-4 ships. 

This reboot needs to give way more command points, make fleets easier to create, rather than acting like a weed that sucks the life out of this game.

I firmly believe that 4X strategy games have every bit the right as the next game to have high production values, and this game shows just that. But it should be noted that when it comes to gameplay you won't find any new features here. It's a tride and true traditional 4X game all together, and damn it, I love it for that. I await to see further DLC from it, hopefully.
The feel of the classic games updated with modern systems and interface. Ive enjoyed it with no major issues.
Really have always loved this game since i was a child. played it for thousands of hours as MOO2. This is a stunning and wonderfully upgraded version of the classic turn based strategy genre 10/10

As a long term fan of the MOO franchise I had very high expectations. I was not dissapointed. They took the feel and mechanics and put a new hat on it, and then amped it up. If you played MOO2 then MOO3 you may not have liked the Tech tree from MOO3, well they kept the tech tree style from MOO2 :D Overall, as a fan from MOO to MOONEW ;P If you are a fan of the Master of Orion Series, this game is a must have. The only thing I wasn't a fan of is the Gnolam Empire being part of the DLC, the other races fine ok, but the Gnloam Empire is the only real Economic Race and should have been included in the core for a rounded selection. I just create my own race with the Gnolam Characteristics to get around that, eventually I'll get the DLC. GREAT GAME 10/10 Would buy again.
I think it is very much like I remember it playing when I was a kid. So nostalgic, I love it.

This game is not MOO2 with better graphics. This is MOO4, and it is a blast to play. The same races are still there and all of the tech plus much more tech, but the game play is completely different. The graphics are excellent. The sound is great, the game play is excellent. It is just a different game where you need a few different strategies than you used in MOO2. Every turn there is something to do. The game actually tells you about every bulid, every ship move, every spy. In MOO2 there were dozens of turns where nothing happens as you try to build buildings and units, which I did not care for.

This biggest change is "no fuel limits". That allows you to move all over the galaxy freely. To balance that change, there are now space lanes (ala Sins of the Solar Empire). Space lanes can be defended and blocked and fought over. This does restrict free movement to "any" planet but with no fuel requirements there is always a way around.

Also, no food freighters. There are techs that allow you to settle on any planet and not starve though, which allows you to colonize more freely.

Spying is completely different. You create a spy and then give him a mission. He may or may not succeed but if he does he gains spy levels which makes it easier to succeed. Spies now cost maintenance (higher level, higher cost) so no more 40+ spies.

I have played through this game several times now and have not felt the least bit disappointed or bored.

There is one item that is missing that should be in the game. When marines attack a planet there is no fight simulation. The units just disappear from the screen as they die. They also left out the view of the enemy marine armor, which was very helpful in MOO2.

All in all, this is a great game and I highly recommend it. Just don't try to find MOO2 here, you won't.

Having now played through a handful of complete campaigns, I have to give this at least a small thumbs up for such excellent production values.  It's really well executed on both Mac and Win, with an engaging visual look, engaging races, and a very nice user interface.

So, why only a "small" thumbs up?  Well, for all of the things they've done well here, I think they still really need to improve the AI implementation.  Generally I have found that the AI is not only pretty passive, but the behavior can also often be somewhat unintelligent.  To be honest, this led to some pretty sleepy campaigns.

So fundamentally I think they've designed a really lovely 4X platform here, and I can only hope that they will continue to work on improving the AI.

I tried to like this game. I really did.

I'm a big MoO2 fan.... and while this is very similar to MoO2, its basically a bad clone with updated graphics.

The enemy AI is so bad its silly.
The balance is non-existant.

Basically its really easy and doesn't require much in the way of brains.
